{"uri": "8118718588", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "07:59:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T07:59:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T07:59:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://metro.co.uk/2024/05/09/new-camera-shot-reveals-bayern-munichs-offside-goal-stood-20803719/", "title": "New camera shot reveals if Bayern Munich's offside goal should have stood", "body": "A fresh graphic from Wednesday's controversial Champions League clash between Real Madrid and Bayern Munich has revealed that play should not have been halted for offside.\n\nThe Bundesliga giants were closing in on a brilliant semi-final win at the Bernabeu after Alphonso Davies had put them ahead with a thunderous effort, only for the match to flip on its head in a chaotic finale.\n\nManager Thomas Tuchel had made a number of defensive subs, switching to a back five and subbing off Harry Kane, and eventually Real's pressure proved too much as the otherwise excellent Manuel Neuer spilled a shot and Joselu tucked home the rebound.\n\nJust three minutes later, the former Stoke City forward tapped home his second to seal the victory for Real after a lengthy offside check from VAR.\n\nBayern's players looked distraught but they still had over 10 minutes of added time to find an equaliser, and even without their four first-choice attackers on the pitch they still managed to carve out one big chance late on.\n\nAn optimistic long ball was floated into the box and headed away by Ferland Mendy, but only as far as Noussair Mazraoui who passed to Matthijs de Ligt, with the centre-back stroking the ball into the bottom corner.\n\nBefore the ball had reached him, however, the linesman had raised his flag for offside and referee Szymon Marciniak blew his whistle, with Real's players appearing to give up once they heard it and before De Ligt had rolled the ball in.\n\nHowever, officials are instructed to let the play continue for tight offside calls and Bayern were livid that the whistle had been blown so early - and they will be even more annoyed when they see that the chance was not offside.\n\nFootage from beIN SPORTS has confirmed that, while De Ligt was offside when the ball was first played, Mazraoui - who competes for the ball with Mendy - was not.\n\nAs De Ligt does not challenge for the first ball, he is not active, so the move should have been allowed to play out.\n\nBayern's players were still seething in the mixed zone afterwards when they spoke to the media, with De Ligt saying: 'The linesman said to me, \"I'm sorry, I made a mistake\".\n\n'The rule says that if it's not clear offside ... you have to keep playing.\n\n'And if you go in the last minute and you whistle like this, I think this is a big mistake. If it's offside or not, I don't know, VAR can check it, but if you don't check it, how can you see it? This is a shame.'\n\nTuchel was just as annoyed, telling TNT Sports: 'There was a disastrous decision from the linesman and the referee. It feels like a betrayal in the end.\n\n'The linesman says sorry but that does not help. To raise the flag in a moment like this... The referee sees we get the second ball and we get the shot. It's hard to swallow but that's the way it is.'\n\nReal Madrid will now take on Borussia Dortmund in the final of the Champions League at the very start of next month, while Bayern will end the season {"uri": "8118652400", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "07:16:36", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T07:16:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T07:16:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-13398865/Teary-Thomas-Tuchel-violation-rules-emotional-blast-Bayern-Munichs-Champions-League-loss-Real-Madrid.html", "title": "Teary Tuchel in new blast after Bayern Munich's loss to Real Madrid", "body": "Another nightmare... which players are to blame and should Thomas Tuchel come in? Listen to the It's All Kicking Off! Man United Crisis Special podcast\n\nThomas Tuchel had tears in his eyes as he tore into officials in a new blast after Bayern Munich were controversially denied a potential late equaliser against Real Madrid.\n\nThe Bundesliga giants crashed out of the Champions League on Wednesday night, as Los Blancos booked their place in next month's final at Wembley with a 4-3 aggregate victory, after two late goals from former Stoke forward Joselu.\n\nHowever, that wasn't the last of the drama, as Matthijs de Ligt netted in the 13th minute of injury time which would have sent the game to extra time, only for Polish referee Szymon Marciniak to have blown his whistle for offside moments before the ball hit the back of the net.\n\nReplays showed that the call was extremely tight, with Bayern's Noussair Mazraoui appearing at first glance to be onside despite the call. Due to the whistle already being blown, VAR could not intervene.\n\nDuring an interview with DAZN, as per BILD, Tuchel was visibly seen fighting back the tears as he hit out at a 'complete violation of the rules'.\n\nThomas Tuchel fought back the tears in a new blast at officials after Bayern Munich were denied a potential late equaliser during their Champions League defeat to Real Madrid\n\nMatthijs de Ligt was denied a late equaliser after it was adjudged there was an offside in the build-up, with the linesman flagging early\n\nBayern Munich were left to rue the controversial decision which otherwise could have seen the game to extra time at the Santiago Bernabeu on Wednesday night\n\nPodcast All episodes PODCAST: Listen to the latest episode of 'It's All Kicking Off!' EPISODE 84: Listen to the latest episode of 'It's All Kicking Off!' EPISODE 83: Listen to the latest episode of 'It's All Kicking Off!' PODCAST: Is the North London Derby the best game in the League? It's All Kicking Off! 'He's reaching De Bruyne levels' listen now Play on Apple Spotify\n\nHe said: 'This is a disaster, Toni's (Antonio Rudiger) leg is probably deeper than Mazraoui. It's an absolute disaster.'\n\nHe added: 'Imagine if Real Madrid let them keep running when they score their second goal. It would have been the same, the ball goes to Toni and the whistle is blown. The situation must be played out to the end. That's the rule. Especially when she's so close to the gate. Especially when it's so tight.\n\n'The assistant makes the first mistake, the referee makes the second mistake. He doesn't have to whistle, he can just wait and see.\n\n'That's what happened with the second goal. This is a violation of the rules.'\n\nOfficials are generally advised to delay their offside calls in case they are wrong.\n\nTuchel has been vocal about his anger surrounding the offside decision, telling TNT Sports that it 'felt like a betrayal'.\n\nIn his interview with DAZN, he added: 'There are no accusations. Everyone is so angry about the second decision because it probably would have counted as a goal.'\n\nTuchel, speaking to TNT Sports, revealed the assistant referee had apologised to him for flagging early in a move that could have cost his team the game.\n\nNoussair Mazraoui (right) thought he had scored a dramatic equaliser in the 103rd minute\n\nBayern players and staff were furious with the decision for the referee to blow the whistle early\n\nTuchel was visibly emotional during his post match interview with DAZN on Wednesday night\n\nHe said: 'We were almost there and a very unusual mistake of the best player (Manuel Neuer) for the equaliser, then we conceded in a very narrow decision in stoppage time.\n\n'Then we scored one and it was a disastrous decision from the linesman and the referee, so it feels almost like a betrayal in the end because of that decision.\n\n'The linesman said sorry. That does not help at that kind of level, to raise the flag in a decision like this, in a close decision in the last minute. The referee as well, he does not have to whistle, he sees that we win the second ball, he sees that we get the shot away. To whistle is a very, very bad decision.\n\n'It is against the rules and it is a bad decision from both of them. It is a disaster, tough to swallow, but it is the way it is.'\n\nMatthijs de Ligt had led the Bayern protests on the pitch, and echoed his manager's comments post-match in that he too had received an apology from the officials.\n\nBayern will now go trophyless for the season for the first time in over a decade.\n\nBayern Munich will finish the season trophyless, while Tuchel will leave the club this summer\n\n'We all know the rules if the offside is not clear then we have to play on,' said the Dutch defender. 'It's a disgrace that it happened against us and not for us at the other end when Joselu was almost offside and the game was allowed to continue.\n\n'A decision like that in the last minute is a mistake It's always easy to talk about the referee after the game but this time it's merited.'\n\nIt has already been confirmed that Tuchel will leave Bayern Munich at the end of the season.\n\nReal {"uri": "8118167461", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "22:56:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T22:56:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T22:56:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://talksport.com/football/1860131/thomas-tuchel-linseman-apoligises-bayern-munich-goal-real-madrid/", "title": "Tuchel says linesman apologised for 'betrayal' as Bayern goal not given", "body": "Thomas Tuchel says the linesman has apologised after Bayern Munich saw a late equaliser at Real Madrid controversially not given.\n\nAfter Joselu scored two late goals off the bench for Madrid in their stunning Champions League semi-final turnaround, Bayern believed they had sent the tie to extra-time.\n\nIn the 13th minute of second-half stoppage-time, Matthijs de Ligt scored inside the area but referee Szymon Marciniak blew for an offside flag just before.\n\nBayern's celebrations quickly turned to protests, with replays showing that it was a very tight call on Noussair Mazraoui but the linesman's early flag meant VAR couldn't check it.\n\nIt resulted in the German giants crashing out of the Champions League in dramatic circumstances and boss Tuchel vented his frustrations at the manner in which they fell to defeat.\n\nSpeaking to TNT Sports, he said: \"A disastrous decision from the linesman and from the referee... it feels almost like a betrayal in the end because of that decision.\"\n\nHe later added: \"The linesman said sorry but that does not help. At that kind of level, to raise the flag in a decision like this, a close decision in the last minute.\n\n\"And the referee as well, the referee does not have to whistle. He sees that we win the second ball, he sees that we get a shot away. To whistle is a very, very bad decision.\n\n\"It's against the rules and it's a bad decision from both of them, it's a disaster. Tough to swallow but that's the way it is.\"\n\nDe Ligt was also angered by the decision as he told beIN SPORTS: \"I think this is a big, big, big mistake. If it's offside or not, I don't know, you can check it but if you don't check it how can you see it?\"\n\nHe added: \"The linesman said to me, 'Sorry, I made a mistake.' {"uri": "2024-05-350285249", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "13:30:02", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T13:30:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T23:18:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://sg.news.yahoo.com/thomas-tuchel-blasts-officials-disastrous-231841982.html", "title": "Thomas Tuchel blasts officials after 'disastrous' offside decision costs Bayern Munich dearly", "body": "Bayern Munich manager Thomas Tuchel described the Uefa referees' decision-making as a \"disaster\" after his team were denied a late equaliser that would have taken their dramatic Champions League semi-final second leg against Real Madrid to extra time.\n\nThe former Chelsea manager was outraged that the Polish referee Szymon Marciniak had, on the advice of his assistant, blown for a suspect offside early in a phase of play which saw Matthijs De Ligt score an equaliser to take the game to 2-2.\n\nBayern had led 1-0 on the night and 3-2 on aggregate after Alphonso Davies' 68th minute goal but two late goals from substitute Joselu sent Real through to the final.\n\nJude Bellingham will face his former club Borussia Dortmund at Wembley on June 1 with Real playing for a 15th Champions League title going back to 1956.\n\nYet Tuchel said that Marciniak, who took charge of the 2022 World Cup final, got it wrong. He said of the decision by the assistant to raise the flag early: \"I think it is pretty clear - and it can't be any other opinion - that it's against every rule in modern football, what happened.\n\n\"The first big mistake is from the linesman. He raised the flag in a situation like this where you can never, never be sure it's offside. To have the guts to raise the flag is a huge, huge call and it's the wrong call. The referee has the chance not to whistle when we win the second ball and get a shot away within five seconds. He takes the decision to whistle and it's against every rule.\n\nAsked later about De Ligt's post-match suggestion that there had been an apology from the officials, Tuchel became increasingly angry in his post-match press conference. He said: \"We accept the apology. But it's a semi-final. It's not the moment to apologise. It's not the time to make two mistakes that are so important. Everyone is suffering and living on the edge. The referees need to be at the level and it is worthless to apologise. We want the best referees and if he is not able to offer 100 per cent then apologies are worthless.\"\n\nSpeaking to TNT Sports, Tuchel said: \"We are almost through, it's almost there and there was a very unusual mistake from our best player [Manuel Neuer] for the equaliser then we conceded the second one in stoppage time.\n\n\"Then we scored one and there was a disastrous decision from the linesman and the referee. It feels like a betrayal in the end. There was a huge fight. We left everything on the pitch and we were almost there. Now we say congratulations to Real Madrid.\n\n\"The linesman says sorry but that does not help. To raise the flag in a moment like this... The referee sees we get the second ball and we get the shot - it's a very, very bad decision. It's against the rules. It's a disaster. It's hard to swallow but that's the way it is.\"\n\nDe Ligt suggested that the assistant had admitted a mistake was made. The Bayern defender said: \"If it is offside, it is offside, but I think we have rules in football and the rules say if it is not clear then you have to keep playing. And if you go in the last minute and whistle like this - I think it was a big mistake\".\n\nTuchel said that he had no choice but to substitute Harry Kane and Jamal Musiala who were both struggling with injuries and fitness concerns. {"uri": "8118627709", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "07:00:36", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T07:00:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T06:58:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/champions-league/thomas-tuchel-reveals-apology-from-officials-after-disasterous-decision-costs-bayern-munich-in-champions-league/a1597243716.html", "title": "Thomas Tuchel reveals apology from officials after 'disasterous decision' costs Bayern Munich in Champions League", "body": "Bayern Munich boss Thomas Tuchel has revealed the assistant referee apologised to him after a huge mistake at the end of an epic Champions League semi-final against Real Madrid.\n\nTuchel vented his frustration at the \"disastrous decision\" to rule out a potential Matthijs de Ligt equaliser after Bayern Munich missed out on the Champions League final following a 4-3 aggregate loss to Real Madrid.\n\nThe last-four tie had been evenly-poised after a 2-2 draw in Germany last week and Alphonso Davies fired the visitors into a surprise lead with 22 minutes left at the Santiago Bernabeu.\n\nBayern looked on course to end Madrid's 13-month unbeaten home run, but Joselu levelled in the 88th minute after Manuel Neuer spilled a shot by Vinicius Junior before the former Stoke forward steered home from close range three minutes later to earn a memorable 2-1 victory.\n\nThe goal was originally ruled out after the offside flag was raised, but VAR told Szymon Marciniak to review the incident and both Joselu and defender-turned-assist-maker Antonio Rudiger were onside.\n\nFurther drama occurred in the 13th minute of stoppage time when referee Marciniak blew his whistle, upon the offside flag being raised, just before De Ligt fired into the bottom corner after a Joshua Kimmich pass forced a scramble in the Madrid box.\n\nBayern remonstrated with the officials, but to no avail as the German giants and England captain Harry Kane were consigned to a trophyless season.\n\nThat last gasp decision was the subject of intense debate at the final whistle, with Tuchel admitting the officials admitted their mistake.\n\n\"The linesman says sorry but that does not help,\" said Tuchel. \"To raise the flag in a moment like this...\n\n\"The referee sees we get the second ball and we get the shot - it's a very, very bad decision. It's against the rules. It's a disaster. It's hard to swallow but that's the way it is.\"\n\nTuchel, who will will leave Bayern at the end of the season and is being strongly linked with a move to Manchester United admitted the agony of coming so close to the Wembley final will be hard to forget.\n\n\"It hurts. It'll take a while to recover, but on the one hand it's a loss where we left it all out on the pitch,\" he added.\n\n\"We are almost through, it's almost there and there was a very unusual mistake from our best player for the equaliser then we conceded the second one in stoppage time.\n\n\"Then we scored one and there was a disastrous decision from the linesman and the referee. It feels like a betrayal in the end. There was a huge fight, we left everything on the pitch and we were almost there. Now we say congratulations to Real Madrid.\"\n\nTuchel's opposite number Carlos Ancelotti for a fifth time when his side take on Borussia Dortmund in the final and he saluted the courage of his players to fight back from the bring of defeat.\n\n\"Unbelievable. {"uri": "2024-05-350309410", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "13:49:07", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T13:49:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T13:43:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://indianexpress.com/article/sports/football/explained-bayern-munich-champions-league-semifinal-loss-real-madrid-offside-var-controversy-9318546/", "title": "Explained: Why Bayern Munich said their Champions League semifinal loss to Real Madrid ended in a 'betrayal'", "body": "\"There was a disastrous decision from the linesman and the referee,\" Tuchel told TNT Sports. \"It feels like a betrayal in the end. There was a huge fight, we left everything on the pitch and we were almost there. Now we say congratulations to Real Madrid.\"\n\nThe Bayern manager was referring to a late strike from Matthijs de Ligt in the 103rd minute - a possible equaliser for the Germans - which was quickly denied by the linesman as offside.\n\nHowever, as the broadcasters showed a replay of De Ligt's run towards the goal, it looked like the Dutch defender wasn't ahead of Madrid's last line of defence. But since the referee had stopped the game with his whistle following the linesman's decision, VAR was unable to intervene and the goal was not allowed to stand.\n\nFormer Manchester United midfielder Paul Scholes would suggest that the sideline official had raised his flag too early. \"I'm not sure it's offside. For the linesman to put his flag up... he's too hasty. He's got to wait,\" Scholes would suggest on TNT Sports.\n\nWhat did the linesman say?\n\nAfter the game, De Ligt conceded that Poland's Szymon Marciniak, the linesman who deemed his run for the stoppage time goal as offside, had apologized to him after the game.\n\n\"The linesman said to me I'm sorry, I made a mistake, I can't buy anything for that. I'm not the type of person who wants to blame a loss or win on the referee but it means you have to win because you win 2-1. I think if it's a rule, it's a rule,\" De Ligt told beIN Sports.\n\nThe Bayern centre-back added, \"I don't want to say that Real Madrid always has the referees with them but that made the difference today.\"\n\nBayern manager Tuchel also lashed out on the decision. \"The linesman said sorry but that does not help,\" the German said. \"He raised his flag straight away; to raise your flag in a situation like this, you have to be very, very sure it's offside. To have the guts, the balls, to raise the flag like this is a huge, huge call, and it is the wrong call. We got the shot away within five seconds [of the flag] and the referee has the chance not to whistle, but he whistles. It is against every rule.\"\n\nWhat is the rule?\n\nAs UEFA explained last year following a course for European assistant referees in Rome: \"When the VAR system is in place for a match, assistant referees are being advised not to raise the flag if in doubt about a potential offside situation.\"\n\nMadrid's rebuttal\n\nReal Madrid manager Carlo Ancelotti wasn't reticent in giving it back to his {"uri": "8118583344", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "06:25:02", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T06:25:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T06:24:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/paul-scholes-bayern-munich-championsleague-32767442", "title": "\"They are the rules\" - Paul Scholes agrees with furious Bayern Munich protests", "body": "Matthijs de Ligt was left fuming that his goal was ruled out for offside\n\nPaul Scholes suggested that Bayern Munich were within their rights to be angered by a late offside flag in their defeat to Real Madrid.\n\nThe Germans conceded twice late on as the Spanish giants turned the tie on its head, but deep into stoppage time Bayern found a goal that would've forced extra-time. Matthijs de Ligt produced a smart finish, but the linesman's flag had already gone up with the referee whistling.\n\nAs a result the Real keeper didn't attempt to save the effort, but replays showed the decision was a marginal one. Usual protocol now, with VAR in place, is for linesmen to keep their flags down unless the offside is clear, so as to allow VAR to intervene if necessary.\n\nBut the decision to quickly flag for offside meant the officials couldn't go back and check with replays suggesting Bayern's players were onside and the goal should've been given, leading to mass protests on the touchline.\n\nScholes said on TNT Sports: \"I think the linesman puts his flag up too early to be honest. His flag goes up straight away. It is close, we know the defender heads it, even the one in behind De Ligt, I'm not sure he's offside. The linesman is too hasty, he's got to wait, they're the rules! I do think the keeper stop, it is a great finish, would he have saved it anyway?\"\n\nAlphonso Davies had opened the scoring on the night, putting Bayern 1-0 up in Madrid and 3-2 ahead of aggregate. Joselu then scored twice, first in the 89th minute and then again moments later to send the Bernabeu into raptures and set up a Champions League final with Borussia Dortmund.\n\nIt means Thomas Tuchel will depart the German club this summer without winning a trophy this season, but he and his players were left seething at the call.\n\nBayern Munich squandered their lead late on to go out of the Champions League\n\nAfter the game he said \"it was a very, very bad decision\" and \"against the rules\". The ex-Chelsea coach went on to say: \"There was a disastrous decision from the linesman and the referee. It feels like a betrayal in the end. The linesman says sorry but that does not help. To raise the flag in a moment like this... The referee sees we get the second ball and we get the shot. It's hard to swallow but that's the way it is.\"\n\nTuchel also confirmed referee Szymon Marciniak had apologised but that it \"does not help\" with his team out of Europe. \"Everyone has to go to their limit, everyone has to suffer, everyone has to play without making mistakes. So the referee has to be at that level too,\" he added.\n\n\"It just doesn't help to make excuses after the fact. You are on the field for this reason, because you are the best there is. {"uri": "8118831296", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "09:16:05", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T09:16:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T09:15:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.breakingnews.ie/sport/no-comment-from-uefa-as-thomas-tuchel-rails-at-disastrous-decision-1623332.html", "title": "No comment from Uefa as Thomas Tuchel rails at 'disastrous decision' | BreakingNews.ie", "body": "Uefa has offered no comment on what Bayern Munich coach Thomas Tuchel described as a \"disastrous decision\" by the on-field officials in the dying moments of their Champions League semi-final against Real Madrid.\n\nPolish referee Szymon Marciniak blew his whistle after one of his assistants raised an offside flag, moments before Matthijs de Ligt struck what would have been an equaliser for the German side.\n\nVAR could not make a call on whether the goal should stand or not because play had been stopped, and there is also the question of whether De Ligt would even have scored if Real's defence had not stopped for the whistle.\n\nHowever, Tuchel took no comfort from that as his side blew the lead given to them midway through the second half by Alphonso Davies.\n\n\"They have a disastrous decision from the linesman and from the referee,\" he told TNT Sports.\n\n\"So, it feels almost like a betrayal in the end because of that decision. It was a huge fight, we left everything on the pitch and we were almost there. Now we have to say congratulations to Real Madrid.\n\n\"The linesman said sorry, but that does not help. At that kind of level, to raise the flag in a decision like this, a close decision, in the last minute - and the referee as well.\n\n\"The referee does not have to whistle. He sees that we win the second ball, he sees that we get a shot away and to whistle is a very, very bad decision.\n\n\"And it is against the rules and it is a bad decision from both of them. It is a disaster. Tough to swallow, but that is the way it is.\"\n\nWhile there has been no clarification or comment from Uefa, the officials could point to the VAR protocols published by the International Football Association Board, which state that an assistant referee's offside flag should only be delayed \"in a very clear attacking situation when a player is about to score a goal or has a clear run into/towards the opponents' penalty area\".\n\nTwo goals from Joselu helped Real recover from a goal down to win 4-3 on aggregate. {"uri": "8118176185", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "23:04:30", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T23:04:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T23:03:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/articles/cd18lm777qvo", "title": "Thomas Tuchel: Bayern Munich manager says offside decision \"feels like a betrayal\"", "body": "Bayern Munich manager Thomas Tuchel says the decision from officials to stop play before his side scored an injury-time equaliser against Real Madrid \"feels like a betrayal\".\n\nThe Germans led 1-0 in the second leg of their Champions League semi-final up until the 88th minute when substitute Joselu scored twice in three minutes.\n\nWith Bayern trailing 2-1 in the 13th minute of stoppage time, Matthijs de Ligt thought he had equalised but the assistant referee's flag was already raised for offside.\n\nReal defenders stopped before De Ligt fired into the net and television replays showed the original decision may not have been offside and would have needed to be checked by video assistant referee [VAR].\n\nBut having already stopped play, VAR was unable to intervene. Tuchel told TNT Sports afterwards \"it was a very, very bad decision\" and \"against the rules\".\n\n\"There was a disastrous decision from the linesman and the referee. It feels like a betrayal in the end,\" he added.\n\n\"The linesman says sorry but that does not help. To raise the flag in a moment like this... The referee sees we get the second ball and we get the shot.\n\n\"It's hard to swallow but that's the way it is.\"\n\nTuchel later confirmed referee Szymon Marciniak also apologised but that it \"does not help\" with Real in the final.\n\n\"Everyone has to go to their limit, everyone has to suffer, everyone has to play without making mistakes. {"uri": "2024-05-350098889", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "10:40:01", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T10:40:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T10:38:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.cnn.com/2024/05/09/sport/real-madrid-bayern-munich-champions-league-semifinal-spt-intl/index.html", "title": "Real Madrid stuns Bayern Munich late to reach Champions League final but match marred by controversial decision", "body": "Real Madrid players celebrate after a breathless Champions League semifinal second leg.\n\nCNN --\n\nReal Madrid manager Carlo Ancelotti credited the \"magical\" Santiago Bernab\u00e9u stadium for motivating his team to the Champions League final on Wednesday, after the Spanish side scored two late goals to beat Bayern Munich 2-1 in the semifinal second leg.\n\nWith the scores level at 2-2 after the first leg, both teams knew the winner in Madrid would progress through to London's showpiece event against Borussia Dortmund on June 1.\n\nIt had looked as though Bayern had done enough after Alphonso Davies scored a stunning goal in the 68th minute but, as they have done on countless occasions in this competition, Los Blancos found a way to hit back in the final moments of the match.\n\nWith all hope seemingly lost, Madrid's substitute striker Joselu turned the tie on its head after scoring two goals in the space of three minutes.\n\n\"It's happened again. Something that has happened time after time, which is inexplicable, has happened again,\" Ancelotti said, referring to the number of late comebacks Madrid has produced in the Champions League in recent seasons.\n\n\"A set of fans who drive us, a stadium that supports us, a stunning atmosphere and a group of players who believe. It's magical.\"\n\nMadrid's first goal came courtesy of a costly error from Bayern goalkeeper Manuel Neuer. The German had been impressive all game but spilled a simple shot to present Joselu with a chance to score the equalizer in the 88th minute.\n\nThe goal sparked something special inside the newly refurbished Bernab\u00e9u, and it was an atmosphere that pushed Madrid to find the winner in the 91st minute.\n\nFans inside the Santiago Bernab\u00e9u erupted as Real Madrid won the dramatic match. David Ramos/Getty Images\n\nIt was Joselu again who put the ball in the back of the net, but the goal was initially ruled out for offside.\n\nThe stadium held its breath as the video assistant referee (VAR) checked the decision and then erupted when it was decided that neither Antonio R\u00fcdiger, who provided the assist, nor Joselu was offside.\n\nStaff and players flooded off the Madrid bench to celebrate in front of the frenzied crowd, as Bayern players looked crestfallen having seen their hopes of reaching the final slip away in a matter of minutes.\n\nBut, incredibly, the drama wasn't finished yet.\n\nControversial offside flag decision\n\nIn search of an equalizer, Bayern Munich's Matthijs de Ligt did get the ball in the back of Madrid's net in the 13th minute of added time.\n\nHowever, the referee had stopped play just seconds before the defender's shot whistled into the bottom corner, after spotting the linesman had raised his flag.\n\nThis time, VAR could not be used to check the incredibly tight decision because the referee had blown his whistle.\n\nUsually, in such situations, the officials are supposed to let the attacking phase continue before deciding on any offside.\n\nDe Ligt told beIN Sports after the match that the linesman told him, \"I'm sorry, I made a mistake,\" but said that was of little comfort to the side.\n\n\"If it's offside, it's offside, but I think we made rules in football and the rules say if it's not a clear offside, which it wasn't ... you have to keep playing,\" he said postmatch. \"And if you go in the last minute and whistle like this, yeah, I think this is a big, big, big mistake. If it's offside or not, I don't know, you can check it. But if you don't check it, how can you see it?\"\n\nBayern manager Thomas Tuchel also said the linesman apologized for raising his flag too early, but the German said such an apology \"does not help\" and criticized the referee for blowing the whistle too early.\n\n\"It almost feels like a betrayal because of that decision,\" Tuchel told TNT Sports after the match.\n\n\"It's a very, very bad decision. It's against the rules [...] it's tough to swallow, but it's the way it is.\"\n\nWhile Tuchel and de Ligt were unhappy with the officials, they both accepted the defeat and congratulated Madrid for making yet another final.\n\nBayern manager Thomas Tuchel was furious at the officials after the game. S. Mellar/FC Bayern/Getty Images\n\nThe manager, though, came in for criticism himself for his decision to take Harry Kane off in the 85th minute.\n\nIn addition to his attacking threats, the English striker has somewhat perfected the art of running down the clock and his physical presence was needed in the final minutes of the game.\n\nTuchel, though, told critics that Kane was unable to give anymore in the match.\n\nFrom fan to hero\n\nAfter the full-time whistle, Madrid celebrated in style as it crowned Joselu the club's new hero.\n\nThe striker had initially struggled after his loan move from second division Espanyol to the Spanish giant but has now written his name in the club's storied history.\n\nFollowing his match-winning exploits, pictures of the striker in Paris supporting Madrid at the 2022 Champions League final spread on social media - two years later and the 34-year-old inspired his team to the pinnacle of European soccer.\n\n\"My dreams aren't as beautiful as what happened today. As a forward, you dream of scoring goals, and if they're like tonight's, then even better,\" Joselu said after the match.", "source": {"uri": "cnn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CNN"}, "authors": missed out on the Champions League final following a 4-3 aggregate loss to Real Madrid.\n\nThe last-four tie had been evenly-poised after a 2-2 draw in Germany last week and Alphonso Davies fired the visitors into a surprise lead with 22 minutes left at the Santiago Bernabeu.\n\nBayern looked on course to end Madrid's 13-month unbeaten home run, but Joselu levelled in the 88th minute after Manuel Neuer spilled a shot by Vinicius Junior before the former Stoke forward steered home from close range three minutes later to earn a memorable 2-1 victory.\n\nThe goal was originally ruled out after the offside flag was raised, but VAR told Szymon Marciniak to review the incident and both Joselu and defender-turned-assist-maker Antonio Rudiger were onside.\n\nFurther drama occurred in the 13th minute of stoppage time when referee Marciniak blew his whistle, upon the offside flag being raised, just before De Ligt fired into the bottom corner after a Joshua Kimmich pass forced a scramble in the Madrid box.\n\nBayern remonstrated with the officials, but to no avail as the German giants and England captain Harry Kane were consigned to a trophyless season.\n\n\"We were almost through, almost there and had a very unusual mistake by our very best player for the equaliser,\" Tuchel told TNT Sports.\n\nIt feels almost like a betrayal in the end because of that decision Bayern Munich boss Thomas Tuchel\n\n\"Then we conceded in a very narrow decision, the second one in stoppage time. Then we scored one and they have a disastrous decision from the linesman and from the referee.\n\n\"So, it feels almost like a betrayal in the end because of that decision. It was a huge fight, we left everything on the pitch and we were almost there. Now we have to say congratulations to Real Madrid.\n\n\"The linesman said sorry, but that does not help. At that kind of level, to raise the flag in a decision like this, a close decision, in the last minute and the referee as well.\n\n\"The referee does not have to whistle. He sees that we win the second ball, he sees that we get a shot away and to whistle is a very, very bad decision.\n\n\"And it is against the rules and it is a bad decision from both of them. for silverware, and Tuchel made the surprise decision to replace the former Tottenham forward in the 85th minute with Bayern leading.\n\nWhile Tuchel was not asked specifically about Kane being taken {"uri": "8118697306", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "07:44:59", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T07:44:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T07:44:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://sportstar.thehindu.com/football/champions-league/why-was-bayern-goal-disallowed-real-madrid-ucl-semifinal-2023-24-tuchel-comments/article68156603.ece", "title": "Explained: Why was Bayern Munich's late goal ruled out against Real Madrid in UCL 2023-24 semifinal?", "body": "Bayern Munich was eliminated from the Champions League after a late Joselu brace propelled Real Madrid to a thrilling 2-1 comeback win at the Santiago Bernabeu on Thursday.\n\nWith the first leg finishing in a 2-2 draw, Madrid qualified for the final with a 4-3 aggregate score.\n\nDespite the thrilling win, the match was marred with controversy towards the end after Matthijs De Ligt seemed to have scored the equaliser in stoppage-time but the goal was ruled out after the linesman had raised his flag for offside.\n\nWhat happened and why was the goal disallowed?\n\nIn the 13th minute of second-half stoppage time, in one of the last attacks of the game, De Ligt managed to shoot the ball into the net, but not before referee Szymon Marciniak had blown the whistle for offside against fellow defender Noussair Mazraoui.\n\nMazraoui and De Ligt both were intended targets of a long pass from inside their own half, although the Moroccan was the one who ultimately received the ball. Thomas M\u00fcller kept the ball alive in Madrid's box, and De Ligt shot low past Andriy Lunin.\n\nWhen the ball was played forward, De Ligt was offside but did not seem to touch it in the first phase of play. Mazraoui, who did, was immediately flagged offside and a free-kick was given seconds before De Ligt's finish.\n\nIt was not easy to judge from video replays whether Mazraoui was offside or not, but as soon as the linesman raised the flag for offside, the referee stopped the game, preventing VAR from checking the decision, as would normally have been the case.\n\n\"A disaster. An absolute disaster. With Real's second goal, they let the play continue. The clear rule is that the scene must continue. The first mistake was made by the linesman, the second by the referee,\" Bayern coach Thomas Tuchel said after the match.\n\nALSO READ: Far from a Galactico, Joselu produces a galactic night for Real Madrid in the Champions League\n\n\"Very difficult. Of course, as sportspeople we accept it,\" said Tuchel. \"But it is a semifinal, it's not for two such violations of the rule. Everyone has to be at their limit. The referees have to be there as well.\"\n\n\"That is what we expect. So the apology does not really help.\"\n\nDe Ligt said in a post-match interview that the linesman had apologised to him for the hasty decision and not allowing the game to continue.\n\nLatest on SportstarNBA: Jalen Brunson shakes off injury, sends Knicks past Pacers ReutersExplained: Why was Bayern Munich's late goal ruled out against Real Madrid in UCL 2023-24 semifinal? {"uri": "8118121268", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "22:04:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T22:04:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T22:03:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.sportbible.com/football/football-news/champions-league/thomas-tuchel-bayern-munich-offside-real-madrid-linesman-757698-20240508", "title": "Thomas Tuchel confirms what linesman told furious Bayern Munich players immediately after offside decision", "body": "Bayern Munich were the subject of a controversial offside decision against Real Madrid.\n\nThe assistant referee spoke to Bayern Munich players immediately after disallowing their late goal for offside against Real Madrid, according to manager Thomas Tuchel.\n\nBayern were knocked out of the Champions League at the semi-final stage after a 2-1 defeat to Real at the Bernabeu.\n\nThey had gone 1-0 up through Alphonso Davies' superb right-footed strike, with goalkeeper Manuel Neuer in fine form at the other end to keep the score intact.\n\nBut a mistake from Neuer allowed Joselu to steal in and poke the ball into the back of the net to equalise on 88 minutes.\n\nTwo minutes later, Real took the lead on the night and in the tie, with Joselu tapping home Antonio Rudiger's cross to spark chaos inside the Bernabeu after a decision to rule the goal out for offside was overturned by VAR.\n\nBayern then had the ball in the back of the net when Konrad Laimer fired Thomas Muller's knockdown into the bottom corner, but referee Szymon Marciniak had already blown his whistle to signal offside.\n\nAnd because the whistle had been blown in-play, thus stopping the move from developing, VAR was unable to intervene and change the decision.\n\nReplays showed, however, that the decision was exceptionally close - with Bayern players left furious over the decision.\n\nSpeaking after the match to TNT Sports, Tuchel confirmed that the assistant referee apologised to Bayern stars immediately after the incident.\n\nHe explained: \"It was a disastrous decision from the linesman, and from the referee.\n\n\"It feels almost like a betrayal in the end, because of that decision. But we have to say congratulations to Real Madrid.\n\n\"The linesman said sorry, but that doesn't help at that kind of level. To raise the flag in a close decision in the last minute, and the referee as well, he does not have to whistle.\n\n\"It's a very, very bad decision and it's against the rules. Tough to swallow, but that's the way it is.\"\n\nDefender Matthijs de Ligt, meanwhile, told beIN Sports that the decision was a 'big, big mistake', and backed up Tuchel's comments that the linesman {"uri": "8118819068", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "09:08:16", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T09:08:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T09:07:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.90min.com/thomas-tuchel-furious-officials-against-the-rules-offside", "title": "Thomas Tuchel furious with officials for 'against the rules' offside call", "body": "Bayern were left furious / Alexander Hassenstein/GettyImages\n\nAn incredulous Thomas Tuchel lashed out at the decision to rule out Matthijs de Ligt's late strike in Wednesday's defeat to Real Madrid, describing the offside call as \"disastrous\".\n\nBayern Munich had conceded two late goals to Madrid substitute Joselu and were on the cusp of elimination when, in the 13th minute of stoppage time, an early offside flag and referee whistle saw Madrid's defence slow down and allow De Ligt to fire into the back of the net.\n\nReplays of the offside call were incredibly tight - some claim to have evidence that the wrong decision was made - and Tuchel was left livid by the choice to immediately stop the game, rather than follow the normal procedure and allow the game to play out before using a VAR review.\n\n\"That was an absolute disaster,\" he told TNT Sports. \"A violation of the rules. This scene must be played out to the end. That's the rule.\n\n\"The linesman made the mistake, and the referee made the second mistake. We were almost there and a very unusual mistake of the best player for the equaliser, then we conceded in a very narrow decision in stoppage time. Then we scored one and it was a disastrous decision from the linesman and the referee, so it feels almost like a betrayal in the end because of that decision.\n\n\"The linesman said sorry. That does not help at that kind of level, to raise the flag in a decision like this, in a close decision in the last minute. The referee as well, he does not have to whistle, he sees that we win the second ball, he sees that we get the shot away. To whistle is a very, very bad decision. It is against the rules and it is a bad decision from both of them. It is a disaster, tough to swallow, but it is the way it is.\"\n\nDe Ligt went on to reveal his own conversation with the linesman as he pointed out how Madrid were allowed to benefit from a narrow offside decision at the other end of the pitch just minutes earlier.\n\n\"If it's offside, it's offside. But I think we made rules in football and the rules are if it's not a clear offside - which it wasn't because I don't see it yet, if it's offside or not - you have to keep playing,\" he told beIN SPORTS.\n\n\"If you go in the last minutes and you whistle like this, I think it's a big mistake. If it's offside or not you can check it, but if you don't check it, how can you see it? The second goal, [Antonio] Rudiger is almost offside. If he whistles, okay, but now there's a difference and this is a shame.\n\n\"The linesman said to me, 'I'm sorry, I made a mistake' - I can't buy anything for that. I'm not the type of person who wants to blame a loss or win on the referee but it means you have to win because you win 2-1. {"uri": "8118621590", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "06:54:21", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T06:54:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T06:53:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.mangalorean.com/this-is-shame-not-the-moment-for-apologies-de-ligt-tuchel-react-to-offside-decision-controversy-in-champions-league-sf/", "title": "'This is shame; not the moment for apologies': De Ligt, Tuchel react to 'offside decision' controversy in Champions League SF - Mangalorean.com", "body": "'This is shame; not the moment for apologies': De Ligt, Tuchel react to 'offside decision' controversy in Champions League SF\n\nMadrid: A battle between Real Madrid and Bayern Munich is the biggest rivalry in European football. The two teams have met time and time again in the biggest club competition in the world.\n\nOn Wednesday, the two teams met in an epic battle at the Santiago Bernabeu with Real Madrid progressing to their 18th Champions League final.\n\nUnfortunately, in what was a chaotic final 20 minutes of the game which saw two goals being scored, two goals being disallowed and many fights breaking out, the brilliance of the two teams was overshadowed by controversy with Bayern defender, Matthijs De Ligt even claiming that the assistant referee apologised for the late call which saw the referee blow the whistle on an offside decision seconds before the Dutch center back scored what would have been the equalizer.\n\nFollowing the emotional encounter, many players and both coaches had a lot to say about what just transpired on the pitch.\n\n\"The linesman said to me, 'I'm sorry, I made a mistake', The rule says that if it's not clear offside, you have to keep playing and if you go in the last minute and you whistle like this, I think this is a big mistake. If it's offside or not, I don't know, VAR can check it, but if you don't check it, how can you see it? This is a shame,\" said a dejected Matthijs De Ligt.\n\n\"Very difficult. This is a semifinal, it's not the moment for apologies. Really not. It's not the moment for two huge violations of rules and then an apology. We all have to go to our limits, all have to suffer, all have to play without mistakes. The referees at this level also have to do that. When you don't deliver, it doesn't help when you apologize, even though of course as sportsmen we accept it,\" said FC Bayern manager, Thomas Tuchel.\n\nThe moment was brilliant, to score my first Champions League goal against a team like Madrid but when it's all said and done, we didn't make it to the final,\" said Alphonso Davies who has been heavily linked with a move to Real Madrid this summer.\n\n\"The offside episode is simple to explain. Maybe it wasn't offside, but the referee whistled (before the goal) and we stopped playing. That's it. Bayern complaining about the offside? OK, then we complain about the canceled goal of Nacho. Kimmich dived,\" said Ancelotti.\n\n\"We put Real Madrid in another final, today we played for our injured teammates, for our family, for the Bernab\u00e9u and we played for this shirt that always {"uri": "8118190550", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "23:22:11", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T23:22:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T23:21:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/thomas-tuchel-bayern-real-madrid-32767172", "title": "Tuchel 'betrayed' by Real Madrid 'disaster' as he says linesman has apologised", "body": "Thomas Tuchel was furious after Bayern Munich's loss against Real Madrid\n\nThomas Tuchel lashed out at the match officials after Bayern Munich were denied a seemingly legitimate goal in their Champions League semi-final loss against Real Madrid.\n\nDespite taking the lead through David Alaba in the second-half, Bayern were left fighting for their lives following a dramatic late double from Joselu. It looked as though Konrad Laimer had taken the tie to extra-time by scoring with practically the last kick of the game, but the goal was ruled out for offside by the linesman.\n\nReplays showed that the decision was tight and the incident wasn't checked by VAR given that the offside flag had been raised early.\n\nAn irate Tuchel branded the incident a \"betrayal\" in his post-match interview with TNT Sports, with the outgoing Bayern Munich chief also revealing that the officials had already apologised.\n\nHe raged: \"We are almost through, it's almost there and there was a very unusual mistake from our best player for the equaliser then we conceded the second one in stoppage time.\n\n\"Then we scored one and there was a disastrous decision from the linesman and the referee. It feels like a betrayal in the end. There was a huge fight, we left everything on the pitch and we were almost there. Now we say congratulations to Real Madrid.\n\n\"The linesman says sorry but that does not help. To raise the flag in a moment like this... The referee sees we get the second ball and we get the shot - it's a very, very bad decision. It's against the rules. It's a disaster. It's hard to swallow but that's the way it is.\"\n\nJoin the debate! What did you make of the offside decision? Let us know here.\n\nBayern Munich players, like Harry Kane, were in disbelief after the match\n\nMatthijs De Ligt also vented his frustrations post-match. Like Tuchel, he revealed that the officials had apologised during his interview with beIN Sports.\n\nThe defender said: \"If it's offside, it's offside, but we made rules in football and the rule says that if it's not a clear offside, which it wasn't, you have to keep playing. If you go in the last minute and you whistle like this, I think this is a big mistake and a big disgrace. If it's offside or not, I don't know, you can check it but if you don't check it how can you see it.\n\n\"[On] the second goal of Joselu, [Antonio] Rudiger is almost also offside. If he whistles there, nothing, but now it's a difference.\"\n\nDON'T SCRAP REPLAYS! {"uri": "2024-05-349584233", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "23:21:16", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T23:21:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T23:20:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/national/24307684.thomas-tuchel-fumes-disastrous-decision-rule-late-bayern-chance/", "title": "Thomas Tuchel fumes at 'disastrous decision' to rule out late Bayern chance", "body": "Thomas Tuchel vented his frustration at the \"disastrous decision\" to rule out a potential Matthijs de Ligt equaliser after Bayern Munich missed out on the Champions League final following a 4-3 aggregate loss to Real Madrid.\n\nThe last-four tie had been evenly-poised after a 2-2 draw in Germany last week and Alphonso Davies fired the visitors into a surprise lead with 22 minutes left at the Santiago Bernabeu.\n\nBayern looked on course to end Madrid's 13-month unbeaten home run, but Joselu levelled in the 88th minute after Manuel Neuer spilled a shot by Vinicius Junior before the former Stoke forward steered home from close range three minutes later to earn a memorable 2-1 victory.\n\nThe goal was originally ruled out after the offside flag was raised, but VAR told Szymon Marciniak to review the incident and both Joselu and defender-turned-assist-maker Antonio Rudiger were onside.\n\nFurther drama occurred in the 13th minute of stoppage time when referee Marciniak blew his whistle, upon the offside flag being raised, just before De Ligt fired into the bottom corner after a Joshua Kimmich pass forced a scramble in the Madrid box.\n\nBayern remonstrated with the officials, but to no avail as the German giants and England captain Harry Kane were consigned to a trophyless season.\n\n\"We were almost through, almost there and had a very unusual mistake by our very best player for the equaliser,\" Tuchel told TNT Sports.\n\n\"Then we conceded in a very narrow decision, the second one in stoppage time. Then we scored one and they have a disastrous decision from the linesman and from the referee.\n\n\"So, it feels almost like a betrayal in the end because of that decision. It was a huge fight, we left everything on the pitch and we were almost there. Now we have to say congratulations to Real Madrid.\n\n\"The linesman said sorry, but that does not help. At that kind of level, to raise the flag in a decision like this, a close decision, in the last minute and the referee as well.\n\n\"The referee does not have to whistle. He sees that we win the second ball, he sees that we get a shot away and to whistle is a very, very bad decision.\n\n\"And it is against the rules and it is a bad decision from both of them. It is a disaster. Tough to swallow, but that is the way it is.\"\n\nAn intriguing subplot was Kane up against compatriot Jude Bellingham, who produced an all-action display and helped set up a Wembley showdown with old club Borussia Dortmund on June 1.\n\nIt was a different story for Kane after this loss extended his wait for silverware, and Tuchel made the surprise decision to replace the former Tottenham forward in the 85th minute with Bayern leading.\n\nWhile Tuchel was not asked specifically about Kane being taken off, he said: \"Part of the story is we start with a front four and all four players need to Bayern With 'Disgrace' Referee Decision", "body": "Bayern Munich defender Matthijs de Ligt called an important call in his team's Champions League semifinal second leg defeat to Real Madrid a 'disgrace' when interviewed by Spanish broadcaster Movistar post-match.\n\nLos Blancos booked their tickets to Wembley, where they will face Bayern's biggest domestic rival Borussia Dortmund in the final on June 1, by beating the Bavarian's 2-1 in the Bernabeu for a 4-3 aggregate win.\n\nAfter a goalless first half, substitute Alphonso Davies smashed a 68th minute rocket into Andriy Lunin's top corner out of nowhere.\n\nWith just two minutes to spare, however, a previously faultless Manuel Neuer misjudged a shot from MVP Vinicius Jr. which he thought was bound for his hands.\n\nInstead, the ball bounced off the German's chest into Joselu, who poked it in to equalize.\n\nThen in stoppage time, Joselu wasn't deemed to have been offside when converting an Antonio Rudiger pass from close quarters.\n\nIn one of the last plays of the game, though, a controversial incident occurred when the linesman raised his flag for offside and the referee blew his whistle before it had finished which meant that VAR also couldn't be consulted.\n\nStill replays appear to show that there weren't any Bayern players offside, and therefore De Ligt's goal should have perhaps stood.\n\nThe Dutchman and a furious Thomas Muller protested with the official but could do nothing to stop their side from being eliminated.\n\nIn a short post-match interview with Movistar, De Ligt said that he was feeling \"not very good emotions\" after Bayern were \"very close\" to victory.\n\n\"You go from winning to losing in ten minutes, it's a very bad night. We were very close, they pushed, they pressed... and when you think they're dead, Madrid always have a last breath, that's why they've won the Champions League 14 times.\"\n\nCommenting more specifically about the controversial incident which will dominate surrounding the tie, De Ligt said: \"I think we all know the rules. If it's not clear what offside is clear you have to let the play [go].\n\n\"It was a disgrace. With Joselu's goal he was offside and [the referee] let him continue playing, why not with us? It's easy to talk about the referee but they deserved it,\" De Ligt signed off.\n\nIn a separate interview with beIN SPORTS, De Ligt revealed that the referee told him: \"Sorry, I made a mistake\".\n\n\"If it's offside, it's offside,\" De Ligt accepted. \"But I think we made rules in football and the rules say that if it's not offside, which it wasn't - I haven't seen it yet if it's An absolute disaster. With Real's second goal, they let the play continue. The clear rule is that the scene must continue. The first mistake was made by the linesman, the second by the referee,\" he said.\n\nALSO READ: UCL 2023-24 Semifinal: Joselu helps Real Madrid comeback against Bayern Munich to reach Champions League final\n\nBayern took the lead with Alphonso Davies' shot midway through the second half, but Real battled back with two late goals from Joselu to book their final spot.\n\nDe Ligt said the linesman had apologised to him after the game.\n\n\"Very difficult. Of course, as sportspeople we accept it,\" said Tuchel. \"But it is a semifinal, it's not for two such violations of the rule. Everyone has to be at their limit. The referees have to be there as well.\"\n\n\"That is what we expect. So the apology does not really help.\"\n\nBayern keeper Manuel Neuer spilled the ball into Joselu's path for the equaliser in the 88th minute, but Tuchel did not want to blame his keeper, who had been outstanding up to that point.\n\n\"Ninety-nine out of 100 times he makes it. A violation of the rules. This scene must be played out to the end. That's the rule. The linesman made the mistake, and the referee made the second mistake. We were almost there and a very unusual mistake of the best player for the equaliser, then we conceded in a very narrow decision in stoppage time.\"\n\n\"Then we scored one and it was a disastrous decision from the linesman and the referee, so it feels almost like a betrayal in the end because of that decision. The linesman said sorry. That does not help at that kind of level, to raise the flag in a decision like this, in a close decision in the last minute. The referee as well, he does not have to whistle, he sees that we win the second ball, he sees that we get the shot away. To whistle is a very, very bad decision. It is against the rules and it is a bad decision from both of them. It is a disaster, tough to swallow, but it is the way it is.\"\n\nTuchel added: \"Having the balls to raise the flag in a situation like that is a big mistake. And then the referee, when he saw that we won the rebound, made the decision to whistle. It wouldn't have happened the other way round. We accept the apology (from the linesman) but this is not the time to apologise. It's the semi-finals and it's not the time to make those sorts of mistakes.\"\n\nReal are now through to another Champions League final, where they will face more German opposition in the form of {"uri": "8118686963", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "07:39:50", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T07:39:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T07:39:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/matthijs-de-ligt-details-what-32767792", "title": "De Ligt details what linesman said to him after offside flag denied Bayern goal", "body": "Matthijs de Ligt has spoken out about the controversial decision\n\nMatthijs de Ligt admitted the linesman told him he was sorry for his mistake in disallowing a stoppage time Bayern Munich goal.\n\nThe Dutchman scored late on with his strike set to force extra-time, only for the offside flag to deny him. The Germans surged forward after two quick Real Madrid goals had turned the tie on its head, but De Ligt saw the offside flag go up moments before his smart finish.\n\nThe referee whistled and that ruled out the chance for VAR to intervene with replays showing the two Bayern players in question appeared to be onside. It led to mass protests on the pitch and the touchline with De Light adamant the rules should be abided by.\n\nHe told beIN Sports: \"If it's offside, it's offside. But I think we made rules in football and the rules are if's not a clear offside - which it wasn't because I don't see it yet if it's offside or not - you have to keep playing.\n\n\"If you go in the last minutes and you whistle like this, I think it's a big mistake. If it's offside or not you can check it, but if you don't check it, how can you see it? The second goal Rudiger is almost offside. If he whistles ok, but now there's a difference and this is a shame.\n\n\"The linesman said to me I'm sorry, I made a mistake, I can't buy anything for that. I'm not the type of person who wants to blame a loss or win on the referee but it means you have to win because you win 2-1. I think if it's a rule, it's a rule.\"\n\nIt means the Germans' last hope of landing a trophy is over. Bayern have endured a difficult campaign and Thomas Tuchel is due to depart this summer. He too was left seething by the decision and also received an apology - albeit that didn't make it easier to stomach.\n\nBayern Munich were left fuming as an offside denied them an equaliser\n\nThe ex-Chelsea boss said: \"We scored one, and it's a disastrous decision from the linesman and referee. It feels almost like a betrayal in the end because of that decision. The linesman said sorry - that does not help. To raise the flag in a decision like this, in a close decision in the last minute.\n\n\"And the referee as well, the referee does not have to whistle. He sees that we win the second ball. To whistle, it's a very, very bad decision and it's against the rules. It's a bad decision from both of them, it's a disaster. Tough to swallow.\"\n\nJoin our new WhatsApp community and receive your daily dose of Mirror Football content. after 'disastrous' call", "body": "Thomas Tuchel took Harry Kane off before Real Madrid's comeback on Wednesday.\n\nThomas Tuchel vented his frustration at the \"disastrous decision\" to rule out a potential Matthijs de Ligt equaliser after Bayern Munich missed out on the Champions League final following a 4-3 aggregate loss to Real Madrid, and defended his decision to substitute Harry Kane.\n\nThe last-four tie had been evenly-poised after a 2-2 draw in Germany last week and Alphonso Davies fired the visitors into a surprise lead with 22 minutes left at the Santiago Bernabeu.\n\nBayern looked on course to end Madrid's 13-month unbeaten home run, but Joselu levelled in the 88th minute after Manuel Neuer spilled a shot by Vinicius Junior before the former Stoke forward steered home from close range three minutes later to earn a memorable 2-1 victory.\n\nThe goal was originally ruled out after the offside flag was raised, but VAR told Szymon Marciniak to review the incident and both Joselu and defender-turned-assist-maker Antonio Rudiger were onside.\n\nFurther drama occurred in the 13th minute of stoppage time when referee Marciniak blew his whistle, upon the offside flag being raised, just before De Ligt fired into the bottom corner after a Joshua Kimmich pass forced a scramble in the Madrid box.\n\nREAD MORE: Real Madrid have Tuchel and Stoke City to thank for another Champions League final\n\nBayern remonstrated with the officials, but to no avail as the German giants and England captain Harry Kane were consigned to a trophyless season.\n\n\"We were almost through, almost there and had a very unusual mistake by our very best player for the equaliser,\" Tuchel told TNT Sports.\n\n\"Then we conceded in a very narrow decision, the second one in stoppage time. Then we scored one and they have a disastrous decision from the linesman and from the referee.\n\n\"So, it feels almost like a betrayal in the end because of that decision. It was a huge fight, we left everything on the pitch and we were almost there. Now we have to say congratulations to Real Madrid.\n\n\"The linesman said sorry, but that does not help. At that kind of level, to raise the flag in a decision like this, a close decision, in the last minute and the referee as well.\n\n\"The referee does not have to whistle. He sees that we win the second ball, he sees that we get a shot away and to whistle is a very, very bad decision.\n\n\"And it is against the rules and it is a bad decision from both of them. It is a disaster. Tough to swallow, but that is the way it is.\"\n\nAn intriguing subplot was Kane up against compatriot Jude Bellingham, who produced an all-action display and helped set up a Wembley showdown with old club Borussia Dortmund on June 1.\n\nUNIQUE TO F365: Mediawatch | Mailbox | Winners & Losers | Bespoke Prem tables\n\nIt was a different story for Kane after this loss extended his wait for silverware, and Tuchel made the surprise decision to replace the former Tottenham forward in the 85th minute with Bayern leading.\n\nTuchel defended his decision after the game, claiming: \"He couldn't keep going. He played with back pain and he couldn't keep going, his back froze up.\n\n\"Part of the story is we start with a front four and all four players need to go out because of injuries and cramps.", {"uri": "2024-05-350015095", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "09:25:51", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T09:25:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T09:00:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/bayern-munich-news-fans-furious-denied-equaliser-vs-real-madrid-champions-league", "title": "Bayern Munich fans are furious with denied equaliser vs Real Madrid in the Champions League", "body": "Bayern Munich's Champions League dreams were shattered in the dying moments of their semi-final clash vs Real Madrid\n\nBayern Munich's Champions League dreams were shattered in the dying moments of their semi-final clash against Real Madrid, reported by GOAL. Trailing 2-1 at the Santiago Bernabeu, Bayern thought they had salvaged a lifeline when Matthijs de Ligt found the back of the net with a late equaliser. However, celebration turned to disbelief as the goal was disallowed due to a contentious offside call.\n\nThe controversy stemmed from a ball played into the Bayern box, where Leroy Sane seemed poised to pounce. Real Madrid's Ferland Mendy outjumped Sane to head the ball away, but the linesman swiftly raised his flag, flagging Sane offside. Before the ball even nestled into the net, the referee blew his whistle, halting play and denying Bayern their crucial equaliser.\n\nSocial media erupts with Bayern Munich fans\n\nFootball fans took to social media to express their outrage over the controversial decision. Many argued that the offside call was questionable at best and called for VAR intervention. The consensus among fans was that Bayern had been robbed of a legitimate chance to equalise, with some labelling the decision a catastrophe for football.\n\nThe @thefutballboy_1 wrote on social media: \"In all honesty, this is not offside, and even if it was, it's a close close call, and the rules say \"Players must keep playing until the attack is over, then check VAR\". Bayern got robbed!\"\n\n@HLTCO said: \"It's absolutely bonkers that they've blown up and not allowed VAR to determine whether or not that was offside.\"\n\n\"Linesmen and refs let players run through on goal for ages even if it's clearly offside, potentially causing injury,\" @lawrence_bury said. \"The one time in ages I have seen an instant whistle blow is tonight, at the highest level. Why? It's a catastrophe to football how bad the game is being managed.\"\n\n\"I refuse to believe that this is offside lmao,\" @CFC_Iann said. \"De ligt is offside but he doesn't even touch the ball, the linesman f*cked up the game.\"\n\n@Thomasjrennie wrote: \"Hold on. He's onside there isn't he? That's a balls up there from the linesman. When you think about all the times they play on when you KNOW someone is offside.\"\n\nBayern coach Thomas Tuchel was visibly incensed by the decision and didn't hold back his frustration. He received a yellow card for his vociferous protests aimed at the linesman. Speaking after the match, Tuchel labelled the incident an \"absolute disaster\" and criticised the officials for violating the rules by prematurely halting play.\n\nTuchel told DAZN: \"It's an absolute disaster. This scene must be played out to the end. That's the rule. The linesman made the mistake, and the referee made the second mistake. It's a violation of the rules.\"\n\nMatthijs de Ligt, the player at the centre of the offside controversy, shed light on the aftermath of the incident. He revealed that the linesman had apologised to him for the erroneous call, admitting his mistake. \"I don't want to say that Real Madrid always has the referees with them but that made the difference today.\" He added to Bein Sports: \"The linesman told me: 'Sorry, I made a mistake'.\" De Ligt's comments added fuel to the fire, with many questioning the impartiality of the officials.\n\nWhat lies ahead for Bayern Munich and Real Madrid\n\nWhile Bayern Munich's season ended in disappointment, Real Madrid marched on to the Champions League final. They are set to face Borussia Dortmund in a bid to clinch their 15th European title. However, the controversial decision against Bayern will undoubtedly linger in the minds of fans and players alike, casting a shadow over an otherwise thrilling encounter.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8118829928", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "09:15:10", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T09:15:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T09:14:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://guernseypress.com/sport/uk-sport/2024/05/09/no-comment-from-uefa-as-thomas-tuchel-rails-at-disastrous-decision/", "title": "No comment from UEFA as Thomas Tuchel rails at 'disastrous decision'", "body": "A linesman's flag was raised and the referee's whistle blown to rule out Matthijs de Ligt's late equaliser for Bayern Munich against Real Madrid.\n\nUEFA has offered no comment on what Bayern Munich coach Thomas Tuchel described as a \"disastrous decision\" by the on-field officials in the dying moments of their Champions League semi-final against Real Madrid.\n\nPolish referee Szymon Marciniak blew his whistle after one of his assistants raised an offside flag, moments before Matthijs de Ligt struck what would have been an equaliser for the German side.\n\nVAR could not make a call on whether the goal should stand or not because play had been stopped, and there is also the question of whether De Ligt would even have scored if Real's defence had not stopped for the whistle.\n\n\"They have a disastrous decision from the linesman and from the referee,\" he told TNT Sports.\n\n\"So, it feels almost like a betrayal in the end because of that decision. It was a huge fight, we left everything on the pitch and we were almost there. Now we have to say congratulations to Real Madrid.\n\n\"The linesman said sorry, but that does not help. At that kind of level, to raise the flag in a decision like this, a close decision, in the last minute - and the referee as well.\n\n\"The referee does not have to whistle. He sees that we win the second ball, he sees that we get a shot away and to whistle is a very, very bad decision.\n\n\"And it is against the rules and it is a bad decision from both of them. It is a disaster. Tough to swallow, but that is the way it is.\"\n\nWhile there has been no clarification or comment from UEFA, the officials could point to the VAR protocols published by the International Football Association Board, which state that an assistant referee's offside flag should only be delayed \"in a very clear attacking situation when a player is about to score a goal or has a clear run into/towards the opponents' penalty area\".\n\nTwo goals from Joselu helped Real recover from a goal down to win 4-3 on aggregate. They will now go on to face Borussia Dortmund in the final at Wembley on June 1.\n\nEnglish officials Michael Oliver and Anthony Taylor - both highly regarded by UEFA - could be in contention to referee the match. {"uri": "8119043502", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "11:31:38", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T11:31:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T11:31:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.indiatoday.in/sports/football/story/real-madrid-vs-bayern-munich-matthijs-de-ligt-offside-linesman-2537132-2024-05-09", "title": "Bayern's De Ligt reveals linesman apology after 'disastrous' offside call vs Madrid", "body": "Real Madrid beat Bayern Munich 4-3 on aggregate in the UCL semi-final\n\nBayern Munich centre-back Matthijs De Ligt revealed his conversation with the linesman in their UEFA Champions League semi-final against Real Madrid on May 8, and how the official apologised for the last-minute controversial offside call. Real Madrid came back from a 1-0 deficit to win the clash by 4-3 on aggregate, thanks to Joselu's brace in the dying moments of the match and secure their spot in what will be their 18th UCL final. However, the match was stamped by yet another controversial refereeing call, when De Ligt's stoppage time strike was falsely ruled offside, without even a proper VAR check. Since the final whistle of the high-value clash on Wednesday, the football world is yet again in argument about whether the proceedings were too harsh on the German giants.\n\nHaving drawn 2-2 against Carlo Ancelotti-managed Madrid in the first leg at the Allianz arena, Bayern saw themselves get a lead in the second leg due to a 68th minute strike from Alphonse Daives. However, Real Madrid's phenomenal clutch-ability in the competition, saw themselves secure their ticket to the Final at Wembley against Borussia Dortmund. But, De Ligt's ruled out goal has been a constant talking point amongst football pundits, on whether the match should have indeed headed into extra-time.\n\nSpeaking to beIN sports, De Ligt revealed how the linesman apologised and admitted to making an error with the offside call.\n\n\"The linesman said to me, 'I'm sorry, I made a mistake,' I can't buy anything for that. I'm not the type of person who wants to blame a loss or win on the referee, but it means you have to win because you win 2-1. I think if it's a rule, it's a rule,\" De Ligt said.\n\n'If it's offside, it's offside. But I think we made rules in football and the rules are if it's not a clear offside - which it wasn't because I don't see it yet if it's offside or not - you have to keep playing...If you go in the last minutes and you whistle like this, I think it's a big mistake. If it's offside or not, you can check it, but if you don't check it, how can you see it? The second goal, Rudiger is almost offside. If he whistles ok, but now there's a difference and this is a shame,\" De light added.\n\nUpon the game walking into the 13th minute of added time, De Ligt hit a deflected ball into the Real Madrid net, only seconds after the referee blew the whistle that deemed him offside.\n\nHowever, upon watching the replay, one can easily judge that De Ligt was considerably within the line of the Real Madrid defence.\n\nDue to the linesman raising his flag, which led to the referee blowing the whistle, the Real Madrid defenders, including goalkeeper Andriy Lunin, halted in their positions, withdrawing from play due to the apparent offside call. The argument around this scenario has put constant highlight on how the modern-day rules of football deem it unnecessary for the referee to stop the play, and only base his decision upon VAR inspection.\n\nWith Real Madrid having already won this year's La Liga title, Los Blancos will be heading to Wembley with some added confidence for their Final against Dortmund on June 2.", "source":
