{"uri": "8119033767", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "11:24:37", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T11:24:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T11:24:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/real-madrid-stuns-bayern-munich-103851607.html", "title": "Real Madrid stuns Bayern Munich late to reach Champions League final but match marred by controversial decision", "body": "Real Madrid manager Carlo Ancelotti credited the \"magical\" Santiago Bernab\u00e9u stadium for motivating his team to the Champions League final on Wednesday, after the Spanish side scored two late goals to beat Bayern Munich 2-1 in the semifinal second leg.\n\nWith the scores level at 2-2 after the first leg, both teams knew the winner in Madrid would progress through to London's showpiece event against Borussia Dortmund on June 1.\n\nIt had looked as though Bayern had done enough after Alphonso Davies scored a stunning goal in the 68th minute but, as they have done on countless occasions in this competition, Los Blancos found a way to hit back in the final moments of the match.\n\nWith all hope seemingly lost, Madrid's substitute striker Joselu turned the tie on its head after scoring two goals in the space of three minutes.\n\n\"It's happened again. Something that has happened time after time, which is inexplicable, has happened again,\" Ancelotti said, referring to the number of late comebacks Madrid has produced in the Champions League in recent seasons.\n\n\"A set of fans who drive us, a stadium that supports us, a stunning atmosphere and a group of players who believe. It's magical.\"\n\nMadrid's first goal came courtesy of a costly error from Bayern goalkeeper Manuel Neuer. The German had been impressive all game but spilled a simple shot to present Joselu with a chance to score the equalizer in the 88th minute.\n\nThe goal sparked something special inside the newly refurbished Bernab\u00e9u, and it was an atmosphere that pushed Madrid to find the winner in the 91st minute.\n\nIt was Joselu again who put the ball in the back of the net, but the goal was initially ruled out for offside.\n\nThe stadium held its breath as the video assistant referee (VAR) checked the decision and then erupted when it was decided that neither Antonio R\u00fcdiger, who provided the assist, nor Joselu was offside.\n\nStaff and players flooded off the Madrid bench to celebrate in front of the frenzied crowd, as Bayern players looked crestfallen having seen their hopes of reaching the final slip away in a matter of minutes.\n\nBut, incredibly, the drama wasn't finished yet.\n\nIn search of an equalizer, Bayern Munich's Matthijs de Ligt did get the ball in the back of Madrid's net in the 13th minute of added time.\n\nHowever, the referee had stopped play just seconds before the defender's shot whistled into the bottom corner, after spotting the linesman had raised his flag.\n\nThis time, VAR could not be used to check the incredibly tight decision because the referee had blown his whistle.\n\nUsually, in such situations, the officials are supposed to let the attacking phase continue before deciding on any offside.\n\nDe Ligt told beIN Sports after the match that the linesman told him, \"I'm sorry, I made a mistake,\" but said that was of little comfort to the side.\n\n\"If it's offside, it's offside, but I think we made rules in football and the rules say if it's not a clear offside, which it wasn't ... you have to keep playing,\" he said postmatch. \"And if you go in the last minute and whistle like this, yeah, I think this is a big, big, big mistake. If it's offside or not, I don't know, you can check it. But if you don't check it, how can you see it?\"\n\nBayern manager Thomas Tuchel also said the linesman apologized for raising his flag too early, but the German said such an apology \"does not help\" and criticized the referee for blowing the whistle too early.\n\n\"It almost feels like a betrayal because of that decision,\" Tuchel told TNT Sports after the match.\n\n\"It's a very, very bad decision. It's against the rules [...] it's tough to swallow, but it's the way it is.\"\n\nWhile Tuchel and de Ligt were unhappy with the officials, they both accepted the defeat and congratulated Madrid for making yet another final.\n\nThe manager, though, came in for criticism himself for his decision to take Harry Kane off in the 85th minute.\n\nIn addition to his attacking threats, the English striker has somewhat perfected the art of running down the clock and his physical presence was needed in the final minutes of the game.\n\nTuchel, though, told critics that Kane was unable to give anymore in the match.\n\nAfter the full-time whistle, Madrid celebrated in style as it crowned Joselu the club's new hero.\n\nThe striker had initially struggled after his loan move from second division Espanyol to the Spanish giant but has now written his name in the club's storied history.\n\nFollowing his match-winning exploits, pictures of the striker in Paris supporting Madrid at the 2022 Champions League final spread on social media - two years later and the 34-year-old inspired his team to the pinnacle of European soccer.\n\n\"My dreams aren't as beautiful as what happened today. As a forward, you dream of scoring goals, and if they're like tonight's, then even better,\" Joselu said after the match.", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo An absolute disaster. With Real's second goal, they let the play continue. The clear rule is that the scene must continue. The first mistake was made by the linesman, the second by the referee,\" he said.\n\nBayern took the lead with Alphonso Davies' shot midway through the second half but Real battled back with two late goals from Joselu to book their final spot.\n\nDe Ligt said the linesman had apologised to him after the game.\n\n\"Very difficult. Of course as sportspeople we accept it,\" said Tuchel. \"But it is a semi-final, it's not for two such violations of the rule. Everyone has to be at their limit. The referees have to be there as well.\"\n\n\"That is what we expect. So the apology does not really help.\"\n\nBayern keeper Manuel Neuer spilled the ball into Joselu's path for the equaliser in the 88th minute but Tuchel did not want to blame his keeper who had been outstanding up to that point.\n\n\"Ninety-nine out of 100 times he makes it. {"uri": "8119000134", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "11:03:57", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T11:03:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T11:03:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/sports/national/real-madrid-stuns-bayern-munich-late-to-reach-champions-league-final-but-match-marred-by/article_29029e9b-29b7-5176-aa90-17f2e58e695f.html", "title": "Real Madrid stuns Bayern Munich late to reach Champions League final but match marred by controversial decision", "body": "(CNN) -- Real Madrid manager Carlo Ancelotti credited the \"magical\" Santiago Bernab\u00e9u stadium for motivating his team to the Champions League final on Wednesday, after the Spanish side scored two late goals to beat Bayern Munich 2-1 in the semifinal second leg.\n\nWith the scores level at 2-2 after the first leg, both teams knew the winner in Madrid would progress through to London's showpiece event against Borussia Dortmund on June 1.\n\nIt had looked as though Bayern had done enough after Alphonso Davies scored a stunning goal in the 68th minute but, as they have done on countless occasions in this competition, Los Blancos found a way to hit back in the final moments of the match.\n\nWith all hope seemingly lost, Madrid's substitute striker Joselu turned the tie on its head after scoring two goals in the space of three minutes.\n\n\"It's happened again. Something that has happened time after time, which is inexplicable, has happened again,\" Ancelotti said, referring to the number of late comebacks Madrid has produced in the Champions League in recent seasons.\n\n\"A set of fans who drive us, a stadium that supports us, a stunning atmosphere and a group of players who believe. It's magical.\"\n\nMadrid's first goal came courtesy of a costly error from Bayern goalkeeper Manuel Neuer. The German had been impressive all game but spilled a simple shot to present Joselu with a chance to score the equalizer in the 88th minute.\n\nThe goal sparked something special inside the newly refurbished Bernab\u00e9u, and it was an atmosphere that pushed Madrid to find the winner in the 91st minute.\n\nIt was Joselu again who put the ball in the back of the net, but the goal was initially ruled out for offside.\n\nThe stadium held its breath as the video assistant referee (VAR) checked the decision and then erupted when it was decided that neither Antonio R\u00fcdiger, who provided the assist, nor Joselu was offside.\n\nStaff and players flooded off the Madrid bench to celebrate in front of the frenzied crowd, as Bayern players looked crestfallen having seen their hopes of reaching the final slip away in a matter of minutes.\n\nBut, incredibly, the drama wasn't finished yet.\n\nControversial offside flag decision\n\nIn search of an equalizer, Bayern Munich's Matthijs de Ligt did get the ball in the back of Madrid's net in the 13th minute of added time.\n\nHowever, the referee had stopped play just seconds before the defender's shot whistled into the bottom corner, after spotting the linesman had raised his flag.\n\nThis time, VAR could not be used to check the incredibly tight decision because the referee had blown his whistle.\n\nUsually, in such situations, the officials are supposed to let the attacking phase continue before deciding on any offside.\n\nDe Ligt told beIN Sports after the match that the linesman told him, \"I'm sorry, I made a mistake,\" but said that was of little comfort to the side.\n\n\"If it's offside, it's offside, but I think we made rules in football and the rules say if it's not a clear offside, which it wasn't ... you have to keep playing,\" he said postmatch. \"And if you go in the last minute and whistle like this, yeah, I think this is a big, big, big mistake. If it's offside or not, I don't know, you can check it. But if you don't check it, how can you see it?\"\n\nBayern manager Thomas Tuchel also said the linesman apologized for raising his flag too early, but the German said such an apology \"does not help\" and criticized the referee for blowing the whistle too early.\n\n\"It almost feels like a betrayal because of that decision,\" Tuchel told TNT Sports after the match.\n\n\"It's a very, very bad decision. It's against the rules [...] it's tough to swallow, but it's the way it is.\"\n\nWhile Tuchel and de Ligt were unhappy with the officials, they both accepted the defeat and congratulated Madrid for making yet another final.\n\nThe manager, though, came in for criticism himself for his decision to take Harry Kane off in the 85th minute.\n\nIn addition to his attacking threats, the English striker has somewhat perfected the art of running down the clock and his physical presence was needed in the final minutes of the game.\n\nTuchel, though, told critics that Kane was unable to give anymore in the match.\n\nFrom fan to hero\n\nAfter the full-time whistle, Madrid celebrated in style as it crowned Joselu the club's new hero.\n\nThe striker had initially struggled after his loan move from second division Espanyol to the Spanish giant but has now written his name in the club's storied history.\n\nFollowing his match-winning exploits, pictures of the striker in Paris supporting Madrid at the 2022 Champions League final spread on social media - two years later and the 34-year-old inspired his team to the pinnacle of European soccer.\n\n\"My dreams aren't as beautiful as what happened today. As a forward, you dream of scoring goals, and if they're like tonight's, then even better,\" Joselu said after the match.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. {"uri": "8118686493", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "07:39:39", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T07:39:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T07:39:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://tribune.com.pk/story/2465809/absolute-disaster-tuchel-slams-late-offside-call", "title": "'Absolute disaster': Tuchel slams late offside call", "body": "Bayern Munich boss says decision to disallow a late goal for his side was against every rule of modern football\n\nBayern Munich coach Thomas Tuchel slammed a late offside call, calling the decision an \"absolute disaster\" as Real Madrid eliminated his side in the Champions League semi-finals on Wednesday.\n\nWith Real 2-1 up having come from behind with two late goals, Joshua Kimmich put in a long pass which was headed centrally by Thomas Mueller for defender Matthijs de Ligt to score in the 12th minute of stoppage time.\n\nReal, who drew the Munich tie 2-2, went through 4-3 on aggregate.\n\nThe goal did not stand after the linesman raised his flag earlier in the move before the ball went in the net, therefore ruling out a VAR review.\n\nAn animated Tuchel ran down the sideline after the decision. After the match, he told broadcaster DAZN the decision was \"a disaster, an absolute disaster\".\n\n\"We have to let the action play out until the end. That's the rule, especially since it's so close to the goal, and it's so limited.\n\n\"The first error is made by the linesman, the second comes from the referee,\" Tuchel said.\n\nThe 50-year-old coach told broadcaster TNT the decision \"felt like a betrayal\".\n\nSpeaking at the press conference, Tuchel said the referee apologised but added: \"It doesn't help to say sorry.\n\n\"Everyone has to go to their limit, everyone has to suffer, everyone has to play without making mistakes. So the referee has to be at that level too.\n\n\"It just doesn't help to make excuses after the fact.\n\n\"You are on the field for this reason, because you are the best there is. And we have the right to expect that until the end.\"\n\nThe goalscorer De Ligt agreed with his coach, calling the decision decisive in the match.\n\n\"The scene at the end, I find it incredible. I can't understand why he (the referee) doesn't let the action play out.\n\n\"He apologised. I wouldn't want to say that Real are always lucky, but that decision makes the difference today,\" De Ligt told DAZN.\n\nA disappointed Bayern captain Manuel Neuer said: \"We're in the Champions League semi-finals... {"uri": "8118691090", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "07:42:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T07:42:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T07:42:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.sportbible.com/football/football-news/champions-league/thomas-tuchel-bayern-munich-real-madrid-offside-var-862986-20240509", "title": "Thomas Tuchel makes serious allegation about referee after Bayern Munich offside decision", "body": "Thomas Tuchel made a serious allegation about the referee after Bayern Munich were knocked out of the Champions League by Real Madrid.\n\nOn Wednesday Bayern Munich were defeated in the semi-finals of the Champions League in the cruelest of circumstances as they fell foul of yet another remarkable Real Madrid comeback.\n\nBayern looked to be heading to the final after Alphonso Davies broke the deadlock with a second half wonder strike, but former Stoke City striker Joselu scored 88th and 91st minute goals to turn the tie on its head.\n\nMadrid successfully defended their slender 4-3 aggregate lead for 15 minutes of injury-time, sparking jubilant scenes in the Estadio Santiago Bernabeu.\n\nHowever, Bayern were left furious after being denied what appeared to be a legitimate equaliser in the 13th minute of added time.\n\nThe linesman raised his flag for offside as Noussair Mazraoui contested a long ball with Ferland Mendy, and referee Szymon Marciniak blew his whistle seconds before Matthijs de Ligt smashed home a would-be equaliser.\n\nReplays appeared to show that Mazraoui was actually onside, but VAR could not review the incident as the referee had already blown his whistle.\n\nBayern's player and coaching staff were furious, as current offside protocols dictate that officials let play continue until the attack is over, meaning VAR can then intervene if the incorrect decision is made on-field.\n\nAccording to Bayern boss Thomas Tuchel, the linesman apologised for raising his flag early.\n\nAfter the match Tuchel didn't hold back in his criticism of the officials, and even claimed that the incident would not have occurred had it been Los Blancos searching for a late goal.\n\n\"To raise the flag in a situation like this where you can never, ever be sure that it is offside... to have the balls, to have the guts to raise the flag in a situation like this is a huge, huge call, and it's the wrong call,\" Tuchel said during his post-match media conference.\n\n\"The referee has the chance - when he sees that we win the second ball, and we win the rebound, and we get a shot away within five seconds - not to whistle. He takes the decision to whistle.\n\n\"It's against every rule. We accept that we lost, it is what it is. But...that would not have happened on the other side.\"\n\nUEFA could decide to punish Tuchel for alleging officiating bias.\n\nDefeat means Bayern will finish a season trophy-less for the first time since 2011-12, and denies Tuchel one final hoorah before he departs the club this summer.", "source": {"uri": "sportbible.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "www.sportbible.com"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8119316454", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "14:32:31", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T14:32:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T14:32:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://morningstaronline.co.uk/article/no-comment-uefa-tuchel-rages-disastrous-decision", "title": "No comment from Uefa as Tuchel rages at 'disastrous decision'", "body": "UEFA has offered no comment on what Bayern Munich coach Thomas Tuchel described as a \"disastrous decision\" by the on-field officials in the dying moments of their Champions League semi-final against Real Madrid on Wednesday evening.\n\nPolish referee Szymon Marciniak blew his whistle after one of his assistants raised an offside flag, moments before Matthijs de Ligt struck what would have been an equaliser for the German side.\n\nVAR could not make a call on whether the goal should stand or not because play had been stopped, and there is also the question of whether De Ligt would even have scored if Real's defence had not stopped for the whistle.\n\nHowever, Tuchel took no comfort from that as his side blew the lead given to them midway through the second half by Alphonso Davies.\n\n\"They have a disastrous decision from the linesman and from the referee,\" he told TNT Sports.\n\n\"So, it feels almost like a betrayal in the end because of that decision. It was a huge fight, we left everything on the pitch and we were almost there. Now we have to say congratulations to Real Madrid.\n\n\"The linesman said sorry, but that does not help. At that kind of level, to raise the flag in a decision like this, a close decision, in the last minute -- and the referee as well.\n\n\"The referee does not have to whistle. He sees that we win the second ball, he sees that we get a shot away and to whistle is a very, very bad decision.\n\n\"And it is against the rules and it is a bad decision from both of them. It is a disaster. Tough to swallow, but that is the way it is.\"\n\nWhile there has been no clarification or comment from Uefa, the officials could point to the VAR protocols published by the International Football Association Board, which state that an assistant referee's offside flag should only be delayed \"in a very clear attacking situation when a player is about to score a goal or has a clear run into/towards the opponents' penalty area.\"\n\nTwo goals from Joselu helped Real recover from a goal down to win 4-3 on aggregate. They will now go on to face Borussia Dortmund in the final at Wembley on June 1.\n\nEnglish officials Michael Oliver and Anthony Taylor -- both highly regarded by Uefa -- could be in contention to referee the match. The appointments for all three men's club competition finals will be announced by Uefa on Monday.\n\nAn intriguing subplot was Harry Kane up against compatriot Jude Bellingham, who produced an all-action display and helped set up a Wembley showdown with old club Borussia Dortmund on June 1.\n\nIt was a different story for Kane after this loss extended his wait for silverware, and Tuchel made the surprise decision to replace the former Tottenham forward in the 85th minute with Bayern leading.\n\nWhile Tuchel was not asked specifically about Kane being taken off, he said: \"Part of the {"uri": "8118754711", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "08:23:50", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T08:23:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T08:23:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.wionews.com/football/matthijs-de-ligt-claims-referee-apologised-to-him-for-mistake-that-cost-bayern-place-in-ucl-final-719670", "title": "Matthijs de Ligt claims referee apologised to him for 'mistake' that cost Bayern place in UCL final", "body": "The offside on the De Ligt goal looked close to the naked eye but since the whistle was blown, VAR could not involve itself in the recheck process\n\nBayern Munich defender Matthijs de Ligt has claimed that the linesman apologised to him for disallowing the goal that could have levelled the Champions League semifinal tie against Real Madrid on Wednesday (May 9). De Ligt scored the contentious goal in the stoppage time but it was ruled out as the linesman had raised the offside flag.\n\nSpeaking after the match, the Dutchman rued that the lapse of judgement from the referee had cost his team a place in the UCL final.\n\n\"The rule says that if it's not clear offside...you have to keep playing.\" De Ligt said. \"And if you go in the last minute and you whistle like this, I think this is a big mistake. If it's offside or not, I don't know, VAR can check it, but if you don't check it, how can you see it? This is a shame.\"\n\nThe offside on the De Ligt goal looked close to the naked eye but since the whistle was blown, VAR could not involve itself in the recheck process.\n\nDe Ligt's sentiments were echoed by manager Thomas Tuchel who said it was a 'disaster' that the referee chalked off the goal.\n\n\"I think it's pretty clear and there is no doubt that is against the rules of modern football. A disaster. An absolute disaster,\" said Tuchel.\n\n\"Very difficult. Of course as sportspeople we accept it. But it is a semi-final, it's not for two such violations of the rule. Everyone has to be at their limit. The referees have to be there as well. That is what we expect. So the apology does not really help.\"\n\nAlso read | 'Absolute disaster': Thomas Tuchel fumes over Bayern's late disallowed goal against Madrid\n\nMeanwhile, Madrid boss Carlo Ancelotti shrugged off the controversy saying a similar goal was ruled out for his side when Nacho scored from inside the box.\n\n\"The last play is clear, the referee blows the whistle and we stop,\" he said. \"This referee is very good, he refereed in a World Cup final. They complain about this and we complain about the goal by Nacho that was disallowed. I got a strange feeling. To raise your flag in a situation like this when you can never be sure that this is offside, to have the guts to raise the flag in a situation like this is a huge call. And it's the wrong call.\n\n\"The referee has the chance when he sees that we win the second ball and we win the rebound and we get the shot away within five seconds, he has the chance not to whistle. He takes the decision to whistle - it is against every rule.\n\n\"We accept we lost. It is what it is but that would not have happened on the other side.\"\n\nDe Ligt revealed the linesman apologised for \"making a mistake\" after the match.\n\nHe said: \"This is a shame. The linesman said to me 'I'm sorry I made a mistake'.\n\n\"In the end, I'm not the type of person who wants to blame the loss or win on the referee so Madrid deserves to win because they won {"uri": "2024-05-349588484", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "23:31:08", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T23:31:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T22:00:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.rfi.fr/en/sports/20240508-absolute-disaster-bayern-boss-tuchel-slams-late-offside-call", "title": "'Absolute disaster': Bayern boss Tuchel slams late offside call", "body": "Madrid (AFP) - Bayern Munich coach Thomas Tuchel slammed a late offside call, calling the decision an \"absolute disaster\" as Real Madrid eliminated his side in the Champions League semi-finals on Wednesday.\n\nWith Real 2-1 up having come from behind with two late goals, Joshua Kimmich put in a long pass which was headed centrally by Thomas Mueller for defender Matthijs de Ligt to score in the 12th minute of stoppage time.\n\nReal, who drew the Munich tie 2-2, went through 4-3 on aggregate.\n\nThe goal did not stand after the linesman raised his flag earlier in the move before the ball went in the net, therefore ruling out a VAR review.\n\nAn animated Tuchel ran down the sideline after the decision. After the match, he told broadcaster DAZN the decision was \"a disaster, an absolute disaster\".\n\n\"We have to let the action play out until the end. That's the rule, especially since it's so close to the goal, and it's so limited.\n\n\"The first error is made by the linesman, the second comes from the referee,\" Tuchel said.\n\nThe 50-year-old coach told broadcaster TNT the decision \"felt like a betrayal\".\n\nSpeaking at the press conference, Tuchel said the referee apologised but added: \"It doesn't help to say sorry.\n\n\"Everyone has to go to their limit, everyone has to suffer, everyone has to play without making mistakes. So the referee has to be at that level too.\n\n\"It just doesn't help to make excuses after the fact.\n\n\"You are on the field for this reason, because you are the best there is. And we have the right to expect that until the end.\"\n\nThe goalscorer De Ligt agreed with his coach, calling the decision decisive in the match.\n\n\"The scene at the end, I find it incredible. I can't understand why he (the referee) doesn't let the action play out.\n\n\"He apologised. I wouldn't want to say that Real are always lucky, but that decision makes the difference today,\" De Ligt told DAZN.\n\nA disappointed Bayern captain Manuel Neuer said: \"We're in the Champions League semi-finals... {"uri": "8118633131", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "07:02:55", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T07:02:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T07:02:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.the42.ie/real-madrid-bayern-munich-2-6374586-May2024/", "title": "'It feels almost like a betrayal' - Tuchel fumes at decision to rule out Bayern equaliser", "body": "Referee Szymon Marciniak ruled out goal in 13th-minute of stoppage time when linesman raised offside flag before phase of play concluded.\n\nTHOMAS TUCHEL VENTED his frustration at the \"disastrous decision\" to rule out a potential Matthijs de Ligt equaliser after Bayern Munich missed out on the Champions League final following a 4-3 aggregate loss to Real Madrid.\n\nThe last-four tie had been evenly-poised after a 2-2 draw in Germany last week and Alphonso Davies fired the visitors into a surprise lead with 22 minutes left at the Santiago Bernabeu.\n\nBayern looked on course to end Madrid's 13-month unbeaten home run, but Joselu levelled in the 88th minute after Manuel Neuer spilled a shot by Vinicius Junior before the former Stoke forward steered home from close range three minutes later to earn a memorable 2-1 victory.\n\nThe goal was originally ruled out after the offside flag was raised, but VAR told Szymon Marciniak to review the incident and both Joselu and defender-turned-assist-maker Antonio Rudiger were onside.\n\nFurther drama occurred in the 13th minute of stoppage time when referee Marciniak blew his whistle, upon the offside flag being raised, just before De Ligt fired into the bottom corner after a Joshua Kimmich pass forced a scramble in the Madrid box.\n\nBayern remonstrated with the officials, but to no avail as the German giants and England captain Harry Kane were consigned to a trophyless season.\n\n\"We were almost through, almost there and had a very unusual mistake by our very best player for the equaliser,\" Tuchel told TNT Sports.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"Then we conceded in a very narrow decision, the second one in stoppage time. Then we scored one and they have a disastrous decision from the linesman and from the referee.\n\n\"So, it feels almost like a betrayal in the end because of that decision. It was a huge fight, we left everything on the pitch and we were almost there. Now we have to say congratulations to Real Madrid.\n\n\"The linesman said sorry, but that does not help. At that kind of level, to raise the flag in a decision like this, a close decision, in the last minute and the referee as well.\n\n\"The referee does not have to whistle. He sees that we win the second ball, he sees that we get a shot away and to whistle is a very, very bad decision.\n\n\"And it is against the rules and it is a bad decision from both of them. It is a disaster. Tough to swallow, but that is the way it is.\"\n\nAn intriguing subplot was Kane up against compatriot Jude Bellingham, who produced an all-action display and helped set up a Wembley showdown with old club Borussia Dortmund on 1 June.\n\nIt was a different story for Kane after this loss extended his wait for silverware, and Tuchel made the surprise decision to replace the former Tottenham forward in the 85th minute with Bayern leading.\n\nWhile Tuchel was not asked specifically about Kane being taken off, he said: \"Part of the story is we start with a front four and all four players need to go out because of injuries and cramps.\n\n\"It is a bit too much at that level.\"\n\nReal Madrid players celebrate. Alamy Stock Photo Alamy Stock Photo\n\nBellingham hailed Madrid's never-say-die attitude and insisted he felt no nerves after a dream night.\n\n\"We have seen it a lot of times this season where it looks like we're dead and buried. It doesn't matter who scores the goal because someone always manages it. That mentality of never-say-die,\" Bellingham told TNT Sports.\n\n\"Joselu, I don't think he will be sleeping much tonight! He will be useless in training tomorrow. But, no honestly he deserves it all. He has been an amazing member of the squad throughout the whole season and this is his night.\n\n\"They are unbelievable (the fans). They are the best in the world by far.\n\n\"Coming here, there is a reason why we turn so many games or why when we're down in certain legs that we always manage to come back in the second leg. It is because of these lot. They give you an energy that you can't get from anything else.\n\n\"You come here and that is all they talk about. They talk about how you've had the 14th, but how they want the 15th. The lads said it was the same when we won the 10th, all they asked for was the 11th, but that is why I love being here because you can never be settled.\"", "source": {"uri": "the42.ie", "dataType": {"uri": "2024-05-349879830", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "07:18:32", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T07:18:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T06:33:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://weeklyvoice.com/this-is-shame-not-the-moment-for-apologies-de-ligt-tuchel-react-to-offside-decision-controversy-in-champions-league-sf/", "title": "'This is shame; not the moment for apologies': De Ligt, Tuchel react to 'offside decision' controversy in Champions League SF", "body": "Madrid, May 9 (VOICE) A battle between Real Madrid and Bayern Munich is the biggest rivalry in European football. The two teams have met time and time again in the biggest club competition in the world.\n\nOn Wednesday, the two teams met in an epic battle at the Santiago Bernabeu with Real Madrid progressing to their 18th Champions League final.\n\nUnfortunately, in what was a chaotic final 20 minutes of the game which saw two goals being scored, two goals being disallowed and many fights breaking out, the brilliance of the two teams was overshadowed by controversy with Bayern defender, Matthijs De Ligt even claiming that the assistant referee apologised for the late call which saw the referee blow the whistle on an offside decision seconds before the Dutch center back scored what would have been the equalizer.\n\nFollowing the emotional encounter, many players and both coaches had a lot to say about what just transpired on the pitch.\n\n\"The linesman said to me, 'I'm sorry, I made a mistake', The rule says that if it's not clear offside, you have to keep playing and if you go in the last minute and you whistle like this, I think this is a big mistake. If it's offside or not, I don't know, VAR can check it, but if you don't check it, how can you see it? This is a shame,\" said a dejected Matthijs De Ligt.\n\n\"Very difficult. This is a semifinal, it's not the moment for apologies. Really not. It's not the moment for two huge violations of rules and then an apology. We all have to go to our limits, all have to suffer, all have to play without mistakes. The referees at this level also have to do that. When you don't deliver, it doesn't help when you apologize, even though of course as sportsmen we accept it,\" said FC Bayern manager, Thomas Tuchel.\n\nThe moment was brilliant, to score my first Champions League goal against a team like Madrid but when it's all said and done, we didn't make it to the final,\" said Alphonso Davies who has been heavily linked with a move to Real Madrid this summer.\n\n\"The offside episode is simple to explain. Maybe it wasn't offside, but the referee whistled (before the goal) and we stopped playing. That's it. Bayern complaining about the offside? OK, then we complain about the canceled goal of Nacho. Kimmich dived,\" said Ancelotti.\n\n\"We put Real Madrid in another final, today we played for our injured teammates, for our family, for the Bernab\u00e9u and we played for this shirt that always {"uri": "8118590428", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "06:30:34", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T06:30:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T06:30:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.rte.ie/sport/soccer/2024/0509/1448123-tuchel-rage-at-bernabeu-betrayal-that-sent-bayern-out/", "title": "Tuchel rage at Bernabeu 'betrayal' that sent Bayern out", "body": "Thomas Tuchel vented his frustration at the \"disastrous decision\" to rule out a potential Matthijs de Ligt equaliser after Bayern Munich missed out on the Champions League final following a 4-3 aggregate loss to Real Madrid.\n\nThe last-four tie had been evenly-poised after a 2-2 draw in Germany last week and Alphonso Davies fired the visitors into a surprise lead with 22 minutes left at the Santiago Bernabeu.\n\nBayern looked on course to end Madrid's 13-month unbeaten home run, but Joselu levelled in the 88th minute after Manuel Neuer spilled a shot by Vinicius Junior before the former Stoke forward steered home from close range three minutes later to earn a memorable 2-1 victory.\n\nThe goal was originally ruled out after the offside flag was raised, but VAR told Szymon Marciniak to review the incident and both Joselu and defender-turned-assist-maker Antonio Rudiger were onside.\n\nFurther drama occurred in the 13th minute of stoppage time when referee Marciniak blew his whistle, upon the offside flag being raised, just before De Ligt fired into the bottom corner after a Joshua Kimmich pass forced a scramble in the Madrid box.\n\nBayern remonstrated with the officials, but to no avail as the German giants and England captain Harry Kane were consigned to a trophyless season.\n\n\"We were almost through, almost there and had a very unusual mistake by our very best player for the equaliser,\" Tuchel said.\n\n\"Then we conceded in a very narrow decision, the second one in stoppage time. Then we scored one and they have a disastrous decision from the linesman and from the referee.\n\n\"So, it feels almost like a betrayal in the end because of that decision. It was a huge fight, we left everything on the pitch and we were almost there. Now we have to say congratulations to Real Madrid.\n\n\"The linesman said sorry, but that does not help. At that kind of level, to raise the flag in a decision like this, a close decision, in the last minute and the referee as well.\n\n\"The referee does not have to whistle. He sees that we win the second ball, he sees that we get a shot away and to whistle is a very, very bad decision.\n\n\"And it is against the rules and it is a bad decision from both of them. It is a disaster. Tough to swallow, but that is the way it is.\"\n\nAn intriguing subplot was Kane up against compatriot Jude Bellingham, who produced an all-action display and helped set up a Wembley showdown with old club Borussia Dortmund on June 1.\n\nIt was a different story for Kane after this loss extended his wait for silverware, and Tuchel made the surprise decision to replace the former Tottenham forward in the 85th minute with Bayern leading.\n\nWhile Tuchel was not asked specifically about Kane being taken off, he said: \"Part of the story is we start with a front four and all four players need to go out because of injuries and cramps.\n\n\"It is a bit too much at that level.\"\n\nWatch Shamrock Rovers v St Patrick's Athletic in the League of Ireland on Friday from 7.35pm on RT\u00c92 and But it was ruled off.\n\nBayern Munich coach Thomas Tuchel slammed a late offside call, calling the decision an \"absolute disaster\" as Real Madrid eliminated his side in the Champions League semi-finals on Wednesday.\n\nWith Real 2-1 up having come from behind with two late goals, Joshua Kimmich put in a long pass which was headed centrally by Thomas Mueller for defender Matthijs de Ligt to score in the 12th minute of stoppage time.\n\nReal, who drew the Munich tie 2-2, went through 4-3 on aggregate.\n\nThe goal did not stand after the linesman raised his flag earlier in the move before the ball went in the net, therefore ruling out a VAR review.\n\nREAD ALSO: Joselu Earns Madrid Incredible Bayern Comeback To Reach Champions League Final\n\nAn animated Tuchel ran down the sideline after the decision. After the match, he told broadcaster DAZN the decision was \"a disaster, an absolute disaster\".\n\n\"We have to let the action play out until the end. That's the rule, especially since it's so close to the goal, and it's so limited.\n\n\"The first error is made by the linesman, the second comes from the referee,\" Tuchel said.\n\nThe 50-year-old coach told broadcaster TNT the decision \"felt like a betrayal\".\n\nSpeaking at the press conference, Tuchel said the referee apologised but added: \"It doesn't help to say sorry.\n\n\"Everyone has to go to their limit, everyone has to suffer, everyone has to play without making mistakes. So the referee has to be at that level too.\n\n\"It just doesn't help to make excuses after the fact.\n\n\"You are on the field for this reason, because you are the best there is. And we have the right to expect that until the end.\"\n\nThe goalscorer De Ligt agreed with his coach, calling the decision decisive in the match.\n\n\"The scene at the end, I find it incredible. I can't understand why he (the referee) doesn't let the action play out.\n\n\"He apologised. I wouldn't want to say that Real are always lucky, but that decision makes the difference today,\" De Ligt told DAZN.\n\nA disappointed Bayern captain Manuel Neuer said: \"We're in the Champions League semi-finals... {"uri": "8118801260", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "08:56:08", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T08:56:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T08:55:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/no-uefa-thomas-tuchel-rails-085138848.html", "title": "No comment from UEFA as Thomas Tuchel rails at 'disastrous decision'", "body": "UEFA has offered no comment on what Bayern Munich coach Thomas Tuchel described as a \"disastrous decision\" by the on-field officials in the dying moments of their Champions League semi-final against Real Madrid.\n\nPolish referee Szymon Marciniak blew his whistle after one of his assistants raised an offside flag, moments before Matthijs de Ligt struck what would have been an equaliser for the German side.\n\nVAR could not make a call on whether the goal should stand or not because play had been stopped, and there is also the question of whether De Ligt would even have scored if Real's defence had not stopped for the whistle.\n\nHowever, Tuchel took no comfort from that as his side blew the lead given to them midway through the second half by Alphonso Davies.\n\n\"They have a disastrous decision from the linesman and from the referee,\" he told TNT Sports.\n\n\"So, it feels almost like a betrayal in the end because of that decision. It was a huge fight, we left everything on the pitch and we were almost there. Now we have to say congratulations to Real Madrid.\n\n\"The linesman said sorry, but that does not help. At that kind of level, to raise the flag in a decision like this, a close decision, in the last minute - and the referee as well.\n\n\"The referee does not have to whistle. He sees that we win the second ball, he sees that we get a shot away and to whistle is a very, very bad decision.\n\n\"And it is against the rules and it is a bad decision from both of them. It is a disaster. Tough to swallow, but that is the way it is.\"\n\nWhile there has been no clarification or comment from UEFA, the officials could point to the VAR protocols published by the International Football Association Board, which state that an assistant referee's offside flag should only be delayed \"in a very clear attacking situation when a player is about to score a goal or has a clear run into/towards the opponents' penalty area\".\n\nTwo goals from Joselu helped Real recover from a goal down to win 4-3 on aggregate. They will now go on to face Borussia Dortmund in the final at Wembley on June 1.\n\nEnglish officials Michael Oliver and Anthony Taylor - both highly regarded by UEFA - could be in contention to referee the match. Vardrid is a term used to mock Real Madrid owing to what many football fans believe is a clear bias present in the game of referees and the VAR favouring Real Madrid during matches.\n\nBayern took the lead with a stunning goal from Alphonso Davies, while goalkeeper Manuel Neuer made some excellent saves to maintain their advantage.\n\nHowever, Real Madrid ultimately secured the victory to advance to the final.\n\nHowever, a blunder by Neuer allowed Joselu to snatch the ball and slide it into the net to level the score in the 88th minute.\n\nJust two minutes later, Real Madrid went ahead in the game and the overall tie, with Joselu converting a cross from Antonio Rudiger, igniting pandemonium inside the Bernabeu.\n\nThis came after VAR overturned a call to disallow the goal due to offside. Bayern thought they had scored when Konrad Laimer drilled Thomas Muller's knockdown into the bottom corner, but referee Szymon Marciniak had already stopped play, signaling offside.\n\nSince the whistle was blown during the play, VAR could not review or overturn the decision.\n\nReplays indicated that the offside call was extremely close, leading to frustration among Bayern players, who were upset that the play was halted prematurely.\n\nSpeaking after the match, Tuchel revealed that the assistant referee apologized to the Bayern players right after the controversial incident.\n\nHe stated, \"The linesman's decision was terrible, and the referee's call was just as bad. It feels like we've been betrayed because of that call. Still, we have to congratulate Real Madrid.\"\n\nTuchel concluded, \"It was a really poor decision, and it went against the rules. It's a hard pill to swallow, but that's how it is.\"\n\nBayern's sporting director, Max Eberl, later stated that referee Marciniak had apologized to him regarding the incident.\n\nAt the same time, defender Matthijs de Ligt echoed these sentiments, calling the decision a \"major, major error,\" and confirmed Tuchel's claim that the linesman had offered an apology about the situation.", "source": It was a huge fight, we left everything on the pitch and we were almost there. Now we have to say congratulations to Real Madrid.\n\n\"The linesman said sorry, but that does not help. At that kind of level, to raise the flag in a decision like this, a close decision, in the last minute - and the referee as well.\n\n\"The referee does not have to whistle. He sees that we win the second ball, he sees that we get a shot away and to whistle is a very, very bad decision.\n\n\"And it is against the rules and it is a bad decision from both of them. It is a disaster. Tough to swallow, but that is the way it is.\"\n\nWhile there has been no clarification or comment from Uefa on Tuchel's outburst, officials could point to the VAR protocols published by the International Football Association Board.\n\nThey state that an assistant referee's offside flag should only be delayed \"in a very clear attacking situation when a player is about to score a goal or has a clear run into/towards the opponents' penalty area\".\n\nReal Madrid's win means they will now go on to face Borussia Dortmund in the final at Wembley on June 1, where they could lift the trophy for a record-extending 15th time.\n\nBayern - and England captain Harry Kane - are destined to finish the season without a trophy for the first time since 2012, after Bayer Leverkusen ended their 11-year domination of the Bundesliga.\n\nThe absence of any Premier League teams means that English officials Michael Oliver and Anthony Taylor - both highly regarded by Uefa - could be in contention {"uri": "8118182707", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "23:12:37", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T23:12:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T23:11:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.tbsnews.net/sports/bayern-manager-tuchel-slams-disastrous-decision-linesman-disallowed-goal-against-real-ucl", "title": "Bayern manager Tuchel slams 'disastrous decision' by linesman for", "body": "\"We scored one, and it's a disastrous decision from the linesman and referee,\" the Bayern manager said.\n\nThomas Tuchel slammed the \"disastrous\" decision by the match officials to disallow Matthijs de Ligt's late goal as Bayern Munich crashed out of the UEFA Champions League to Real Madrid.\n\nThe flashpoint occurred in the 13th minute of injury time when Bayern pumped the ball into the Madrid box to Noussair Mazraoui who knocked the ball down for the Dutch defender.\n\nDe Ligt volleyed the ball into the net, only for the referee to wave the goal away on account of the linesman raising his flag.\n\nTuchel and several players were incensed and strongly protested the decision.\n\nReplays show that there may not have been an offside and the linesman raised his flag early.\n\n\"We scored one, and it's a disastrous decision from the linesman and referee,\" the Bayern manager said.\n\n\"It feels almost like a betrayal in the end because of that decision.\n\n\"The linesman said sorry - that does not help. To raise the flag in a decision like this, in a close decision in the last minute.\n\n\"And the referee as well, the referee does not have to whistle. He sees that we win the second ball.\n\n\"To whistle, it's a very, very bad decision and it's against the rules. It's a bad decision from both of them, it's a disaster. Tough to swallow.\"\n\nThe call was naturally a point of conversation amongst TNT Sports pundits Owen Hargreaves and Paul Scholes in the post-match analysis.\n\n\"I think the linesman puts his flag up too early,\" said Scholes.\n\n\"It's close. I'm not sure they're offside. The linesman is too hasty, he's got to wait, they're the rules now.\"\n\n\"That's what we see all the time, we're always moaning about linesmen not putting up [the flag] - he's done it straight away.\n\n\"But once that flags gone up, they cannot give the goal.\"\n\nHargreaves chimed in, noting the feeling that Bayern's players will have felt in that moment.\n\nThat's why football is so beautiful but so awful at the same time. Those players will be so upset on what's been a really difficult season for Bayern Munich.\"\n\nBayern had one foot in the final when Alphonso Davies scored in the 68th minute, cutting inside and firing past Andriy Lunin thanks to a superb pass from Kane.\n\nIn typical Madrid fashion, the Spanish giants hit Bayern with a quick one-two as former Stoke City striker Joselu grabbed a brace.\n\nThe Spaniard scored an 88th-minute equaliser when he reacted quickly after Bayern goalkeeper Manuel Neuer fumbled Vinicius Jr's effort.\n\nHe popped up two minutes later with the winner, latching onto Antonio Rudiger's pass across the box.\n\nThen 12 minutes later the offside situation occurred, confirming Bayern's first trophyless season since 2011-12, and leaving Harry Kane still hunting for his {"uri": "2024-05-349936567", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "08:13:41", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T08:13:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T07:47:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://inews.co.uk/sport/football/offside-betrayal-bayern-out-champions-league-3047508", "title": "Why Bayern are right to feel 'betrayed' by linesman's offside call", "body": "Matthijs de Ligt appeared to have scored a dramatic equaliser in the 13th minute of added-time after former Stoke City striker Joselu's late brace had turned the tie on its head.\n\nYet referee Szymon Marciniak blew his whistle to stop play before De Ligt took the shot after the linesman had flagged for offside against the Dutchman and Noussair Mazraoui.\n\nThis appeared to go against the guidance now provided to officials on how to handle offside calls when Video Assistant Referee (VAR) is in use.\n\nHere's what Tuchel had to say, an explanation of the current offside rule and refereeing guidance on how to handle offsides and 's view on whether Bayern would have scored had the whistle not been blown.\n\nWhat did Thomas Tuchel say about the offside 'betrayal'?\n\nTuchel was visibly furious at the end of the game, haranguing the fourth official while his players targeted Marciniak.\n\nAnd his anger continued after the game, saying in his post-match press conference: \"I think it is pretty clear - and it can't be any other opinion - that it's against every rule in modern football, what happened.\n\n\"The first big mistake is from the linesman. He raised the flag in a situation like this where you can never, never be sure it's offside. To have the guts to raise the flag is a huge, huge call and it's the wrong call. The referee has the chance not to whistle when we win the second ball and get a shot away within five seconds. He takes the decision to whistle and it's against every rule.\"\n\nAnd speaking on TNT Sports, the German said: \"That was an absolute disaster. A violation of the rules.\n\n\"This scene must be played out to the end. That's the rule. The linesman made the mistake, and the referee made the second mistake.\n\n\"We were almost there and a very unusual mistake of the best player [Manuel Neuer] for the equaliser, then we conceded in a very narrow decision in stoppage time. Then we scored one and it was a disastrous decision from the linesman and the referee, so it feels almost like a betrayal in the end because of that decision.\"\n\nHe continued: \"The linesman said sorry. That does not help at that kind of level, to raise the flag in a decision like this, in a close decision in the last minute. The referee as well, he does not have to whistle, he sees that we win the second ball, he sees that we get the shot away. To whistle is a very, very bad decision.\n\n\"It is against the rules and it is a bad decision from both of them. It is a disaster, tough to swallow, but it is the way it is.\"\n\nWhat is Uefa's rule on delaying the offside flag?\n\nAccording to guidance from Ifab - the governing body of football's laws - on adjudicating offsides when VAR is in use, assistant referees can delay raising the flag in clear attacking situations, allowing play to continue. The regulations read:\n\nThis aligns with guidance provided by Uefa's chief refereeing officer Roberto Rosetti in January 2023: \"We need the assistant referees to show their traditional abilities from the past. Accuracy, precision in offside evaluation. But timing is now an essential element of the job - they must know when to raise the flag.\n\n\"If they raise the flag at the wrong moment, problems can arise as far as the final decision is concerned. We've worked hard on the 'flag delay' concept.\"\n\nSimilar guidance has been in place in the Premier League since the start of the 2020-21 season, with former referee Chris Foy explaining: \"When an immediate goalscoring opportunity is likely to occur, the assistant referee will keep their flag down if they think there is an offside until the passage of play is completed.\n\n\"Once a goal is scored or the chance is gone, the assistant will raise the flag to indicate the initial offence. If a goal is scored, the VAR will review the offside call.\"\n\nWould Bayern have scored had the flag not been raised?\n\nWhile Bayern players and fans would probably maintain they would have scored had the referee decided to delay raising his flag, the reality is less clear.\n\nMarciniak blew his whistle as Thomas Muller headed the ball towards De Ligt, which appears to have distracted the Real Madrid defenders and goalkeeper Andriy Lunin, causing them to stop competing for the ball fractionally before the Dutchman takes the shot.\n\nIt is unclear whether he would have had such a simple shot on goal had the referee not blown his whistle to stop play at that point, which may well have resulted in his effort being blocked or saved.\n\nBut what is obvious is that the assistant referee should not have raised his flag as early as he did, even though VAR may have eventually agreed with his offside call.\n\nThe guidance and regulations clearly state he should have allowed play to continue in this goalscoring opportunity and then raised his flag once that phase of play had ended, whether that was with a goal or not.", "source": {"uri": "inews.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8118551741", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "06:01:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T06:01:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T06:00:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.westmeathindependent.ie/2024/05/09/thomas-tuchel-fumes-at-disastrous-decision-to-rule-out-late-bayern-chance/", "title": "Thomas Tuchel fumes at 'disastrous decision' to rule out late Bayern chance | Westmeath Independent", "body": "Thomas Tuchel fumes at 'disastrous decision' to rule out late Bayern chance RSS Syndicated Content Published: Thu 9 May 2024, 6:35 AM Last updated: Thu 9 May 2024, 6:58 AM\n\nBy George Sessions, PA\n\nThomas Tuchel vented his frustration at the \"disastrous decision\" to rule out a potential Matthijs de Ligt equaliser after Bayern Munich missed out on the Champions League final following a 4-3 aggregate loss to Real Madrid.\n\nThe last-four tie had been evenly-poised after a 2-2 draw in Germany last week and Alphonso Davies fired the visitors into a surprise lead with 22 minutes left at the Santiago Bernabeu.\n\nBayern looked on course to end Madrid's 13-month unbeaten home run, but Joselu levelled in the 88th minute after Manuel Neuer spilled a shot by Vinicius Junior before the former Stoke forward steered home from close range three minutes later to earn a memorable 2-1 victory.\n\nThe goal was originally ruled out after the offside flag was raised, but VAR told Szymon Marciniak to review the incident and both Joselu and defender-turned-assist-maker Antonio Rudiger were onside.\n\nFurther drama occurred in the 13th minute of stoppage time when referee Marciniak blew his whistle, upon the offside flag being raised, just before De Ligt fired into the bottom corner after a Joshua Kimmich pass forced a scramble in the Madrid box.\n\nBayern remonstrated with the officials, but to no avail as the German giants and England captain Harry Kane were consigned to a trophyless season.\n\n\"We were almost through, almost there and had a very unusual mistake by our very best player for the equaliser,\" Tuchel told TNT Sports.\n\n\"Then we conceded in a very narrow decision, the second one in stoppage time. Then we scored one and they have a disastrous decision from the linesman and from the referee.\n\n\"So, it feels almost like a betrayal in the end because of that decision. It was a huge fight, we left everything on the pitch and we were almost there. Now we have to say congratulations to Real Madrid.\n\n\"The linesman said sorry, but that does not help. At that kind of level, to raise the flag in a decision like this, a close decision, in the last minute and the referee as well.\n\n\"The referee does not have to whistle. He sees that we win the second ball, he sees that we get a shot away and to whistle is a very, very bad decision.\n\n\"And it is against the rules and it is a bad decision from both of them. It is a disaster. Tough to swallow, but that is the way it is.\"\n\nAn intriguing subplot was Kane up against compatriot Jude Bellingham, who produced an all-action display and helped set up a Wembley showdown with old club Borussia Dortmund on June 1.\n\nIt was a different story for Kane after this loss extended his wait for silverware, and Tuchel made the surprise decision to replace the former Tottenham forward in the 85th minute with Bayern leading.\n\nWhile Tuchel was not asked specifically about Kane being taken off, he said: \"Part of the story is we start with a front four and all four players need to {"uri": "8118895736", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "09:57:31", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T09:57:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T09:56:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://newsable.asianetnews.com/sports/football-champions-league-2023-24-new-angle-of-critical-offside-incident-in-real-madrid-vs-bayer-munich-clash-revealed-snt-sd7q3k", "title": "Champions League 2023-24: New angle of controversial offside incident in Real Madrid vs Bayern clash revealed", "body": "A fresh perspective on the contentious offside incident during the Champions League semi-final clash on Wednesday has surfaced, amplifying the controversy surrounding Bayern Munich's denied late equalizer against Real Madrid.\n\nA fresh perspective on the contentious offside incident during the Champions League semi-final clash on Wednesday has surfaced, amplifying the controversy surrounding Bayern Munich's denied late equalizer against Real Madrid - a call that Thomas Tuchel labelled as \"an absolute disaster.\"\n\nIn a pulsating atmosphere at the Santiago Bernabeu, the hosts orchestrated a late comeback to clinch a 2-1 victory on the night, courtesy of Joselu's brace, sealing a 4-3 aggregate triumph. Their winning momentum was bolstered by a glaring error from Bayern keeper Manuel Neuer.\n\nAmidst the drama, Bayern managed to level the scoreline in stoppage time through Matthijs de Ligt. However, jubilation turned to dismay as the goal was disallowed due to Noussair Mazraoui being adjudged offside. With the assistant referee's flag halting play, VAR was unable to intervene, highlighting a procedural oversight. Consequently, the crucial goal was nullified, much to Bayern's chagrin.\n\nFollowing the match, beIN Sports revealed an angle indicating that Mazraoui was, in fact, onside during the build-up to de Ligt's goal. This revelation, circulated on X (formerly Twitter), suggests that the effort should have stood if play had been permitted to continue.\n\nThe aftermath left Bayern manager Tuchel visibly shaken, reportedly on the brink of tears. The controversial call loomed large in his post-match emotions, serving as the focal point of his frustration following their Champions League exit.\n\n\"This is a disaster, Toni's (Antonio Rudiger) leg is probably deeper than Mazraoui. It's an absolute disaster,\" the Bayern boss said in an interview with DAZN.\n\n\"Imagine if Real Madrid let them keep running when they score their second goal. It would have been the same, the ball goes to Toni and the whistle is blown. The situation must be played out to the end. That's the rule. Especially when she's so close to the gate. Especially when it's so tight,\" Tuchel added.\n\n\"The assistant makes the first mistake, the referee makes the second mistake. He doesn't have to whistle, he can just wait and see. That's what happened with the second goal. This is a violation of the rules,\" he added.\n\nOfficials are typically encouraged to hold off on making offside calls until the conclusion of the attacking phase, providing a chance to correct potential errors. However, the reasons for this standard not being adhered to in Madrid remain unclear.\n\nIn an interview with TNT Sports, Tuchel disclosed that the assistant referee had personally apologized to him for raising the flag prematurely in a sequence that could have altered the outcome of the game for his team.\n\n\"If it's offside, it's offside. But I think we made rules in football and the rules are if's not a clear offside - which it wasn't because I don't see it yet if it's offside or not - you have to keep playing. If you go in the last minutes and you whistle like this, I think it's a big mistake. If it's offside or not you can check it, but if you don't check it, how can you see it?\" Tuchel said.\n\n\"The second goal Rudiger is almost offside. If he whistles ok, but now there's a difference and this is a shame. The linesman said to me I'm sorry, I made a mistake, I can't buy anything for that. 'm not the type of person who wants to blame a loss or win on the referee but it means you have to win because you win 2-1. I think if it's a rule, it's a rule,\" the Bayern manager added.\n\nPaul Scholes weighed in on the controversy, suggesting that the linesman acted hastily in raising his flag. During his commentary on TNT Sports, Scholes remarked, \"I'm not sure it's offside. For the linesman to put his flag up... he's too hasty. He's got to wait.\"\n\nLooking ahead, Real Madrid will square off against Bayern's Bundesliga counterparts, Borussia Dortmund, in the upcoming Champions League final at Wembley Stadium next month.", {"uri": "8118141335", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "22:25:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T22:25:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T22:24:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.cbssports.com/soccer/news/champions-league-rules-expert-explains-game-changing-errors-in-real-madrids-comeback-over-bayern-munich/", "title": "Champions League: Rules expert explains game-changing 'errors' in Real Madrid's comeback over Bayern Munich - CBSSports.com", "body": "The fallout from the linesman blowing his whistle early and wiping out what would've been a Matthijs de Ligt goal for Bayern Getty Images\n\nIn one of the most epic Champions League semifinals in recent memory, Real Madrid produced another late UCL comeback, scoring twice in the final minutes to beat Bayern Munich 2-1 at the Santiago Bernabeu. It was Joselu who came off the bench for a brace, seeing the Spanish club advance 4-3 on aggregate, and they'll take on Dortmund in the final on June 1.\n\nBut it wasn't without massive controversy.\n\nAs Bayern pushed forward in need of an equalizer to force extra time, defender Matthijs de Ligt found the back of the net with a brilliantly struck low shot from inside of the box. The only problem? The assistant referee put his flag up and called offside on the long ball preceding the Dutch defender's shot. De Ligt and teammate Noussair Mazraoui went up for a long ball into the box and appeared onside. Instead of keeping his flag down and letting the play continue, the assistant referee called the offside, the ref whistled it, and the play was called dead. That meant that it could not be reviewed as Real Madrid players stopped playing before the shot went off.\n\nDe Ligt and Bayern Munich manager Thomas Tuchel said the assistant referee apologized after the match with the coach calling it \"disastrous\" and \"like betrayal\" in an interview with TNT Sports.\n\nCBS Sports rule analyst Christina Unkel broke down the controversy on the Champions League Today Post-Match show and said there were multiple mistakes by the crew of Szymon Marciniak, Tomasz Listkiewicz and Adam Kupsik:\n\n\"Unfortunately, there are two officiating errors that occur here,\" Unkel said.\n\n\"Here, he [Mazraoui] is not in an offside position, so we don't even have to get into discussion about whether he interfered with play. But, we have the first error by the assistant referee in raising that flag, which goes against the direction of holding that flag, especially where the attacking phase of play and it has not yet finished. And then we have the second error by the referee in accepting that recommendation by the assistant referee and blowing his whistle instead of saying, 'Thank you, I see you. I'm going to hold my whistle until this play goes out.' And this is very surprising. This isn't some of the best in Europe, this actually would be considered the best [refereeing crew] in Europe. This Polish trio, having refereed Champions League final, having just done the men's World Cup final. It was a very surprising decision by both the assistant referee and the referee which goes to an oversight in detail and attention at these critical moments.\n\n\"So it was not a good day for the third team today. \"\n\nUnkel went on to say that we could possibly see them punished in terms of future assignments of big games.\n\n\"It's never a good day when the discussion truly is about a clear, critical error by the refereeing crew. As we know, we call these key match incidents, game-changing decisions ... It doesn't sit well, not just only for that officiating crew naturally, but it doesn't sit well for the whole referee community, especially when we have three different layers of technology that can prevent us from making these types of mistakes,\" she said.", "source": {"uri": "cbssports.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CBS Sports"}, "authors": [{"uri": "roger_gonzalez@cbssports.com", "name": {"uri": "2024-05-349993791", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "09:07:46", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T09:07:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T08:51:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/uefa-thomas-tuchel-matthijs-de-ligt-bayern-munich-real-madrid-b2542120.html", "title": "No comment from UEFA as Thomas Tuchel rails at 'disastrous decision'", "body": "Polish referee Szymon Marciniak blew his whistle after one of his assistants raised an offside flag, moments before Matthijs de Ligt struck what would have been an equaliser for the German side.\n\nVAR could not make a call on whether the goal should stand or not because play had been stopped, and there is also the question of whether De Ligt would even have scored if Real's defence had not stopped for the whistle.\n\nHowever, Tuchel took no comfort from that as his side blew the lead given to them midway through the second half by Alphonso Davies.\n\n\"They have a disastrous decision from the linesman and from the referee,\" he told TNT Sports.\n\n\"So, it feels almost like a betrayal in the end because of that decision. It was a huge fight, we left everything on the pitch and we were almost there. Now we have to say congratulations to Real Madrid.\n\n\"The linesman said sorry, but that does not help. At that kind of level, to raise the flag in a decision like this, a close decision, in the last minute - and the referee as well.\n\n\"The referee does not have to whistle. He sees that we win the second ball, he sees that we get a shot away and to whistle is a very, very bad decision.\n\n\"And it is against the rules and it is a bad decision from both of them. It is a disaster. Tough to swallow, but that is the way it is.\"\n\nWhile there has been no clarification or comment from UEFA, the officials could point to the VAR protocols published by the International Football Association Board, which state that an assistant referee's offside flag should only be delayed \"in a very clear attacking situation when a player is about to score a goal or has a clear run into/towards the opponents' penalty area\".\n\nTwo goals from Joselu helped Real recover from a goal down to win 4-3 on aggregate. They will now go on to face Borussia Dortmund in the final at Wembley on June 1.\n\nEnglish officials Michael Oliver and Anthony Taylor - both highly regarded by UEFA - could be in contention to referee the match. Start Your Free Trial Today >\n\nBut Bayern collapsed amid a host of questionable substitutions as Real Madrid roared back to claim a sensational fightback victory thanks to two goals in three minutes from their own substitute Joselu.\n\nAfter a Madrid equaliser from a corner was ruled out due to a clear Nacho foul on Joshua Kimmich in the box, legendary Munich goalkeeper Manuel Neuer - who had been excellent up to that point - spilt a regulation Vinicius Jnr shot straight to the feet of Joselu to poke home in the 88th minute.\n\n\"(Before that) there were world class saves after world class saves, but that can happen, it's football,\" said Bayern defender Matthijs de Ligt.\n\nThree minutes later the unheralded Spanish striker had the ball in the back of the net again after a cross from Antonio Rudiger, but it was ruled out for offside - only to be correctly overturned by VAR, sparking jubilant scenes at the Santiago Bernabeu.\n\nBayern Munich - having surprisingly substituted many of their best players including Leroy Sane, Jamail Musiala and Harry Kane in a defensive-minded bid to hold on to their lead - nearly scored a leveller deep in stoppage time when Matthijs de Ligt poked home from a long ball.\n\nBut the referee had already blown the whistle for offside, meaning VAR could not check or overturn the offside call. It was unclear whether a Munich player was indeed offside in the play, but the referee's decision to blow the whistle and not let play continue was nevertheless a significant mistake.\n\nThe decision incensed Munich players and coaches, as their nightmare season took another dismal turn when the final whistle blew to seal a 4-3 aggregate defeat.\n\n\"I don't want to say that it's always the referee's mistake with Real Madrid, but that made the difference today,\" said De Ligt.\n\nHe added to BeIN Sport: \"It's a big, big mistake, and a big disgrace... the linesman said to me 'I'm sorry. I made a mistake'.\"\n\nCoach Tuchel - who earned a yellow card earlier in the second half for protesting at the referee - was equally incensed, saying: \"It was a disaster. An absolute disaster and it's clear violation of the rules.\n\n\"The clear rule is that the scene must continue. The first mistake was made by the linesman, the second by the referee\".\n\nMadrid will now face Dortmund, who beat French giants PSG yesterday, in the final on June 1 at Wembley.\n\n\"That's one of He played with back pain and he couldn't keep going, his back froze up,\" said Tuchel.\n\nThe loss means Harry Kane's long wait for a trophy continues, with the 30-year-old striker still yet to lift silverware in his club career.\n\n'Absolute disaster'\n\nThomas Tuchel slammed a late offside call, calling the decision an \"absolute disaster\" as Real Madrid eliminated his side in the Champions League semi-finals on Wednesday.\n\nWith Real 2-1 up having come from behind with two late goals, Joshua Kimmich put in a long pass which was headed centrally by Thomas Mueller for defender Matthijs de Ligt to score in the 12th minute of stoppage time.\n\nReal, who drew the Munich tie 2-2, went through 4-3 on aggregate.\n\nThe goal did not stand after the linesman raised his flag earlier in the move before the ball went in the net, therefore ruling out a VAR review.\n\nAn animated Tuchel ran down the sideline after the decision. After the match, he told broadcaster DAZN the decision was \"a disaster, an absolute disaster\".\n\n\"We have to let the action play out until the end. That's the rule, especially since it's so close to the goal, and it's so limited.\n\n\"The first error is made by the linesman, the second comes from the referee,\" Tuchel said.\n\nThe 50-year-old coach told broadcaster TNT the decision \"felt like a betrayal\".\n\nSpeaking at the press conference, Tuchel said the referee apologised but added: \"It doesn't help to say sorry.\n\n\"Everyone has to go to their limit, everyone has to suffer, everyone has to play without making mistakes. So the referee has to be at that level too.\n\n\"It just doesn't help to make excuses after the fact.\n\n\"You are on the field for this reason, because you are the best there is. And we have the right to expect that until the end.\"\n\nThe goalscorer De Ligt agreed with his coach, calling the decision decisive in the match.\n\n\"The scene at the end, I find it incredible. I can't understand why he (the referee) doesn't let the action play out.\n\n\"He apologised. I wouldn't want to say that Real are always lucky, but that decision makes the difference today,\" De Ligt told DAZN.\n\nA disappointed Bayern captain Manuel Neuer said: \"We're in the Champions League semi-finals... {"uri": "8118641974", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "07:09:44", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T07:09:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T07:09:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.wionews.com/football/absolute-disaster-thomas-tuchel-fumes-over-bayerns-late-disallowed-goal-against-madrid-719645", "title": "'Absolute disaster': Thomas Tuchel fumes over Bayern's late disallowed goal against Madrid", "body": "The linesman had raised the offside flag much before the shot from De Ligt went in, prompting the referee to blow the whsitle, signaling a stop in play\n\nThomas Tuchel was left fuming, claiming it \"felt like a betrayal\" after Bayern Munich were denied a stoppage time equaliser against Real Madrid in the second leg of the Champions League semifinal on Wednesday (May 8).\n\nHaving blown away a one goal lead against Madrid, Bayern leveled proceedings in the dying seconds of the game, courtesy of a tidy finish from Mathejis de Ligt. However, the linesman had raised the offside flag much before the shot went in, prompting the referee to blow the whsitle, signaling a stop in play.\n\n\"I think it's pretty clear and there is no doubt that is against the rules of modern football. A disaster. An absolute disaster,\" Bayern coach Thomas Tuchel said.\n\n\"With Real's second goal, they let the play continue. The clear rule is that the scene must continue. The first mistake was made by the linesman, the second by the referee,\" he said.\n\n\"Very difficult. Of course as sportspeople we accept it,\" said Tuchel. \"But it is a semi-final, it's not for two such violations of the rule. Everyone has to be at their limit. The referees have to be there as well. That is what we expect. So the apology does not really help.\"\n\nDespite dominating the match in front of a boisterous Bernabeau crowd, it was visitors that took the lead in the 68th minute against Madrid.\n\nAlphonso Davies, who was substituted in the first half in place of an injured Serge Gnabry, made a darting run across the field as Madrid were caught on a counterattack. Harry Kane held up the ball beautifully in the centre before pinging it straight to Davies.\n\nThe Canadian tool the ball in control, chopped onto his weaker, right foot and curled one past a diving Lunin into the far post.\n\nHaving got the advantage, Bayern formed a low block, forcing Carlo Ancelotti to bring Luka Modric, Brahim Diaz and Joselu onto the pitch.\n\nIn the 88th minute, Madrid
