{"uri": "2024-05-349658394", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "02:00:11", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T02:00:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T01:06:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.mykhel.com/football/tuchel-champions-league-semi-final-defeat-tough-to-accept-280901.html", "title": "Tuchel: Champions League semi-final defeat 'tough to accept'", "body": "Thomas Tuchel reflects on \"tough to accept\" defeat after Real Madrid came from behind to win 2-1 and knock Bayern Munich out of the Champions League on Wednesday.\n\nAfter a 2-2 draw in the first leg of the semi-final at the Allianz Arena, Bayern took the lead in the 68th minute through Alphonso Davies.\n\nHowever, Joselu came off the bench to score twice in three minutes to send the LaLiga champions to the Champions League final with a 4-3 aggregate win over Bayern.\n\n\"It hurts. It'll take a while to recover, but on the one hand, it's a loss where we left it all out on the pitch,\" Tuchel told DAZN after the game.\n\n\"Of course, it's tough to accept. It's part of reality. No regrets. But on the other, there were too many injuries, a few too many substitutions, too many cramps.\n\n\"We started with a front four and by the end they were all off the pitch. And then Manu, who had been exceptional in saving us all night, made a mistake he wouldn't make in another 100 years.\"\n\nIn stoppage time, Matthijs de Ligt had the ball in the back of the net, but the referee had already blown his whistle after the linesman raised his flag, so VAR could not intervene.\n\nThe replays showed that the original decision was closer than first thought, and Tuchel was frustrated with how the situation was handled.\n\nSpeaking to TNT Sports, Tuchel said: \"We are almost through, it's almost there and there was a very unusual mistake from our best player for the equaliser, then we conceded the second one in stoppage time.\n\n\"Then we scored one and there was a disastrous decision from the linesman and the referee. It feels like a betrayal in the end. There was a huge fight, we left everything on the pitch, and we were almost there. Now we say congratulations to Real Madrid.\n\n\"The linesman says sorry, but that does not help. To raise the flag in a moment like this... The referee sees we get the second ball, and we get the shot - it's a very, very bad decision. It's against the rules. It's a disaster. It's hard to swallow, but that's the way it is.\"\n\nManuel Neuer made five saves in the game and looked equal to Madrid's threat until he spilled the ball in the build-up to Joselu's first goal.\n\n\"Anyone who's ever played football knows how I'm feeling right now,\" he told DAZN.\n\n\"That we've been knocked out in the closing stages, having led 1-0 until the 88th minute, it's extremely bitter.\n\n\"We'd taken one step to London; we saw ourselves in the final, and now I'm lost for words.\"", "source": {"uri": "mykhel.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "myKhel.com"}, {"uri": "8118344037", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "02:38:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T02:38:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T02:34:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.indiatoday.in/sports/football/story/champions-league-real-madrid-stun-bayern-munich-with-late-fightback-to-reach-final-2536899-2024-05-09", "title": "Champions League: Real Madrid stun Bayern Munich with late fightback to reach final", "body": "Real Madrid set to contest for UCL 15th title vs Borussia Dortmund on June 1\n\nReal Madrid showed they remain Europe's comeback kings as Joselu's late double rescued them from the brink of elimination to reach the Champions League final with a dramatic 2-1 second-leg win over Bayern Munich at Santiago Bernabeu on Wednesday. A 4-3 aggregate victory sealed Real's progress to a remarkable sixth Champions League final in 10 years and they will bid for a record-extending 15th title against Borussia Dortmund at Wembley on June 1.\n\nIn a repeat of their spectacular semi-final comeback win over Manchester City two years ago, they saw their opponents take the lead after Bayern substitute Alphonso Davies fired home a stunning strike from a counterattack in the 68th minute. But Joselu climbed off the bench to equalise following a calamitous error from Manuel Neuer in the 88th minute and, two minutes later, he shinned a second into the Bayern goal from a cross by Antonio Rudiger.\n\nThe effort was first ruled out for an apparent offside, but the goal was given following a VAR check. \"We've seen it a lot of times this season when it looked as though we're dead and buried ... it doesn't matter who scores the goals but someone always manages it... that mentality of never say die,\" Jude Bellingham, who will play against his former club in the final, told TNT Sports.\n\nReal dominated proceedings, but misfired on several chances as a gritty Bayern put their domestic woes aside to almost eliminate the Spaniards in their own back yard. Davies, who came off the bench early in the first half in place of injured Serge Gnabry, opened the scoring in spectacular fashion, cutting back on his right foot and curling an unstoppable bullet of a shot into the far corner on a counter-attack.\n\nNEUER FUMBLE\n\nBut Real, who were the better side throughout the game, piled on the pressure with Vinicius Jr tormenting the visitors down the left channel. The Brazilian glided past Matthijs De Ligt and Joshua Kimmich effortlessly and created a number chances for himself and his team mates, who were denied several times by an inspired Neuer.\n\nThe Bayern keeper looked on course to be man of the match as he weathered a storm, but with minutes remaining he fumbled a Vinicius strike from the edge of the box to gift Joselu the equaliser. The goal recharged a raucous Santiago Bernabeu under their spectacular new roof and two minutes later Real worked their European magic again, snatching a deserved winner that fired the Spanish giants into another final.\n\nBayern made a late push for an equaliser which they thought they had found when defender De Ligt rifled the ball home deep in added time. But play had already been stopped after the linesman flagged for a debatable offside in the build-up, leading Bayern's players and bench to complain vociferously to the referee and his assistants.\n\n\"We all know the rules and it's clear that, if it's not an obvious offside, you have to let it play. It was a disgraceful call,\" De Ligt said. With Bayer Leverkusen ending Bayern's 11-year Bundesliga reign by securing the league title last month, the six-times European Cup winners had only one trophy left to fight for this season.\n\n\"We are almost through, it's almost there and there was a very unusual mistake from our best player for the equaliser then we conceded the second one in stoppage time,\" Bayern boss Thomas Tuchel said. \"Then we scored one and there was a disastrous decision from the linesman and the referee. Davies fired home a stunning strike from a counter attack in the 68th minute.\n\nBut Joselu climbed off the bench to equalise following a calamitous error from Manuel Neuer in the 88th minute and, two {"uri": "8118921841", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "10:12:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T10:12:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T10:12:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/bayern-munich-realmadrid-offside-apology-32769404", "title": "Furious Bayern Munich chief slams officials' apology - \"We can't buy s***!\"", "body": "Bayern Munich chief Max Eberl has rubbished the apology from the officials after a potential equaliser for his side was ruled out against Real Madrid.\n\nBayern were knocked out 4-3 on aggregate in the Champions League semi-final second leg on Wednesday night in a dramatic 2-1 defeat. Alphonso Davies' strike had the German team ahead but Joselu scored a quickfire late double to turn things around.\n\nThere was controversy, though, with a possible injury-time equaliser by Matthijs de Ligt not allowed. The Bayern defender rifled in, but referee Szymon Marciniak had already blown the whistle, following an offside flag from his assistant Tomasz Listkiewicz against Noussair Mazraoui, who had challenged Ferland Mendy for a header.\n\nThe offside call was extremely tight and officials are instructed to keep their flag down in such situations. That protocol was followed at the other end when Antonio Rudiger crossed for what turned out to be Joselu's winner - with the flag only going up after the ball hit the net, allowing VAR to check - but De Ligt did not get the same courtesy.\n\nDON'T SCRAP REPLAYS!Join our petition to keep the magic of the FA Cup alive!\n\nBayern reacted furiously on the pitch at the time and after the final whistle and Thomas Tuchel said he felt \"betrayed\" by the call. De Ligt explained that Listkiewicz had apologised for the mistake, yet that admission had not helped cool the anger in the Bayern camp.\n\n\"There is nothing to explain. There is zero to explain. How many years has the VAR been around? For how many years has this offside rule been this way? This is already highly curious and dubious for me,\" Bayern's director of sport Eberl told reporters. \"He whistled, so no video assistant can intervene anymore because it was in front of the goal. The referee said it was his mistake. We can't buy s*** from that.\n\n\"Logically, this is a mistake. We all don't need [to check] the rules, we know exactly what it is. And if a situation is not yet finished, it is finished and then checked. Everyone was in favour [of an all-German final], only the Polish referees were not in favour, so I will keep my fingers crossed for BVB in the final.\"\n\nReferee Szymon Marciniak blew his whistle after seeing the offside flag\n\nHAVE YOUR SAY! What did you make of the decision? Comment below.\n\nDe Ligt explained what happened in the aftermath of the mistake. \"The linesman said to me I'm sorry, I made a mistake, I can't buy anything for that,\" he said. \"I'm not the type of person who wants to blame a loss or win on the referee but it means you have to win because you win 2-1. I think if it's a rule, it's a rule.\"\n\nBayern forward Thomas Muller hinted that the officials may have been influenced by the partisan crowd inside the Bernabeu. \"He whistled for offside, that means the VAR could no longer intervene,\" he told RMC Sport. \"The referee didn't go to the VAR. He didn't even have the opportunity to go see it. A situation like this is very strange, blowing the whistle so quickly. It happens a lot here in Madrid... I saw it a few years ago, with two goals from Cristiano Ronaldo, but that was before VAR.\"\n\nJoin our new WhatsApp community and receive your daily dose of Mirror Football content. {"uri": "8118623653", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "06:55:44", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T06:55:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T06:55:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.givemesport.com/rules-expert-explains-bayern-munich-disallowed-goal-vs-real-madrid/", "title": "Rules expert explains what happened with Bayern Munich's late disallowed goal vs Real Madrid", "body": "Former referee, Christina Unkel, has given her views on the controversial incident which saw a Bayern Munich goal disallowed vs Real Madrid.\n\nHighlights A rules analyst has explained the multiple errors that occurred as Bayern Munich were denied a late goal against Real Madrid in the Champions League. Matthijs de Ligt had the ball in the net, only to see the effort ruled out due to a controversial decision by the linesman to flag for offside. Two late Joselu goals sealed Real Madrid's place in the Champions League final against Borussia Dortmund at Wembley Stadium.\n\nA rules expert has explained the controversial decision which saw Matthijs de Ligt's late goal disallowed in the Champions League semi-final between Real Madrid and Bayern Munich, admitting several errors took place. The Spanish side progressed to the final - where they will meet Borussia Dortmund - after Joselu scored a quick-fire brace late in the game.\n\nThe tie was set up perfectly heading into the second leg, with the two European giants drawing 2-2 in the reverse fixture in Germany. The stage was set for the return clash at the Santiago Bernabeu, and the away side even took the lead against the run of play through an Alphonso Davies stunner. The left-back fired an effort into the far corner of the net with his weaker right foot to put the Germans in the driving seat.\n\nHowever, Manuel Neuer - who had been flawless until that point - would then spill the ball to the feet of Joselu in the 88th minute. The Newcastle United and Stoke City flop tucked the ball home before then adding his second of the game with a tap-in from Antonio Rudiger's cross just moments later. After a lengthy VAR check, the goal was awarded after initially being ruled out for offside.\n\nGIVEMESPORT Key Statistic: Carlo Ancelotti has never lost as a manager against Bayern Munich in 10 games.\n\nThe controversy in the match came when the visitors launched a late attack in the hopes of finding an equaliser. De Ligt had the ball in the net, although the Dutchman was denied by the offside flag, which was raised before the attack played out fully. This was despite the fact the margin for error was extremely slim.\n\nRelated Real Madrid 2-1 Bayern Munich: Player Ratings and Match Highlights The side from Spain enjoyed a late double from Joselu to book a spot in the Champions League final once again. Rules Expert Explains Offside Decision Christina Unkel admitted two mistakes occurred\n\nCBS Sports spoke to a former FIFA referee-turned-rules expert, Christina Unkel about the incident. The analyst told the panel of Thierry Henry, Micah Richards and Jamie Carragher: \"Here, he [Mazraoui] is not in an offside position, so we don't even have to get into discussion about whether he interfered with play. But we have the first error by the assistant referee in raising that flag, which goes against the direction of holding that flag, especially where the attacking phase of play and it has not yet finished. Then we have the second error by the referee in accepting that recommendation by the assistant referee and blowing his whistle instead of saying, 'Thank you, I see you. I'm going to hold my whistle until this play goes out.'\"\n\nWhile acknowledging the error, Unkel admitted: \"This is very surprising. This isn't some of the best in Europe, this actually would be considered the best [refereeing crew] in Europe.\" She then continued to say it was a sad state of affairs, adding:\n\n\"It's never a good day when the discussion truly is about a clear, critical error by the refereeing crew.\"\n\nRelated Why Rodrygo is Wearing 'Pray For RS' Shirt in Real Madrid v Bayern Munich Rodrygo was seen wearing a shirt that said 'Pray for RS' under his Real Madrid kit in the Champions League semi-final - here's why. Bayern Munich's Champions League Dreams End Thomas Tuchel will bow out in a trophyless campaign\n\nBayern Munich thought they'd done enough to set up a final against fellow Bundesliga side Borussia Dortmund when they took the lead in the Spanish capital. However, Thomas Tuchel's decision to substitute Harry Kane and Leroy Sane appeared detrimental as his team lost control from that point.\n\nThe German will depart at the end of the season without lifting any silverware this season, while Kane's wait for a major honour will continue beyond the club campaign. Tuchel and De Ligt claimed the linesman apologised for his error after the game, but this came too late to help the Bavarian outfit as they were already out of the competition.\n\nRelated The 15 best {"uri": "8118348354", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "02:40:04", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T02:40:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T02:39:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.chinadailyasia.com/hk/article/582730", "title": "Real Madrid stun Bayern with late fightback to reach Champions League final", "body": "MADRID - Real Madrid showed they remain Europe's comeback kings as Joselu's late double rescued them from the brink of elimination to reach the Champions League final with a dramatic 2-1 second-leg win over Bayern Munich at Santiago Bernabeu on Wednesday.\n\nA 4-3 aggregate victory sealed Real's progress to a remarkable sixth Champions League final in 10 years and they will bid for a record-extending 15th title against Borussia Dortmund at Wembley on June 1.\n\nIn a repeat of their spectacular semi-final comeback win over Manchester City two years ago, they saw their opponents take the lead after Bayern substitute Alphonso Davies fired home a stunning strike from a counter attack in the 68th minute.\n\nReal Madrid dominated proceedings, but misfired with several chances as a gritty Bayern Munich put their domestic woes aside to almost eliminate the Spaniards in their own back yard\n\nBut Joselu climbed off the bench to equalize following a calamitous error from Manuel Neuer in the 88th minute and, two minutes later, he shinned a second into the Bayern goal from a cross by Antonio Ruediger.\n\nThe effort was first ruled out for an apparent offside, but the goal was given following a VAR check.\n\n\"We've seen it a lot of times this season when it looked as though we're dead and buried ... it doesn't matter who scores the goals but someone always manages it... that mentality of never say die,\" Jude Bellingham, who will play against his former club in the final, told TNT Sports.\n\nALSO READ: Hummels on target as composed Dortmund knock PSG out to reach final\n\nReal dominated proceedings, but misfired with several chances as a gritty Bayern put their domestic woes aside to almost eliminate the Spaniards in their own back yard.\n\nDavies, who came off the bench early in the first half in place of injured Serge Gnabry, opened the scoring in spectacular fashion, cutting back on his right foot and curling an unstoppable bullet of a shot into the far corner on a counter-attack.\n\nNeuer fumble\n\nBut Real, who were the better side throughout the game, piled on the pressure with Vinicius Jr tormenting the visitors down the left channel.\n\nThe Brazilian glided past Matthijs De Ligt and Joshua Kimmich effortlessly and created a number chances for himself and his team mates, who were denied several times by an inspired Neuer.\n\nThe Bayern keeper looked on course to be man of the match as he weathered a storm, but with minutes remaining he fumbled a Vinicius strike from the edge of the box to gift Joselu the equalizer.\n\nThe goal recharged a raucous Santiago Bernabeu under their spectacular new roof and two minutes later Real worked their European magic again, snatching a deserved winner that fired the Spanish giants into another final.\n\nBayern made a late push for an equalizer which they thought they had found when defender De Ligt rifled the ball home deep in added time.\n\nBut play had already been stopped after the linesman flagged for a debatable offside in the build-up, leading Bayern's players and bench to complain vociferously to the referee and his assistants.\n\n\"We all know the rules and it's clear that, if it's not an obvious Madrid stun Bayern Munich", "body": "Madrid: Real Madrid showed they remain Europe's comeback kings as Joselu's late double rescued them from the brink of elimination to reach the UEFA Champions League (UCL) final with a dramatic 2-1 second-leg win over Bayern Munich at the Santiago Bernabeu on Wednesday.\n\nA 4-3 aggregate victory sealed Real's progress to a remarkable sixth Champions League final in 10 years and they will bid for a record-extending 15th title against Borussia Dortmund at Wembley on June 1.\n\nIn a repeat of their spectacular semifinal comeback win over Manchester City two years ago, they saw their opponents take the lead after Bayern substitute Alphonso Davies fired home a stunning strike from a counter attack in the 68th minute.\n\nBut Joselu climbed off the bench to equalise following a calamitous error from Manuel Neuer in the 88th minute and, two minutes later, he shinned a second into the Bayern goal from a cross by Antonio Ruediger.\n\nThe effort was first ruled out for an apparent offside, but the goal was given following a VAR check.\n\n\"We've seen it a lot of times this season when it looked as though we're dead and buried ... it doesn't matter who scores the goals but someone always manages it... that mentality of never say die,\" Jude Bellingham, who will play against his former club in the final, told TNT Sports.\n\nReal dominated proceedings, but misfired with several chances as a gritty Bayern put their domestic woes aside to almost eliminate the Spaniards in their own back yard.\n\nDavies, who came off the bench early in the first half in place of injured Serge Gnabry, opened the scoring in spectacular fashion, cutting back on his right foot and curling an unstoppable bullet of a shot into the far corner on a counter-attack.\n\nBut Real, who were the better side throughout the game, piled on the pressure with Vinicius Jr tormenting the visitors down the left channel.\n\nThe Brazilian glided past Matthijs De Ligt and Joshua Kimmich effortlessly and created a number chances for himself and his teammates, who were denied several times by an inspired Neuer.\n\nThe Bayern keeper looked on course to be man of the match as he weathered a storm, but with minutes remaining he fumbled a Vinicius strike from the edge of the box to gift Joselu the equaliser.\n\nThe goal recharged a raucous Santiago Bernabeu under their spectacular new roof and two minutes later Real worked their European magic again, snatching a deserved winner that fired the Spanish giants into another final.\n\nBayern made a late push for an equaliser which they thought they had found when defender De Ligt rifled the ball home deep in added time.\n\nBut play had already been stopped after the linesman flagged for a debatable offside in the build-up, leading Bayern's players and bench to complain vociferously to the referee and his assistants.\n\n\"We all know the rules and it's clear that, if it's not an obvious offside, you have to let it play. into Champions League final", "body": "THIS is the moment Antonio Rudiger kisses the VAR monitor following Real Madrid's controversial win over Bayern Munich.\n\nLos Blancos set up a Champions League final clash against Borussia Dortmund at Wembley with a dramatic 2-1 win on Wednesday.\n\nBayern went ahead with 20 minutes left thanks to an audacious strike from Alphonso Davies.\n\nBut after Thomas Tuchel went to a back five while taking off Leroy Sane, Jamal Musiala and Harry Kane, Real struck back.\n\nSub Joselu scored goals in the 88th and 91st minutes to turn the tie on its head and put Real on the cusp of a 15th European title.\n\nHowever, Bayern were left raging at the final whistle following a controversial moment at the death.\n\nAs the clock raced on during injury time, Matthijs de Ligt ended up putting the ball in the back of Real's net for 2-2.\n\nBizarrely, the linesman had already raised his flag for an offside moments before, technically bringing play to an end.\n\nBut replays suggested Bayern were not offside, and the linesman should never have raised his flag either until the phase of play had been completed.\n\nBecause of his actions, VAR refused to intervene as Bayern went beserk.\n\nBEST FREE BET SIGN UP OFFERS FOR UK BOOKMAKERS\n\nAnd some fans even accused Uefa of a \"fix\", with Thomas Tuchel claiming the decision was \"disastrous.\"\n\nBut Real star sure to enrage Bayern, Rudiger then went over to the VAR monitor before planting a big kiss on it.\n\nSpeaking afterwards, Bayern boss Tuchel lashed out at VAR and the linesman for their decision not to give the goal.\n\nHe said: \"There are two mistakes. The first big mistake is from the linesman.\n\n\"He raised his flag straight away; to raise your flag in a situation like this, you have to be very, very sure it's offside.\n\n\"To have the guts, the balls, to raise the flag like this is a huge, huge call, and it is the wrong call.\n\n\"We got the shot away within five seconds [of the flag] and the referee has the chance not to whistle, but he whistles. {"uri": "8119563510", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "17:36:58", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T17:36:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T17:36:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.omanobserver.om/article/1153500/sports/football/real-stun-bayern-with-late-fightback-to-reach-cl-final", "title": "Real stun Bayern with late fightback to reach CL final", "body": "* Bayern fume at offside decision in stoppage time\n\nMADRID: Real Madrid showed they remain Europe's comeback kings as Joselu's late double rescued them from the brink of elimination to reach the Champions League final with a dramatic 2-1 second-leg win over Bayern Munich at Santiago Bernabeu on Wednesday.\n\nA 4-3 aggregate victory sealed Real's progress to a remarkable sixth Champions League final in 10 years and they will bid for a record-extending 15th title against Borussia Dortmund at Wembley on June 1.\n\nIn a repeat of their spectacular semifinal comeback win over Manchester City two years ago, they saw their opponents take the lead after Bayern substitute Alphonso Davies fired home a stunning strike from a counter attack in the 68th minute.\n\nBut Joselu climbed off the bench to equalise following a calamitous error from Manuel Neuer in the 88th minute and, two minutes later, he shinned a second into the Bayern goal from a cross by Antonio Ruediger.\n\nThe effort was first ruled out for an apparent offside, but the goal was given following a VAR check.\n\n\"We've seen it a lot of times this season when it looked as though we're dead and buried ... it doesn't matter who scores the goals but someone always manages it... that mentality of never say die,\" Jude Bellingham, who will play against his former club in the final, told TNT Sports.\n\nReal dominated proceedings, but misfired with several chances as a gritty Bayern put their domestic woes aside to almost eliminate the Spaniards in their own back yard.\n\nDavies, who came off the bench early in the first half in place of injured Serge Gnabry, opened the scoring in spectacular fashion, cutting back on his right foot and curling an unstoppable bullet of a shot into the far corner on a counter-attack.\n\nNEUER FUMBLE\n\nBut Real, who were the better side throughout the game, piled on the pressure with Vinicius Jr tormenting the visitors down the left channel.\n\nThe Brazilian glided past Matthijs De Ligt and Joshua Kimmich effortlessly and created a number chances for himself and his team-mates, who were denied several times by an inspired Neuer.\n\nThe Bayern keeper looked on course to be man of the match as he weathered a storm, but with minutes remaining he fumbled a Vinicius strike from the edge of the box to gift Joselu the equaliser.\n\nThe goal recharged a raucous Santiago Bernabeu under their spectacular new roof and two minutes later Real worked their European magic again, snatching a deserved winner that fired the Spanish giants into another final.\n\nBayern made a late push for an equaliser which they thought they had found when defender De Ligt rifled the ball home deep in added time.\n\nBut play had already been stopped after the linesman flagged for a debatable offside in the build-up, leading Bayern's players and bench to complain vociferously to the referee and his assistants.\n\n\"We all know the rules and it's clear that, if it's not an obvious offside, you have to let it play. It was a disgraceful call,\" De Ligt said.\n\nWith Bayer Leverkusen ending Bayern's 11-year Bundesliga reign by securing the league title last month, the six-time European Cup winners had only one trophy left to fight for this season.\n\n\"We are almost through, it's almost there and there was a very unusual mistake from our best player for the equaliser then we conceded the second one in stoppage time,\" Bayern boss Thomas Tuchel said.\n\n\"Then we scored one and there was a disastrous decision from the linesman and the referee. An absolute disaster. With Real's second goal, they let the play continue. The clear rule is that the scene must continue. The first mistake was made by the linesman, the second by the referee,\" he said.\n\nBayern took the lead with Alphonso Davies' shot midway through the second half but Real battled back with two late goals from Joselu to book their final spot.\n\nDe Ligt said the linesman had apologised to him after the game.\n\n\"Very difficult. Of course as sportspeople we accept it,\" said Tuchel. \"But it is a semi-final, it's not for two such violations of the rule. Everyone has to be at their limit. The referees have to be there as well.\"\n\n\"That is what we expect. So the apology does not really help.\"\n\nBayern keeper Manuel Neuer spilled the ball into Joselu's path for the equaliser in the 88th minute but Tuchel did not want to blame his keeper who had been outstanding up to that point.\n\n\"Ninety-nine out of 100 times he makes it. No-one will point a finger at him and he is the most unhappy one,\" said the coach.\n\nReal progressed to their sixth Champions League final in 10 years and will bid for a record-extending 15th title It was a huge fight, we left everything on the pitch and we were almost there. Now we have to say congratulations to Real Madrid.\n\n\"The linesman said sorry, but that does not help. At that kind of level, to raise the flag in a decision like this, a close decision, in the last minute - and the referee as well.\n\n\"The referee does not have to whistle. He sees that we win the second ball, he sees that we get a shot away and to whistle is a very, very bad decision.\n\n\"And it is against the rules and it is a bad decision from both of them. It is a disaster. Tough to swallow, but that is the way it is.\"\n\nWhile there has been no clarification or comment from Uefa, the officials could point to the VAR protocols published by the International Football Association Board, which state that an assistant referee's offside flag should only be delayed \"in a very clear attacking situation when a player is about to score a goal or has a clear run into/towards the opponents' penalty area\".\n\nTwo goals from Joselu helped Real recover from a goal down to win 4-3 on aggregate. They will now go on to face Borussia Dortmund in the final at Wembley on June 1st.\n\nRSS Syndicated Content Published: Thu 9 May 2024, 9:58 AM Last updated: Thu 9 May 2024, 10:17 AM", "source": has theory behind Bayern Munich offside decision that no-one has suggested", "body": "Paul Scholes has a theory behind Bayern Munich's disallowed equaliser that not many people have considered.\n\nOn Wednesday Real Madrid and Bayern Munich played out the second leg of their mouth-watering Champions League semi-final tie, and in terms of drama, it certainly didn't disappoint.\n\nBayern Munich appeared to be heading to the final at Wembley thanks to Alphonso Davies' wonder-strike, but 88th and 91st minute goals from Joselu produced yet another famous Real Madrid comeback.\n\nThere was still time for drama after the late goals, when Bayern thought they had snatched an equaliser in the 13th minute of injury-time.\n\nThe linesman raised his flag for offside as Noussair Mazraoui contested a long ball with Ferland Mendy, and referee Szymon Marciniak blew his whistle seconds before Matthijs de Ligt smashed home a would-be equaliser.\n\nMazraoui appeared to be onside, but VAR could not review the incident as the referee had already blown his whistle.\n\nBayern's player and coaching staff were furious, as current offside protocols dictate that officials let play continue until the attack is over, meaning VAR can then intervene if the incorrect decision is made on-field.\n\nPlenty of fans and pundits have sympathy with Bayern, but after the game, TNT Sports pundit Paul Scholes pointed something out that not many people have considered.\n\nThe former Manchester United midfielder admitted that the referee blew his whistle too early, but questioned whether De Ligt would have scored had goalkeeper Andriy Lunin not stopped playing.\n\nThe Madrid goalkeeper didn't even attempt to dive for De Ligt's shot as the referee had already blown.\n\n\"It's a great finish,\" Scholes said on TNT Sports, \"but I do think that the keeper stops. After the match, he told broadcaster DAZN the decision was \"a disaster, an absolute disaster\".\n\n\"We have to let the action play out until the end. That's the rule, especially since it's so close to the goal, and it's so limited.\n\n\"The first error is made by the linesman, the second comes from the referee,\" Tuchel said.\n\nThe 50-year-old coach told broadcaster TNT the decision \"felt like a betrayal\".\n\nSpeaking at the press conference, Tuchel said the referee apologised but added: \"It doesn't help to say sorry.\n\n\"Everyone has to go to their limit, everyone has to suffer, everyone has to play without making mistakes. So the referee has to be at that level too.\n\n\"It just doesn't help to make excuses after the fact.\n\n\"You are on the field for this reason, because you are the best there is. And we have the right to expect that until the end.\"\n\nThe goalscorer De Ligt agreed with his coach, calling the decision decisive in the match.\n\n\"The scene at the end, I find it incredible. The first big mistake is from the linesman. He raised his flag straight away; to raise your flag in a situation like this, you have to be very, very sure it's offside. To have the guts, the balls, to raise the flag like this is a huge, huge call, and it is the wrong call. We got the shot away within five seconds [of the flag] and the referee has the chance not to whistle, but he whistles. It is against every rule.\"\n\nTuchel added: \"We accept that we lost, it is what it is, but it should not have happened. It would not have happened at the other end. It is tough to swallow. I am really angry. If \u00adanyone did not deserve that it's Manuel.\"\n\nAncelotti took a different view. \"If they can complain about that we can complain about the goal Nacho had disallowed,\" he said, referring to a referral by the video assistant referee that ruled out an almost immediate equaliser after Bayern had taken the lead, for a push. \"It happened again: it has happened other times and it's inexplicable. It's something magical. We played well, we had chances, and then we had the strength not to lose our heads when they scored. We have completed a season that few expected.\"\n\nJude Bellingham, who will now face his old club Borussia Dortmund in the final, said: \"I don't think Joselu will be sleeping much tonight, he'll be useless in training tomorrow! The Englishman swapped Tottenham for Bayern Munich last summer, a team who hadn't gone trophyless in over a decade.\n\nIn the Bundesliga, Bayer Leverkusen simply refused to lose - running the gauntlet unbeaten (so far) to become the first team to pip Bayern to the post since the 11/12 season.\n\nREAD MORE: Cappuccino crazy Harry Kane and footballer's oddest diets - from ice cream to nan's eggs\n\nREAD MORE: 'Jude Bellingham is an insufferable ego maniac - how can fawning fans not see it'\n\nLeverkusen, a team who had never conquered Germany, have hit a golden vein of form, that's almost once in a generation, since Kane rocked up in Bavaria.\n\nThe cup competitions haven't gone much better - Bayern were beaten by RB Leipzig in the German Super Cup. And German football was stunned back in November when a 96th minute winner saw third-tier FC Saarbrucken dump Bayern out of the DFB-Pokal.\n\nWhat do you think of Harry Kane going the season trophyless? Let us know in the comments section\n\nWednesday night was the latest blow in Kane's trophy hunt, as Bayern were the latest side to fall on their sword at the Santiago Bernabeu.\n\nBayern had been the better side when Alphonso Davies whipped the ball past an outstretched Andriy Lunin. However, strange things happen on European nights in Madrid - and ex-Stoke City striker Joselu bagged a brace to spin the tie on its head.\n\nThe Bavarian giants had one last chance and, in the 12th minute of added time, the ball was launched into the Madrid box and headed down to centre-back Matthijs de Ligt.\n\nDe Ligt lashed the ball into the back of the net, but seconds beforehand the whistle was blown after the offside flag had been raised.\n\nBayern players were furious, with Thomas Tuchel barking at the fourth official while the players argued with the linesman. And tensions only continued to rise as replays showed the offside decision looked to an incredibly close call.\n\nIn this situation, VAR would normally intervene. However, as the referee blew his whistle before De Ligt scored, the play couldn't be reviewed.\n\nTuchel said after the game: \"We scored one and there was a disastrous decision from the linesman and the referee. It feels like a betrayal in the end.\n\n\"The linesman says sorry but that does not help. To raise the flag in a moment like this... The referee sees we get the second ball and we get the shot - it's a very, very bad decision. It's against the rules. It's a disaster. It's hard to swallow but that's the way it is.\"\n\nWhile a disappointed De Ligt told Movistar: \"I don't want to say that Real Madrid always has the referees with them but that made the difference today. Real, when you think they are dead, have a last breath... that is why they have 14 Champions Leagues.\"\n\nHe later added: \"The linesman told me: sorry, I made a mistake.\"\n\nKane's wait for a Bayern with late fightback to reach Champions League final", "body": "MADRID, May 9 -- Real Madrid showed they remain Europe's comeback kings as Joselu's late double rescued them from the brink of elimination to reach the Champions League final with a dramatic 2-1 second-leg win over Bayern Munich at Santiago Bernabeu today.\n\nA 4-3 aggregate victory sealed Real's progress to a remarkable sixth Champions League final in 10 years and they will bid for a record-extending 15th title against Borussia Dortmund at Wembley on June 1.\n\nIn a repeat of their spectacular semi-final comeback win over Manchester City two years ago, they saw their opponents take the lead after Bayern substitute Alphonso Davies fired home a stunning strike from a counter attack in the 68th minute.\n\nBut Joselu climbed off the bench to equalise following a calamitous error from Manuel Neuer in the 88th minute and, two minutes later, he shinned a second into the Bayern goal from a cross by Antonio Ruediger.\n\nThe effort was first ruled out for an apparent offside, but the goal was given following a VAR check.\n\n\"We've seen it a lot of times this season when it looked as though we're dead and buried ... it doesn't matter who scores the goals but someone always manages it... that mentality of never say die,\" Jude Bellingham, who will play against his former club in the final, told TNT Sports.\n\nReal dominated proceedings, but misfired with several chances as a gritty Bayern put their domestic woes aside to almost eliminate the Spaniards in their own back yard.\n\nDavies, who came off the bench early in the first half in place of injured Serge Gnabry, opened the scoring in spectacular fashion, cutting back on his right foot and curling an unstoppable bullet of a shot into the far corner on a counter-attack.\n\nNeuer fumble\n\nBut Real, who were the better side throughout the game, piled on the pressure with Vinicius Jr tormenting the visitors down the left channel.\n\nThe Brazilian glided past Matthijs De Ligt and Joshua Kimmich effortlessly and created a number chances for himself and his team mates, who were denied several times by an inspired Neuer.\n\nThe Bayern keeper looked on course to be man of the match as he weathered a storm, but with minutes remaining he fumbled a Vinicius strike from the edge of the box to gift Joselu the equaliser.\n\nThe goal recharged a raucous Santiago Bernabeu under their spectacular new roof and two minutes later Real worked their European magic again, snatching a deserved winner that fired the Spanish giants into another final.\n\nBayern made a late push for an equaliser which they thought they had found when defender De Ligt rifled the ball home deep in added time.\n\nBut play had already been stopped after the linesman flagged for a debatable offside in the build-up, leading Bayern's players and bench to complain vociferously to the referee and his assistants.\n\n\"We all know the rules and it's clear that, if it's not an obvious offside, you have to let it play. It was a disgraceful call,\" De Ligt said.\n\nWith Bayer Leverkusen ending Bayern's 11-year Bundesliga reign by securing the league title last month, the six-times European Cup winners had only one trophy left to fight for this season.\n\n\"We are almost through, it's almost there and there was a very unusual mistake from our best player for the equaliser then we conceded the second one in stoppage time,\" Bayern boss Thomas Tuchel said.\n\n\"Then we scored one and there was a disastrous decision from the linesman and the referee. {"uri": "8118784733", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "08:45:07", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T08:45:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T08:43:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.opinionnigeria.com/ucl-why-i-had-to-remove-kane-bayern-boss-tuchel-gives-reason-for-substitution/", "title": "UCL: Why i had to remove Kane  --  Bayern boss Tuchel gives reason for substitution - Opinion Nigeria", "body": "Harry Kane's substitution appeared to change the momentum of the match with Bayern in control but Tuchel told broadcaster DAZN the striker was unable to continue.\n\nWith six minutes remaining in Wednesday's Champions League semi-final loss to Real Madrid, Harry Kane was substituted off by Bayern Munich coach Thomas Tuchel, who gave an explanation for his decision, stating that the injured England captain \"could not continue\".\n\nWith Eric Maxim Choupo-Moting as a backup striker in place of Harry Kane, Tuchel gave Bayern a 1-0 lead and guaranteed a spot in the championship game.\n\nThe home team took the lead for the evening, winning 2-1 and 4-3 on aggregate, thanks to goals from German-born Madrid striker Joselu, who tied the score just four minutes later and added another in the second minute of injury time.\n\nThomas Mueller, a Bayern veteran, was substituted for Jamal Musiala by Tuchel.\n\nHarry Kane's substitution appeared to change the momentum of the match with Bayern in control but Tuchel told broadcaster DAZN the striker was unable to continue.\n\n\"He couldn't keep going. He played with back pain and he couldn't keep going, his back froze up,\" said Tuchel.\n\nThe loss means Harry Kane's long wait for a trophy continues, with the 30-year-old striker still yet to lift silverware in his club career.\n\n'Absolute disaster'\n\nThomas Tuchel slammed a late offside call, calling the decision an \"absolute disaster\" as Real Madrid eliminated his side in the Champions League semi-finals on Wednesday.\n\nWith Real 2-1 up having come from behind with two late goals, Joshua Kimmich put in a long pass which was headed centrally by Thomas Mueller for defender Matthijs de Ligt to score in the 12th minute of stoppage time.\n\nReal, who drew the Munich tie 2-2, went through 4-3 on aggregate.\n\nThe goal did not stand after the linesman raised his flag earlier in the move before the ball went in the net, therefore ruling out a VAR review.\n\nAn animated Tuchel ran down the sideline after the decision. After the match, he told broadcaster DAZN the decision was \"a disaster, an absolute disaster\".\n\n\"We have to let the action play out until the end. That's the rule, especially since it's so close to the goal, and it's so limited.\n\n\"The first error is made by the linesman, the second comes from the referee,\" Tuchel said.\n\nThe 50-year-old coach told broadcaster TNT the decision \"felt like a betrayal\".\n\nSpeaking at the press conference, Tuchel said the referee apologised but added: \"It doesn't help to say sorry.\n\n\"Everyone has to go to their limit, everyone has to suffer, everyone has to play without making mistakes. So the referee has to be at that level too.\n\n\"It just doesn't help to make excuses after the fact.\n\n\"You are on the field for this reason, because you are the best there is. And we have the right to expect that until the end.\"\n\nThe goalscorer De Ligt agreed with his coach, calling the decision decisive in the match.\n\n\"The scene at the end, I find it incredible. I can't understand why he (the referee) doesn't let the action play out.\n\n\"He apologised. I wouldn't want to say that Real are always lucky, but that decision makes the difference today,\" De Ligt told DAZN.\n\nA disappointed Bayern captain Manuel Neuer said: \"We're in the Champions League semi-finals... I think he knows it was a mistake and that you shouldn't make a decision like that so quickly.\"", "source": {"uri": "opinionnigeria.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Opinion Nigeria"}, "authors": Instead, they lost 2-1 in the match and 4-3 on aggregate across the two matches.\n\n\"We're also a bit angry because of the last decision to give offside and whistle the offside, which is not an offside. So that makes it very, very hard to swallow,\" said Bayern Munich head coach Thomas Tuchel.\n\n\"We were almost there. We had a big fight and okay, that's how it is. The first mistake is that he lifts the flag because he can never be sure that this is offside. Never. And the referee sees that we win the rebound and we get the chance to shoot and he whistles.\n\n\"So this is the second big mistake in one action. This is very, very hard to swallow because it feels that they got anxious in the last minute here.\"\n\nFormer Socceroos player and Stan Sport commentator Craig Foster said the wrong call was made but couldn't be reversed as the Real Madrid players had stopped contesting the ball.\n\n\"In a goal-scoring situation, he doesn't need to blow his whistle and he should let it go on,\" said Foster on Stan Sport's gameday coverage.\n\n\"I don't think he's off-side. Then what happens? The whistle goes, people stop, and now you score. So Bayern are incensed because they're saying 'Hang on a minute, you should go to VAR because we've scored it', which is true. The referee messed it up there. However, the problem is they think they're denied a goal. No, because Real Madrid aren't defending.\"\n\nFormer Premier League goalkeeper Mark Bosnich added, \"You don't raise your flag. If you're unsure, you don't raise your flag. Then we scored one and they have a disastrous decision from the linesman and from the referee.\n\n\"So, it feels almost like a betrayal in the end because of that decision. It was a huge fight, we left everything on the pitch and we were almost there. Now we have to say congratulations to Real Madrid.\n\n\"The linesman said sorry, but that does not help. At that kind of level, to raise the flag in a decision like this, a close decision, in the last minute and the referee as well.\n\n\"The referee does not have to whistle. He sees that we win the second ball, he sees that we get a shot away and to whistle is a very, very bad decision.\n\n\"And it is against the rules and it is a bad decision from both of them. club Borussia Dortmund on June 1.\n\nIt was a different story for Kane after this loss extended his wait for silverware, and Tuchel made the surprise decision to replace the former Tottenham forward {"uri": "8118788773", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "08:48:09", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T08:48:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T08:47:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/ancelotti-bayern-madrid-disallowed-goal-32767973", "title": "Ancelotti takes brutal swipe at Bayern star after offside 'goal' complaints", "body": "Matthijs de Ligt thought he had scored a late equaliser for Bayern Munich\n\nReal Madrid manager Carlo Ancelotti responded to complaints about Bayern Munich's disallowed equaliser in Wednesday's Champions League semi-final by accusing Joshua Kimmich of diving to get an earlier Madrid goal chalked off.\n\nAncelotti's team thought they'd equalised moments after going behind, after pinball in the Bayern box. However, captain Nacho was penalised for a push on Kimmich in the build-up.\n\nIt didn't end up mattering for Los Blancos, who completed a dramatic late turnaround when substitute Joselu scored twice in three minutes. There was still time for Bayern to put the ball in the back of the net, but the whistle had blown for offside before Matthijs de Ligt fired into Andriy Lunin's net.\n\nDe Ligt claimed the referee's assistant apologised to him after the disallowed goal. However, speaking after the game, Ancelotti turned his focus to the contentious incident at the other end.\n\n\"Bayern complained about the offside? Ok, so we complain about the cancelled goal of Nacho... because Kimmich dived,\" Ancelotti said.\n\n\"If they complain about that, then we can complain about our disallowed goal. Both players were pushing each other and it's Nacho who gets penalised.\"\n\nHis opposite number Tuchel brought up the late disallowed goal in his own post-match interview. However he also recognised the part played by goalkeeper Manuel Neuer, who spilled the ball at Joselu's feet for the Spanish side's equaliser.\n\nDo you agree with Carlo Ancelotti? Have your say in the comments section\n\nAncelotti took issue with Joshua Kimmich's behaviour for Real Madrid's disallowed goal\n\n\"We are almost through, it's almost there and there was a very unusual mistake from our best player for the equaliser then we conceded the second one in stoppage time,\" Tuchel told TNT Sports after his team's defeat.\n\n\"Then we scored one and there was a disastrous decision from the linesman and the referee. It feels like a betrayal in the end. There was a huge fight, we left everything on the pitch and we were almost there. Now we say congratulations to Real Madrid.\n\n\"The linesman says sorry but that does not help. To raise the flag in a moment like this... The referee sees we get the second ball and we get the shot - it's a very, very bad decision. It's against the rules. It's a disaster. It's hard to swallow but that's the way it is.\"\n\nReal Madrid will go on to play Borussia Dortmund in the final after the German side won home and away against Paris Saint-Germain in the other semi-final. Tuchel, whose Bayern exit was confirmed earlier in the season, has two more Bundesliga games to go as he looks to make sure of second place behind runaway leaders Bayer Leverkusen.\n\nDON'T SCRAP REPLAYS!Join our petition to keep the magic of the FA Cup alive!\n\nJoin our new WhatsApp communityand receive your daily dose of Mirror Football content. {"uri": "8119043050", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "11:32:09", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T11:32:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T11:30:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.wionews.com/football/experienced-this-few-years-ago-furious-thomas-muller-recalls-ronaldos-controversial-goals-after-ucl-exit-719745", "title": "'Experienced this few years ago': Furious Thomas Muller recalls Ronaldo's controversial goals after UCL exit", "body": "During the press duties, Muller said the referees favoured the Spanish side, as they did in 2017\n\nBayern Munich midfielder Thomas Muller referenced Cristiano Ronaldo after Real Madrid came from behind to clinch a famous victory and dump the Bavarian side out of the Champions League. Muller was speaking about the disallowed Bayern goal that would have taken the match into extra time.\n\nThe German giants surrendered a one-goal lead to Madrid in the dying minutes of the game due to individual errors. However, during the press duties, Muller said the referees favoured the Spanish side, as they did in 2017\n\n\"Marciniak? He did not watch the video. He did not give himself the opportunity to look at it,\" said Muller, talking about the Polish referee.\n\n\"It's really strange, in such a situation, to whistle so fast. This often happens here in Madrid. \"I experienced this a few years ago, with two goals from Cristiano Ronaldo. But it was before the VAR,\" he added.\n\nThe incident Muller referred to occurred in the second leg of the UCL quarter-final tie in 2016-17 which saw Real Madrid beat Bayern 4-2 after extra-time to secure a 6-3 aggregate win.\n\nRonaldo scored twice in the added time, helping Madrid reach the next round. However, replays showed that both goals should have been chalked off due to offside. VAR had not been introduced in European competition at the time, so the on-field decisions were final.\n\nAlso read | Real Madrid stun Bayern Munich with late fightback to enter UEFA Champions League final\n\nBayern defender Matthijs de Ligt scored the contentious goal in the stoppage time but it was ruled out as the linesman had raised the offside flag. After the match, De Ligt claimed that the linesman apologised to him for disallowing the goal.\n\n\"The rule says that if it's not clear offside...you have to keep playing.\" De Ligt said. \"And if you go in the last minute and you whistle like this, I think this is a big mistake. If it's offside or not, I don't know, VAR can check it, but if you don't check it, how can you see it? This is a shame.\"\n\nThe offside on the De Ligt goal looked close to the naked eye but since the whistle was blown, VAR could not involve itself in the recheck process.\n\nThe Madrid win means the {"uri": "8118995887", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "11:01:21", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T11:01:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T11:00:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.espn.in/football/story/_/id/40110730/the-var-review-explaining-bayern-munich-offside-goal-real-madrid", "title": "The VAR Review: Explaining Bayern's offside 'goal' vs. Real Madrid", "body": "Video Assistant Referee causes controversy every week across Europe, and it even crops up in the Champions League.\n\nOn Wednesday night, in the second leg of the semifinal between Real Madrid and Bayern Munich, the Bundesliga club were desperately searching for an equaliser.\n\nThe score was 2-1 to Real Madrid, giving them a 3-2 aggregate lead, in the 13th minute of added time (only nine had been signalled.) Bayern had to score but they were thwarted by the offside flag and the referee blew his whistle. Bayern lost 2-1 and were eliminated.\n\nBayern manager Thomas Tuchel was raging, calling it a \"a disastrous decision from the linesman and the referee.\"\n\nSo what happened, who was to blame, and how does this all work with VAR?\n\n- How VAR decisions have affected every Prem club in 2023-24\n\nThe ball was played into the Real Madrid area, with Noussair Mazraoui challenging Ferland Mendy. The Los Blancos defender headed the ball away, and as the ball dropped into open space in the area the assistant, Tomasz Listkiewicz, raised his flag. Referee Szymon Marciniak immediately blew the whistle.\n\nThomas M\u00fcller nodded the ball to Matthijs de Ligt, and he fired into net past Andriy Lunin -- though the goalkeeper made no attempt to make a save because of the whistle so you cannot say Bayern were denied a goal. The Real Madrid defenders may have been affected too.\n\nPlay stopped at the whistle so there was nothing the VAR could do, so this is all about how and when the play should end from a delayed flag.\n\nAs no goal was scored, there's no VAR offside situation to judged. So we won't get the semiautomated offside visualisation for this and we've never know for certain.\n\nBut it looks exceptionally close and Mazraoui may well have been marginally onside to the boot of Antonio R\u00fcdiger.\n\nMazraoui's act of challenging Mendy for the aerial ball is an offside offence even though he didn't touch it.\n\nAssistants are told to keep the flag down on close offsides, and only raise it when a goal is scored or at the end of the attacking move.\n\nIndeed, Real Madrid's winning goal in the 91st minute came through this route. Joselu scored from a pass by R\u00fcdiger and as soon as the ball crossed the line the flag went up; the goal was awarded through a VAR review as the striker was behind the ball. That Bayern lost to a delayed flag when they were denied by a premature flag only adds to their frustration.\n\nThe VAR Handbook states that the assistant \"should delay the flag if an attacking player has a 'free run' or is in a very good scoring position moving directly to, or within, the penalty area.\"\n\nFor Listkiewicz, Bayern never gained possession from the original pass. It's headed away by Mendy and the offside Mazraoui failed to continue the attack. Had Mazraoui collected the pass, or headed it to a teammate himself, the assistant may not have been so ready to raise the flag.\n\nTechnically no, but in a game of such magnitude and at such a crucial stage it would have made much more sense for Listkiewicz just to hold the flag for a little longer to see what developed.\n\nWe see so many delayed flag situations which seem to be completely needless -- for instance, when a player is running to the corner or is offside by a large margin.\n\nThis is a Champions League semifinal, one of the biggest games of the season. You've got VAR, so just wait a few more seconds.\n\nHowever, Listkiewicz's flag doesn't control the game.\n\nDoes the referee share any of the blame?\n\nAbsolutely, in fact he is in charge of when the game is halted so, ultimately, the buck stops with Marciniak. We will see a number examples across a season of an assistant raising the flag too early, and the referee takes the decision to hold the whistle just in case anything develops.\n\nSo regardless of the flag, Marciniak should not have stopped the play when the ball first fell to M\u00fcller. It should have been clear to him there was still an attacking situation.\n\nThe VAR Handbook says: \"If the assistant flags for a tight/unclear offside and a player is about to score a goal, the referee should delay the whistle until the goal results so that if the AR has made a 'clear and obvious error' the goal can be allowed.\"\n\nMarciniak's role is about allowing the attacking phase to complete, not to judge how close the offside may have been. This is on Marciniak.\n\nIt's not been a stellar season for Marciniak, who refereed the 2022 World Cup final and the 2023 Champions League final. Listkiewicz was also the assistant for both showpiece games.\n\nMarciniak was the referee who wrongly awarded a VAR-advised stoppage-time penalty to Paris Saint-Germain against Newcastle United in December, which was converted and effectively resulted in the Magpies being knocked out of Europe.\n\nThe delayed flag and the attacking phase (which the VAR can review) are two different considerations.\n\nIf the assistant has identified an offside, the flag should go up at the quickest point when there's no clear attacking momentum.\n\nHowever, if the assistant doesn't spot an offside the VAR can go back through the whole phase.", "source": {"uri": "espn.in", "dataType": "news", "title": "ESPN"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": He has given us so much, without ever losing confidence in what he's capable of.\"\n\nAncelotti, who will be aiming for a third Champions League title as a coach when Real face Borussia Dortmund at Wembley on June 1, dismissed his counterpart Thomas Tuchel's complaints about a late disallowed goal but struggled to explain Real's latest extraordinary comeback in this competition.\n\nTuchel was incensed at a refereeing error in the 103rd-minute which he felt denied his side an equaliser, calling the decision \"a betrayal\" and \"disastrous\". Matthijs de Ligt scored but the linesman's flag was up for an offside against against Noussair Mazraoui and the referee, Szymon Marciniak, had already blown his whistle before the ball went in, leading the Real defenders to appear to stop.\n\n\"If they can complain about that we can complain about the goal Nacho had disallowed,\" said Ancelotti, referencing Real's disallowed goal for a shove, shortly after Alphonso Davies had put Bayern in front.\n\n\"It happened again: it has happened other times and it's inexplicable. It's something magical. We played well, we had chances, and then we had the strength not to lose our heads when they scored. We have completed a season that few expected.\"\n\nTuchel, who substituted Harry Kane in the 85th-minute with Bayern leading 1-0, felt the defeat could be explained by the officials' errors and a \"very unusual\" blunder by goalkeeper Manuel Neuer, who spilled Vinicius Jr's shot into Joselu's path for the equaliser.\n\n\"The linesman said sorry but that does not help,\" the Bayern Munich manager said. \"There are two mistakes.\n\n\"The first big mistake is from the linesman. He raised his flag straight away; to raise your flag in a situation like this, you have to be very, very sure it's offside. To have the guts, the balls, to raise the flag like this is a huge, huge call, and it is the wrong call. {"uri": "8118642721", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "07:10:30", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T07:10:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T07:09:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/thomas-tuchel-harry-kane-sub-32767484", "title": "Tuchel insists he has no regrets as decision to take off Kane in Madrid slammed", "body": "Thomas Tuchel maintains he has no regrets about bringing Harry Kane off during Bayern Munich's late Champions League exit to Real Madrid.\n\nThe Germans were poised to go through until the 89th minute when Joselu scored the first of his two quickfire strikes in the Spanish capital, which turned the tie on his head. Following Alphonso Davies' opening goal Tuchel proceeded to take off a host of his attacking stars.\n\nLeroy Sane, Jamal Musiala and Kane were all hauled off in the final stages. It meant, when Bayern went searching for an equaliser, they had many of their main attacking weapons sat on the bench. Ultimately they couldn't score the goal that would've forced extra-time.\n\nKane, in his debut season with the Bavarians, has scored 44 times, breaking numerous records en route. He couldn't influence matters in the final moments but Tuchel has no regrets over his tactical decisions.\n\nHe told TNT Sports: \"It hurts. It'll take a while to recover, but on the one hand it's a loss where we left it all out on the pitch. Of course, it's tough to accept. It's part of reality. No regrets. But on the other, there were too many injuries, a few too many substitutions, too many cramps.\n\n\"We started with a front four and by the end they were all off the pitch. And then Manu, who had been exceptional in saving us all night, made a mistake he wouldn't make in another 100 years.\"\n\nTuchel is expected to leave the Allianz Arena in the summer and will do so off the back of a rare trophyless season for the Munich outfit. The German though was left fuming when a late goal was ruled out as the linesman produced an early offside flag, with replays suggesting the Bayern players may have been onside.\n\nThe Bayern Munich marksman was bought off during the second-half\n\nThe ex-Chelsea boss said: \"We scored one, and it's a disastrous decision from the linesman and referee. It feels almost like a betrayal in the end because of that decision. The linesman said sorry - that does not help. To raise the flag in a decision like this, in a close decision in the last minute.\n\n\"And the referee as well, the referee does not have to whistle. He sees that we win the second ball. To whistle, it's a very, very bad decision and it's against the rules. It's a bad decision from both of them, it's a disaster. Tough to swallow.\"\n\nJoin our new WhatsApp community and receive your daily dose of Mirror Football content. "https://i2-prod.mirror.co.uk/incoming/article32767530.ece/ALTERNATES/s1200/0_GettyImages-2152096483.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9551379", "eventUri": "eng-9551379", "location": {"uri": "8118839301", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "09:20:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T09:20:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T09:19:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.espn.co.uk/football/story/_/id/40110730/the-var-review-explaining-bayern-munich-offside-goal-real-madrid", "title": "The VAR Review: Explaining Bayern's offside 'goal' vs. Real Madrid", "body": "Video Assistant Referee causes controversy every week across Europe, and it even crops up in the Champions League.\n\nOn Wednesday night, in the second leg of the semifinal between Real Madrid and Bayern Munich, the Bundesliga club were desperately searching for an equaliser.\n\nThe score was 2-1 to Real Madrid, giving them a 3-2 aggregate lead, in the 13th minute of added time (only nine had been signalled.) Bayern had to score but they were thwarted by the offside flag and the referee blew his whistle. Bayern lost 2-1 and were eliminated.\n\nBayern manager Thomas Tuchel was raging, calling it a \"a disastrous decision from the linesman and the referee.\"\n\nSo what happened, who was to blame, and how does this all work with VAR?\n\n- How VAR decisions have affected every Prem club in 2023-24\n\nWhat happened?\n\nThe ball was played into the Real Madrid area, with Noussair Mazraoui challenging Ferland Mendy. The Los Blancos defender headed the ball away, and as the ball dropped into open space in the area the assistant, Tomasz Listkiewicz, raised his flag, and referee Szymon Marciniak blew the whistle.\n\nThomas M\u00fcller nodded the ball to Matthijs de Ligt, and he fired into net past Andriy Lunin -- though the goalkeeper made no attempt to make a save because of the whistle so you cannot say Bayern were denied a goal. The Real Madrid players may have been affected too.\n\nPlay stopped at the whistle so there was nothing the VAR could do, so this is all about how and when the play stops from a delayed flag.\n\nWas Mazraoui onside?\n\nAs no goal was scored, there's no VAR offside situation to judged. So we won't get the semiautomated offside visualisation for this.\n\nBut it looks exceptionally close and Mazraoui may well have been marginally onside to the boot of Antonio R\u00fcdiger.\n\nMazraoui's act of challenging Mendy for the aerial ball is an offside offence even though he didn't touch it.\n\nWhy did the assistant raise his flag?\n\nAssistants are told to keep the flag down on close offsides, and only raise it when a goal is scored or at the end of the attacking move.\n\nIndeed, Real Madrid's winning goal in the 91st minute came through this route. Joselu scored from a pass by R\u00fcdiger and as soon as the ball crossed the line the flag went up; the goal was awarded through VAR review as the striker was behind the ball. That Bayern lost to a delayed flag when they were denied by a premature flag only adds to their frustration.\n\nThe VAR Handbook states that the assistant \"should delay the flag if an attacking player has a 'free run' or is in a very good scoring position moving directly to, or within, the penalty area.\"\n\nFor Listkiewicz, Bayern never gained possession from the original pass. It's headed away by Mendy and the offside Mazraoui failed to continue the attack. Had Mazraoui collected the pass, or headed it to a teammate, the assistant may not have been so ready to raise the flag.\n\nSo the assistant has done nothing wrong here?\n\nTechnically no, but in a game of such magnitude and at such a crucial stage it would have made much more sense for Listkiewicz just to hold the flag for a little longer to see what developed.\n\nWe see so many delayed flag situations which seem to be completely needless -- for instance, when a player is running to the corner or is offside by a large margin.\n\nThis is a Champions League semifinal, one of the biggest games of the season. You've got VAR, so just wait a few more seconds.\n\nHowever, Listkiewicz's flag doesn't control the game.\n\nDoes the referee share any of the blame?\n\nAbsolutely, in fact he is in charge of when the game stops so, ultimately, the buck stops with Marciniak. We will see a number examples across a season of an assistant raising the flag too early, and the referee takes the decision to hold the whistle just in case anything develops.\n\nSo regardless of the flag, Marciniak should not have stopped the play when the ball first fell to M\u00fcller. It should have been clear to him there was still an attacking situation.\n\nThe VAR Handbook says: \"If the assistant flags for a tight/unclear offside and a player is about to score a goal, the referee should delay the whistle until the goal results so that if the AR has made a 'clear and obvious error' the goal can be allowed.\"\n\nThis is on Marciniak.\n\nIt's not been a stellar season for Marciniak, who refereed the 2022 World Cup final and the 2023 Champions League final. Listkiewicz was also the assistant for both showpiece games.\n\nHe was the referee who wrongly awarded a VAR-advised stoppage-time penalty to Paris Saint-Germain against Newcastle United in December, which was converted and effectively resulted in the Magpies being knocked out of Europe.\n\nBut surely the attacking phase wasn't over?\n\nThe delayed flag and the attacking phase (which the VAR can review) are two different considerations.\n\nIf the assistant has identified an offside, the flag should go up at the quickest point when there's no clear attacking momentum.\n\nHowever, if the assistant doesn't spot an offside the VAR can go back through the whole phase.", "source": {"uri": "espn.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "ESPN.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8118266784", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "01:01:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T01:01:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T01:00:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://pattayaone.news/tuchel-voices-frustration-over-offside-decision-in-bayern-munichs-clash-with-real-madrid/", "title": "Tuchel Slams Offside Decision vs. Real Madrid", "body": "Bayern Munich's manager, Thomas Tuchel, expressed deep frustration over a crucial offside decision that impacted their Champions League semi-final against Real Madrid. Tuchel labeled the decision to halt play before his team's potential injury-time equalizer as a \"betrayal.\"\n\nThe pivotal moment occurred in the dying minutes of the second leg semi-final clash, with Bayern leading 1-0. Substitute Joselu scored twice in three minutes, reversing the scoreline in Real's favor. In the 13th minute of stoppage time, Bayern's Matthijs de Ligt found the net, only for the assistant referee to flag for offside.\n\nDespite protests and television replays indicating a marginal call, VAR couldn't intervene due to the play already being stopped. Tuchel vented his frustration post-match, condemning the decision as \"disastrous\" and \"against the rules.\"\n\nHe highlighted the impact of the offside call, stating it felt like a betrayal considering the pivotal moment in the match. Tuchel acknowledged the linesman's apology but emphasized its insufficiency given the circumstances.\n\nReferee Szymon Marciniak also apologized, but Tuchel emphasized that apologies won't change the outcome, especially with Real advancing to the final.\n\nLooking forward, Tuchel emphasized the importance of consistency and top-level officiating, stressing that referees must perform at the highest level in such critical matches.\n\nReal Madrid progresses to face Borussia Dortmund in the Champions League final at Wembley Stadium on June 1.", "source": {"uri": "pattayaone.news", "dataType": {"uri": "8118808931", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "09:02:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T09:02:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T09:01:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13399277/Bayern-offside-latest-Champions-League-controversy-ref-Marciniak-cup-final-successes.html", "title": "Bayern offside is latest Champions League controversy for ref...", "body": "GENEVA (AP) - It has been a challenging season in the Champions League for the 2022 World Cup final referee Szymon Marciniak and his support officials from Poland.\n\nTwo stoppage-time decisions by Marciniak and his team - affecting Bayern Munich in the semifinals on Wednesday and Newcastle in a group-stage game in November - have fueled referee controversies that are rare in the elite-level competition.\n\nBoth times, Marciniak's and his team\u00b4s interventions seemed to go against the widely understood advice UEFA gives match officials for its games: Don\u00b4t stop play immediately for tight offside calls and don\u00b4t award a penalty for handball when the ball has deflected off a player\u00b4s own body.\n\nA \"disastrous decision,\" Bayern coach Thomas Tuchel said of the assistant\u00b4s flag quickly raised and Marciniak\u00b4s whistle quickly blown for a possible offside in a last-chance attack in the 13th minute of stoppage time. Bayern needed one goal to force extra time against Real Madrid.\n\nMatthijs de Ligt then shot into Madrid\u00b4s net that, if allowed, would have tied the score at 2-2 and kept Bayern in with a chance to reach the final.\n\nIn Marciniak's previous controversy, Newcastle coach Eddie Howe spoke of a \"poor decision ... hugely frustrating\" when Paris Saint-Germain converted a spot kick eight minutes into stoppage time to salvage a 1-1 draw at Parc des Princes.\n\nBayern's Thomas Mueller, centre, reacts with referee during the Champions League semifinal second leg soccer match between Real Madrid and Bayern Munich at the Santiago Bernabeu stadium in Madrid, Spain, Wednesday, May 8, 2024. (AP Photo/Jose Breton)\n\nA win would have lifted Newcastle above PSG into second place in the group standings, behind leader Borussia Dortmund, with one round left. PSG ultimately advanced to the semifinals and was eliminated this week by Dortmund.\n\nMarciniak awarded the penalty for handball against Newcastle defender Tino Livramento only after being urged by his video review specialist to look at the pitchside monitor. That official, Tomasz Kwiatkowski, was stood down by UEFA from his subsequent Champions League game.\n\nKwiatkowski also was on duty on Wednesday in Madrid but never got a chance to advise on the marginal offside call against Bayern because Marciniak whistled to officially stop play before De Ligt could shoot.\n\n\"It feels almost like a betrayal in the end because of that decision,\" Tuchel said. \"The referee does not have to whistle. He sees that we win the second ball, he sees that we get the shot away. To whistle is a very, very bad decision. It\u00b4s against the rules and it\u00b4s a bad decision from both of them.\n\n\"The linesman said sorry. That does not help.\"\n\nDe Ligt said the assistant apologized to him, saying, \"I\u00b4m sorry, I made a mistake.\"\n\n\"If it\u00b4s offside or not, I don\u00b4t know, VAR can check it,\" the Bayern defender said. \"But if you don\u00b4t check it, how can you see it? This is a shame.\"\n\nUEFA did not comment on Thursday in line with its policy on field-of-play rulings.\n\nIn November, Marciniak\u00b4s video review specialist was removed from duty when UEFA\u00b4s chief of football was Zvonimir Boban, the Croatia great who won a Champions League with AC Milan. Boban left UEFA in January in a dispute with its president Aleksander Ceferin about governance standards.\n\nMarciniak and his team were already out of contention for handling the Champions League final on June 1 - when Madrid plays Dortmund at Wembley Stadium in London - because they officiated the showpiece game last year. They were widely praised for handling Manchester City\u00b4s 1-0 win over Inter Milan, and their work at the World Cup final in Qatar.\n\nControversy flared days before that Champions League final when Marciniak spoke at a business rally in Poland run by a far-right politician.\n\nUnder pressure from a Polish anti-discrimination group that works in soccer, and later UEFA, Marciniak made a statement to \"express my deepest apologies\" for being involved in the event. He said he was misled about its true nature.\n\n\"I humbly request an opportunity to make amends and regain your trust through my future actions,\" the referee said last June.\n\nStill recognized as among the world\u00b4s best, Marciniak will return to UEFA duty at the European Championship, where Bayern\u00b4s stadium is one of 10 venues for the June 14-July 14 tournament.\n\nIt will be a surprise if UEFA sends Marciniak and his team to work in Munich so soon.\n\nAP soccer: https://apnews.com/hub/soccer\n\nBayern's Thomas Mueller reacts during the Champions League semifinal second leg soccer match between Real Madrid and Bayern Munich at the Santiago Bernabeu stadium in Madrid, Spain, Wednesday, May 8, 2024. (AP Photo/Jose Breton)\n\nBayern Munich players argues with referee Szymon Marciniak at the end of the Champions League semifinal second leg soccer match between Real Madrid and Bayern Munich at the Santiago Bernabeu stadium in Madrid, Spain, Wednesday, May 8, 2024. (AP Photo/Manu Fernandez)\n\nBayern's goalkeeper Manuel Neuer, left, talks with referee Szymon Marciniak during the Champions League semifinal second leg soccer match between Real Madrid and Bayern Munich at the Santiago Bernabeu stadium in Madrid, Spain, Wednesday, May 8, 2024. Two minutes later Joselu - on loan from second-division side Espanyol - volleyed the Spanish giants into the lead from a cross by Antonio Rudiger.\n\n\"I don't know anything about being a hero, but I'm very happy. You can imagine,\" he said. \"It was incredible, something spectacular. This team never gives up, it's in its blood to fight to the end and that's what we've done.\n\n\"You always dream of this kind of performance, but not even my most beautiful dreams are as big as what happened.\"\n\nMadrid, who have already clinched the La Liga title, face German side Borussia Dortmund in the final at Wembley on June 1.\n\n\"It's something magical, there's no explanation,\" said Madrid coach Carlo Ancelotti.\n\nMadrid had trailed to Alphonso Davies' 68th-minute strike after the first leg in Germany ended 2-2.\n\nBayern were left raging at full-time after defender Matthijs de Ligt netted but play had been stopped beforehand for an offside flag against Noussair Mazraoui.\n\n\"There is no doubt that is against the rules of modern football,\" coach Thomas Tuchel said. \"An absolute disaster ... The clear rule is that the scene must continue.\"\n\nDe Ligt said the linesman had apologized to him after the game.\n\nTuchel took off Harry Kane, still chasing the first trophy of his career, in the final stages to try and hold on to victory but it slipped through his fingers.\n\nMeanwhile, Neuer said he was \"extremely bitter\" over his late howler that started Madrid's comeback.\n\nVinicius
