The whites and the Bernab\u00e9u always find a way out, an extra life, an unexpected hero. Madrid has a pact with the devil, with the football scriptwriter or with the myth of the European Cup itself.\n\nIt doesn't matter that Neuer was playing a great game or that Kane was close to 0-2. It doesn't matter that Joselu had only scored one goal since February 18. All of this collided in the 88th minute. Vin\u00edcius' shot bounced in front of the German goalkeeper and escaped him. No matter how carefully the plan is studied, even if they have done everything almost perfectly, no matter how close you are to falling into the trap, no matter how much the episode is about to end and you have success in your hand, there is still time for the illogical, to escape. There is always a loophole.\n\nIn Manchester, R\u00fcdiger scored the decisive penalty of the shoot-out. This time the German center back put in the cross for Joselu to score the second in the 91st minute, four minutes after 1-1. Anyone would have thought about the extension. {"uri": "8118503413", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "05:17:50", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T05:17:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T05:17:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4901960790157318, "url": "https://www.moviesonline.ca/the-ruling-was-issued-in-the-case-of-simon-marciniak-its-so-bad/", "title": "The ruling was issued in the case of Simon Marciniak. it's so bad", "body": "Later, the former FIFA referee spoke about a possible penalty kick. It may be difficult for Marciniak to manage key matches on the Old Continent. This is record news, but also bad news ahead of Euro 2024\n\nSimon Marciniak and his team had a perfect win in their Champions League semi-final, but the situation overshadowed everything in the 13th minute of extra time. Matthias de Ligt then scored a goal to make the score 2-2, which would have given Bayern Munich extra time, but the Polish referees blew their whistle for offside in this case.\n\nThe problem is that they did it while the procedure was still ongoing. For this reason, VAR was unable to check this action and definitively assess whether Bayern players were offside, which was determined in millimetres.\n\nThe instructions are clear: in such situations, you must wait until the end of the procedure to raise the flag and blow the whistle to check it. The mere raising of the flag by the lineman meant nothing, because Marciniak could have ignored that hint and waited. But when he blew the whistle just before the shot and the ball went into the goal, the option to check the situation definitely disappeared. This is exactly what is wrong in this case.\n\nWhether he was actually a hacker or not is a separate matter. The Germans are feeling angry at the present time, and Bayern Munich coach Thomas Tuchel has not yet accepted the apology of the Polish team, which admitted its mistake (according to the words of Bayern Munich representatives).\n\nChristina Unkel broke down the whole situation on CBS Sports.\n\n- I don't agree with Jamie Carragher that it was just a mistake by the line referee. Unfortunately, in this case there were two refereeing errors. Mazraoui was not in an offside position, so we don't even need to talk about whether he affected the match or not. But the first mistake was when the linesman raised his flag. This is contrary to the recommendations to rush to lift it, especially since the offensive work is not over yet - the former FIFA referee began her statement.\n\nThen she pointed out the second mistake. -- The referee accepted this recommendation and blew the offside whistle instead of saying, \"Thank you, I see you, but I will wait until the end of the procedure to blow the referee's whistle.\" This is very surprising. This is not one of the best refereeing teams in Europe, it is considered the best in Europe. This Polish team has just managed a Champions League final and a World Cup final. The linesman and referee's decision was surprising. It wasn't a good day for them.\n\n- It is never a good idea to talk about an obvious refereeing error. These are fundamental decisions that change the fate of the match... Neither the refereeing team nor the entire refereeing community will be satisfied with them. Especially when we have so much technology at our disposal that can help us avoid these kind of mistakes.\n\nIn addition, Onkel pointed out another mistake committed by Marciniak: Joselu's goal was initially disallowed at 2-1 in the 91st minute for offside (here Adam Kubcic raised his flag), but in this case the VAR intervened and the goal was conceded.\n\nIn addition, in one of Real Madrid's dangerous situations, there were two balls on the field, one of them confused some players, so Marciniak had to stop the match.\n\nUnkel also spoke about the potential consequences for Marciniak and his team. It may be difficult for them to get the next most important matches in the world and this is standard practice in such situations. The American is even more surprised, as she has confirmed several times, as Polish judges are considered among the best, if not the best, in the world.\n\nThis is even more bad news ahead of Euro 2024. Marciniak was to referee the prestigious opening match between Germany and Scotland (June 14). It is not known whether this error will affect whether he will officiate this match, although after the Champions League semi-final match on Wednesday, the chances of him being able to officiate the Euro 2024 semi-final match, for example, It may decline is unlikely, though not because it is so weak. On the contrary, because he fell victim to his own success!\n\n-- Simon Marciniak has already refereed three Grand Finals, and now is definitely the time to give the other judges credit. But the opening match is a completely different matter. This is a great prestige and a great responsibility. The opening match referee must set an example for other referees in how to referee throughout the tournament and how to interpret different situations. Such a match must be led by someone who ensures the highest level. {"uri": "8119052129", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "11:37:00", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T11:37:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T11:36:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4862745106220245, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/thierry-henry-kate-abdo-prettywoman-32770621", "title": "Thierry Henry leaves Kate Abdo lost for words with 'Pretty Woman' comparison", "body": "Thierry Henry had Kate Abdo in stitches after comparing the refereeing controversy at the end of Bayern Munich's defeat by Real Madrid to a scene from Pretty Woman.\n\nBayern were knocked out of the Champions League in the semi-final second leg on Wednesday night after Real came from behind to claim a dramatic 2-1 win. Alphonso Davies curled in a stunning opener to put Bayern ahead before Joselu came off the bench to score twice in three minutes to seal the comeback.\n\nBut there was controversy at the end after the linesman's flag denied Bayern what could have been an equaliser. Matthijs de Ligt rifled in but only after Szymon Marciniak's whistle had been blown, despite the rules stating that officials should let play continue in such situations.\n\nThomas Tuchel said he felt \"betrayed\" by the call, while De Ligt, Thomas Muller and Bayern director of sport Max Eberl all voiced their anger. Former Arsenal striker Henry was on the CBS Sports panel for the post-match discussion, which he took in a very different direction.\n\nDON'T SCRAP REPLAYS!Join our petition to keep the magic of the FA Cup alive!\n\nAsked if he understood Bayern's frustration, Henry replied: \"One million per cent. My view of it at the time wasn't so much on the linesman, because I've seen it before. I've seen linesmen doing that (putting their flag up), but the big man (referee) takes the decision, always him, he is the chief. Why did you blow your whistle? Just let it go. You have something that can tell you if there's an offside or not. Christina [Unkel, CBS' rules analyst] has said it already: massive, just like in Pretty Woman, huge mistake, huge.\"\n\nFor those not familiar with the 1990 romantic comedy Pretty Woman, Henry was referring to a scene in which Julia Roberts' character berates a sales assistant in a clothes shop, describing her behaviour as a \"big mistake, huge\". The reference was not lost on Abdo, but it flew over the heads of fellow pundits Jamie Carragher and Micah Richards.\n\nAfter an awkward pause, Carragher gamely tried to continue the football chat with: \"No, it is a massive mistake. What Christina said about officials at this level - you know they are going to be the best - but to explain that these are actually seen as the best...\"\n\nThierry Henry is a big Julia Roberts fan clearly\n\nBut Abdo could not hold it together, bursting out laughing before saying: \"Sorry, I'm so thrown by you quoting Pretty Woman...\" Henry added: \"A 'huge mistake', the bags, you remember? You don't know? OK, let's go back.\" Carragher admitted: \"You've thrown me a bit there.\"\n\nThe tone of the chat was a long way from the tone of the backlash from those of a Bayern persuasion. \"There was a disastrous decision from the linesman and the referee,\" Tuchel said. \"It feels like a betrayal in the end. There was a huge fight, we left everything on the pitch and we were almost there. Now we say congratulations to Real Madrid. The linesman says sorry but that does not help.\"\n\nJoin our new WhatsApp community and receive your daily dose of Mirror Football content. {"uri": "2024-05-350006480", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "09:17:54", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T09:17:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T08:42:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0, "url": "https://www.hjnews.com/sports/nation/bayern-offside-is-latest-champions-league-controversy-for-ref-marciniak-after-cup-final-successes/article_7b1818fb-5154-5d39-bdd9-b4a49bb03ed8.html", "title": "Bayern offside is latest Champions League controversy for ref Marciniak after cup final successes", "body": "GENEVA (AP) -- It has been a challenging season in the Champions League for the 2022 World Cup final referee Szymon Marciniak and his support officials from Poland.\n\nTwo stoppage-time decisions by Marciniak and his team -- affecting Bayern Munich in the semifinals on Wednesday and Newcastle in a group-stage game in November -- have fueled referee controversies that are rare in the elite-level competition.\n\nBoth times, Marciniak's and his team's interventions seemed to go against the widely understood advice UEFA gives match officials for its games: Don't stop play immediately for tight offside calls and don't award a penalty for handball when the ball has deflected off a player's own body.\n\nA \"disastrous decision,\" Bayern coach Thomas Tuchel said of the assistant's flag quickly raised and Marciniak's whistle quickly blown for a possible offside in a last-chance attack in the 13th minute of stoppage time. Bayern needed one goal to force extra time against Real Madrid.\n\nMatthijs de Ligt then shot into Madrid's net that, if allowed, would have tied the score at 2-2 and kept Bayern in with a chance to reach the final.\n\nIn Marciniak's previous controversy, Newcastle coach Eddie Howe spoke of a \"poor decision ... hugely frustrating\" when Paris Saint-Germain converted a spot kick eight minutes into stoppage time to salvage a 1-1 draw at Parc des Princes.\n\nA win would have lifted Newcastle above PSG into second place in the group standings, behind leader Borussia Dortmund, with one round left. PSG ultimately advanced to the semifinals and was eliminated this week by Dortmund.\n\nMarciniak awarded the penalty for handball against Newcastle defender Tino Livramento only after being urged by his video review specialist to look at the pitchside monitor. That official, Tomasz Kwiatkowski, was stood down by UEFA from his subsequent Champions League game.\n\nKwiatkowski also was on duty on Wednesday in Madrid but never got a chance to advise on the marginal offside call against Bayern because Marciniak whistled to officially stop play before De Ligt could shoot.\n\n\"It feels almost like a betrayal in the end because of that decision,\" Tuchel said. \"The referee does not have to whistle. He sees that we win the second ball, he sees that we get the shot away. To whistle is a very, very bad decision. It's against the rules and it's a bad decision from both of them.\n\n\"The linesman said sorry. That does not help.\"\n\nDe Ligt said the assistant apologized to him, saying, \"I'm sorry, I made a mistake.\"\n\n\"If it's offside or not, I don't know, VAR can check it,\" the Bayern defender said. \"But if you don't check it, how can you see it? This is a shame.\"\n\nUEFA did not comment on Thursday in line with its policy on field-of-play rulings.\n\nIn November, Marciniak's video review specialist was removed from duty when UEFA's chief of football was Zvonimir Boban, the Croatia great who won a Champions League with AC Milan. Boban left UEFA in January in a dispute with its president Aleksander \u010ceferin about governance standards.\n\nMarciniak and his team were already out of contention for handling the Champions League final on June 1 -- when Madrid plays Dortmund at Wembley Stadium in London -- because they officiated the showpiece game last year. They were widely praised for handling Manchester City's 1-0 win over Inter Milan, and their work at the World Cup final in Qatar.\n\nControversy flared days before that Champions League final when Marciniak spoke at a business rally in Poland run by a far-right politician.\n\nUnder pressure from a Polish anti-discrimination group that works in soccer, and later UEFA, Marciniak made a statement to \"express my deepest apologies\" for being involved in the event. He said he was misled about its true nature.\n\n\"I humbly request an opportunity to make amends and regain your trust through my future actions,\" the referee said last June.\n\nStill recognized as among the world's best, Marciniak will return to UEFA duty at the European Championship, where Bayern's stadium is one of 10 venues for the June 14-July 14 tournament.\n\nIt will be a surprise if UEFA sends Marciniak and his team to work in Munich so soon.\n\nAP soccer: https://apnews.com/hub/soccer", "source": {"uri": "hjnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Herald Journal"}, "authors": To raise the flag in a moment like this... The referee sees we get the second ball and we get the shot - it's a very, very bad decision. It's against the rules. It's a disaster.
